UPDATED: APR 9, 2013 Brown cognac colour, white rim. Quite sour aroma, caramel, fruity, cherry, citrus, leather and wood. Lots of red wine. Sour flavour, acetic, vinegar, citrus, hard sour. A light sweetness coming through. Quite thin, watery body. Finish acetic acid, citrus, lactic acid.
I would think this a decent oud bruin. Good, but not brilliant. Too unbalanced sour, and that while Im a lover of sours. Was expecting more of this, considering its high scores.
(From 375cL bottle -Batch 10- @ home)
Bottle pour from a trade.  I always forget that these have sediment on the bottom and just pour the whole thing...  brown + pinot is good here

Pours a brown with a reddish tint. Smells like a big red wine with buttery oak. First sip hits you with mixed berries and oak barrels. This beer toes the line of beer and wine since the carbonation is light. I felt like I needed to let this one breathe a bit before enjoying it.

Här drar man ju på lite extra poäng pga att det är så hög raritetsnivån. Sjukt kul att testa denna. Tack Br Wallén. Smakar lite som man skulle föreställa sig att en sur brown ale skulle smaka. Kvalitet på alla nivåer. Aaaaw yeeeeaaahh
Wine aroma, cherry flavors. Sours taste. I need to train my palate to enjoy sours. #BeerSnob
Soured. Berries, barel and wood finish simply one o the most well crafted slurs Ive had.
UPDATED: APR 8, 2013 This is a great sour. You get the pinot noir barrel flavors, sour cherries, a little sweetness. It ages well
375ml bottle at Hunahpus Day 2013. Pours with a slight white head. Sour grapes and apples. Tart, but not overwhelming and mouthpuckering. Refreshing.
Rich amber color, abundant head, delicious aroma, and even better taste. Aroma is citrus-y, sour, candy-sweet, yet somehow balanced and distinctly beer-like. Flavor is distinctly sour. A must have!

My second sit down with this beer, 375ml corked a caged quite sexily. split into 2 snifters per bottle and cork instructions, batch dated 8.27.12. Pours a ruddy brownish red with no head to speak of. Nose of red fruits and hay and a little basement. This bangs with all the best Flanders styled beers for me, super refreshing tartness without being overbearing, lots of beautiful horse blankest wrapping bowls of cherries rolling around in mouth and having a party. I wish it was hot out because I feel like this would make you feel really special on a hot day, will procur another bottle to test this hypothesis. Mouthfeel is full and carbonation is low to medium letting the funk take the front seat. Amazing brew, a reason to fall in love with sours.

Oh, Supplication. Always the second fiddle to its big brother Cons. Yet somehow this batch (08/27/12) captures the magic of Supp better than precious batches, blending the flavors & bacteria together better than any previous batch I've tried. Fruity, yet dry; sour, yet strongly oaky. I could drink this every day.

Perhaps the best sour brown ale available. Nice brown ale backbone, complemented beautifully by the Brett. What does it for me though is the subtle cherry flavor imparted during the barrel aging. The red wine barrel taste also makes an appearance at the end. Wonderfully complex yet balanced sour!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
If you like sours this is the one. Red color with a small head. Pleasant smell of tart cherries and sour grapes. Taste is dominated by a sour cherry flavor. I think this is my favorite sour.

Love it. Amber color, funky, Pinot nose. This beer just pops, sour initially, but finishes smooth, you definitely get the cherry and Pinot notes as well.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2016 Round 2 of Supplication after a little more experience...damn good beer. 


375ml bottle thanks to changeup45. WARNING: stout drinkers first sour. Have the pleasure of drinking a batch 4. After popping the cork I got a familiar aroma of red wine. Maybe some barley wine mixed in. Pours a murky brown color into my balloon tulip glass. Keeps a nice steady thin foam island in the glass. Slight lacing. Sip #1. Holy moly this is gross. OK not gross just not expected. "Give it a chance Art". I keep telling myself "Think wine". Sip #2. Another whiff. Funky aroma. I smell some cherries. Wow is this thing Sour! The taste reminds me of Warheads candies I had as a kid. Maybe a cherry warhead. I wish I had a comparison with a fresh one at this point but Im sure this is a delicious beer to some. No concern that it has gone bad. Let me check back after Ive acclimated a bit..............OK Im back. Im getting used to this. More cherries coming out now. Still super sour. Causing phlegm to build up. Be right back. ...............ok Im still going strong. I hope this is entertaining to some. If you enjoyed this message me and send me some other top 100 sours. Ill do the same. The sourness is tolerable now. I think this is probably how first time IIPA drinkers feel. Im definitely going to revisit and re-rate this one later. So my last few sips have actually been enjoyable and have changed my perception of this beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Ruby grapefruit colour with a thin, lacing head. Pinot noir hits you full in the face, but with time the cherries and a slight funkyness become more prominent. Massive sour punch filled with grapefruit and sour cherry flavors. Thin, well-carbonated body which adds to the acidic kick of the beer. Clean, tart ending that leaves you reaching for more.

Bottle from Mill Valley Market..Golden brown with a thin layer of white head that fizzles out nearly immediately. Poured without much yeast, so its fairly clear. Smell is very tart. A good amount of grape/wine in the nose. There is also some sour cherry.  At the first sip, the flavor overwhelms, in a good way. The smell was an indication of what I would find in the taste. Its incredibly tart/sour. Theres a bit of wine and sour cherry or raspberry in it. The Brett comes out hard in the taste. The carbonation compliments the flavor quite well. Theres a lot of effervescence that spreads the flavor throughout my palate.  Overall, this is a remarkable beer.

12oz bottle. Pours hazy red with a small but long lasting head. Aromas of cherry wood and hints of chocolate. Highly carbonated. Pleasantly sour and tart. Some background chocolate and roasted flavors. Finishes with a slight sweetness and lingering cherry. Awesome beer.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a hazy, dark brownish ruby color with a half finger head that dissipates very slowly and leaves a blanket of lacing. Tons of sediment, but that is expected with the amount of yeast added. Smells of funky, sour cherries, oak, vinegar, grapes, lots of funkiness. Lots of dryness that really does give it a wine-like smell. Smells almost like a cherry warhead. Taste starts with a very astringent, dry, sour cherry flavor, as well as some oak and funkiness. Then get some of the brown ale qualities: slight breadiness, maybe some cocoa (but i could just be imagining that), some carmel malt. Then the astringent sour notes from the brett and bacteria come back even stronger, along with lots more cherry, grape, funkiness, vinegar, oak, some carmel. Extremely dry finish that blends the wine and the beer qualities nicely. So sour, yet extremely balanced. High medium body with a creamy mouthfeel. Very lively carbonation from the refermentation that does give it a very champagne-like crisp finish. Very complex and so delicious. Just getting into this style, but I have a feeling I wont come across many sours better than this one. Hope to try this again someday.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2015 Bottle. Cloudy reddish amber with a thin tan head that lasts in a ring. Aromas of tart cherry and wood upfront, light malt, vinous notes and spice. Flavor is tart cherry, wood, lightt caramel and light fig. Medium bodied, smooth with a dry end.

On tap @ Super Deli Mart. Pours golden light brown with thin head. Aroma is sharp tartness and mildly sweet malt. Taste is smooth grapefruit tart nose followed by a medium caramel malt body. Rich barrel aged notes of cherries, currants, oak, and buttery tanned leather follow. Perfectly balanced and delicious. Gotta get these guys back in Washington state ASAP.

Bottle sample at a tasting at yoavs place. Thanks Dror Sapir. Batch 008. Pours clear-to-hazy rusty with white ring. Apple vinegar, air freshener, rose-water aroma, delicate sour taste. Medium body, very fizzy, ciderish finish.

thnx to bisippin ! 
tasted with 77ships
pours amber, white foam, smell is cherrie
taste is very dry, sour , cherries, ... NICE ! very sour one, yet so balanced! im shocked i like this so much more than i thought ! damn !

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2014 On tap, pours a dark amber/red color with a thick white head with good lacing. Smells of cherries, pinot noir , and oak from the wine barrel used. Tastes of sour cherries, mixed with wine and wood. Mouthfeel is between light and medium and slightly creamy. Overall this the best sour Ive had out of what Ive tried.

THX! to Kraddel for sharing this one. 375 ml. bottle  batch 0827 12. Bright reddish, some orange shading amber with little white head. Nose is sour raspberries, picking up more raspberry here than cherries to be honest, getting cherry skins in here as well, quite sour, strongly thinned out sour malts, strongly sour & thinned out, cherry pits, acidic red wine & tartness coming through. Sour raspberry pits coming through in the taste, balanced sour vinegar, lots of sour barrel & vinegar interacting with the whole, red wine vinegar, puckering but not overt, very nice, quite clean, thinned out, light touch of sweetish malts, sour & tart but very enjoyable, red wine coming through. Very cleaned out. Lovely. Very lovely & very easy to drink.

Bottle. Pours an almost amber with a little disappating white head. Aroma is tart sour with some wine, flavor is very similar. Nice tart cherries on the to gue. Interesting tart flavor, not super sour but a good beer.

Bottle. 8/12 batch. The pour is a hazy red/orange. The aroma is super sour. The taste is rather smooth for a sour.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2013 Bottle: Vintage 2010:
Thanks Steve:
Ashy vanilla colored head which is more a lacing and changes slowly into a ring with an island in the middle. The beer has a hazy amber color with a light mber ruby shine...
The aromas are nice(!) and complex: yeast, wild yeast, brett, (white) wine, berries, wood, flowers, wet stone, a hint of mashed apricot, caramel, hint of something sugary and some spices.
The flavours are amazing too, a full mix of: good tart, berries, grape, lemon, yeast, wild yeast, wood, hint of stone, sour yeast, hint of something light malty, light (spicy), vinous notes and a hint of bitterness.
Low carbo, soft mouthfeel, full body and a creamy texture.
Wauwie, this is a hell of a good beer! Lovely smell, lovely taste, balanced and just super good!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle, shared by a friendly Count. Pours a nice mahagony brown, opaque body, small and thin white head. Aroma is extremely rich, subtle and deep. Hints of vanilla, dried red fruit, cherry, mild wood and some earthiness. The taste is a sublime symbiosis between terrific beer and wine flavours. A velvety mouthfeel carries with it intense fruit, both sweet and sour. Perfect tartiness in aftertaste. A rather poetic beer almost

Perfect sour beer. The sour cherries is the dominant flavor but can also taste the oak flavor added by the Pinot Noir barrel.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aromas of sour cherries, subtle oak, subtle wine, and some caramel.  Hazy, orange-amber with a mostly dissipating, tan head.  Bitter, tart, and tangy.  Medium bodied, refreshing, and leaves a funky, tart aftertaste.

From the small bottle: Its amber-brown with some burgundy tones, plenty of suspension and a small amount of rapidly dissipating tan-burgundy bubbles. Aromas of funky oak, pinot and sour cherries. The flavor is not as sour as I expected, but still tart. Sour cherry with some caramel and a bit of bitterness and carboardy funk. Effervescent but soft carbonation. All in all a very lovely delicious beer.
375ml bottle poured in a tulip glass. Dark red orange with tart and oak aroma. Sour tart cherry taste. A bit bitter up front.
One of my top beers that I tried at the brewpub. Beautiful sourness with a balance of bitterness. Aromas are of sour cherry.

Batch 062212. 375ml bottle into a tulip glass. Huge thanks to WesM63, this is a huge want of mine!

A - Pours a clear dark ruby body. Lots of rising carbonation and one finger of off white foam. Minimal lacing and retention.

S - Cherries, oak, vanilla, red wine, and some tart vinegar. Quite nice.

T - Tart cherries and oak. A bit of vinegar and moldy cheese with a long sour finish. Not very well balanced and a bit harsh. Aftertaste is clean with a lasting acetic bite. Not quite at the level of a flanders our bruin. Super sour and just a bit jumbled when it comes to the flavors 

M - Crisp and lively, medium bodied. 

O - Super sour with a nice cherry presence, but this one did not live up to the hype for me. Glad to have had the chance to try it though.
On tap at Russian River, served in goblet. Reddish brown with a small white head. Aromas of sour cherry and white wine. Potent but balanced sour cherry flavors that arent overpowering.

Pours cloudy brown, reddish with very little head....
Aroma is sour, lactic, tart cherry, brett...
Taste is nicely bracing, sour, funky fruit...
Tangy and woody.....

Enjoyed via a bottle (Batch 4) from the cellar. Pours a cloudy reddish gold with a medium, lacy, white head. The glass is full of carbonation suspended throughout the glass. The aroma is effervescent and of tart, unsweetened cherries. The taste is so bitter it seems to suck the saliva out of your mouth finishing with some wetness and a tart pie cherry taste. It is extremely smooth with a creamy mouth feel and no hint of an alcohol taste or burn, which is something to be said for a beer clocking in at 7%. Overall, quite a tasty concoction all around.
Bottle @ home Batch 007... It pours reddish copper with a small off white head.....The aroma is sour and vinous.... The flavor is sour cherries, apples, light brett, woody notes and tart....
Poured from a 375 ml bottle shared at home.  Pours a reddish copper with a thin off white head.  Aroma of sour apple.  Sour cherries,  hints of oak.  Bracing tart finsih.
deep reddish brown. Cherry wine like nose. Some sour funk too. Bitter sour. Barrel and cherry notes when the sour gives way. Quite enjoyable

12.68 bottle, 12 to 15 months. Aroma is cherries and sour. Almost smells like wine. Appearance is light brown, and pretty carbonated. Little head. The taste is sour with cherries. Hardly any brown flavor. Palate is sour. Overall, a very good sour, for my taste. I look forward to more. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle courtesy of mashmaster.  Funky brett, oak, tart lactic cherry aroma. Cloudy amber with a minimal off-white head. Tart cherry, sweet vinous, smooth woody, funky, lactic sour flavor. Light body, lively carbonation.

Bottle.  Brett, lactic/sour cherry, and mild caramel malt aroma.  Cloudy orange-brown with minimal head.  Sweet-tart cherry malt flavor with light sour/barnyard finish.  Excellent blending.  Excellent.

On tap at Stone Brewery.. Pours a dark rusty orange color. Nose is sour, tart and pungent. Taste is tart and sour with a hint of sweetness at the end. Mouth puckering, not a fan of sour ales, but leave it to Russian River to
make be a believer. Quaff Score 8 / 10

On draft at Stone Brewery. Pours a copper amber with a tan head and aroma of alcohol and oak. Taste is dominated by tart and sourness with oak notes as well with a sweet finish. Very sour, puckering wild ale

Bottle from 2006.  Aroma of cherries and cat pee. Pours a murky caramel orange with very little head.  Citrus sour, very tart and sharp with a cherry sweetness on the finish.  I am not a fan of the style but this one was good.  Much more refined and better executed than some of the other sours Ive had.

Bottle
Appearance - Pink body, light bubbles, thin head
Aroma - Cherries, wood, yeast, sour candy
Taste - Sour cherries, oak, vanilla, tart, dry finish

This beer was super complex and simultaneously refreshing. As usual - OmegaX, you are the man!

Bottle into snifter. Nose is funky, tart, full of cherries and oak aromas with a touch of vanilla. Excellent aroma. Body is light brown with a pink hue to it. Taste follows suit with a nice tart acidity, tons of cherry flavor and a light oak flavor balancing everything out. I think the balance of flavors is right on with this one. Great stuff.
UPDATED: MAY 31, 2013 Excellent beer, nice funk and wine aroma, smooth and tart finish. My favorite RR sour.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2012 ~12 oz corked bottle from jhogan4 Thanks again.  Really sour and tart, bit of cherries, sour berries .  Has a nice harsh sour bite.  Quite a bit of carbonation, even for a sour.  Probably the best sour Ive had.

Bottle. Pours reddish amber. No head. Very fizzy, like sparling wine. Smells of wine. Tastes of wine, cherries. Starts slightly sweet, ends very sour. Cant pick out much more than the tartness from the cherries and the pinot finish. Not my favorite style, but to each their own.

23/11/12 - 375ml bottle from Healthy Spirits (San Francisco, CA) @ home - batch 10 (2012-1301) Thanks to Thieu for getting the bottle to Belgium!
Clear amber to copper red beer, small off-white head, unstable, adhesive. Aroma: soruish, red fruits, cranberries, raisins, bit sweet, red wine vinegar. MF: quite some carbon, medium body. Taste: sour start, red wine vinegar, sour berries, cherry jam, bitter touch, citrus. Aftertaste: citrus, pretty bitter, sour candy.

375ml bottle. Hazy, pinkish brown colour, small off-white head. Sour aroma, cherry but with very little sweetness, some wood, red wine vinegar and basement funk. Sour dominates the flavour, no sweetness, hints of cherry, more red wine vinegar. Mouthfeel was kind of wet. Overall, this wasnt as much like a lambic as I was expecting, but either way I dont think sour beer is for me.

Draft at Bigwood 12/6/2012 [4/11].  From notes.
Aroma:  Tart cherry.  Acidity.  simple, purposeful.  After sitting for awhile longer, a little faint grass/earth in the aroma too.
Appearance:  Amber meets ruby.  Nice head and lacing.  A little murky.  Inviting.
Taste:  Sweet cherry start, tart cherry finish, connected by ... what is that? I want to say brown sugar, earth and straw -- it works beautifully whatever it is.
Palate:  Like the others Ive rated so far today, basically perfect.  Finish lingers just right.
Overall: So much more memorable than my last tasting.  A delight.

082712 375ml bottle. A quintessential domestic, barrel-aged sour. Focused aromas and flavors of tart, sour cherries, browning apple, apple cider vinegar, leather, hints of Pinot noir and oak barrel. Lighter bodied, delicate super-fine carbonation, tart and DRY. More like a dry cider, then a "beer". I love this ale. Simply delicious.

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...
bottle. pours light brown with tannish head. big sour cherry and funky cheese aroma. taste is very tart. cherry and pinot oaky
Light brown. Lots of fruity tones come through from the Pinot and go well with the oaky aroma. Its just too sour.

Another we dont miss beer from Russian River. What can I say? It was amazing. Tart cherry, some nice wet wood, pinot noir. Great sour. Nothing I can say that hasnt already been said. This brewery is on another level.

Bottle 375ml. [Batch 10]
Pours amber with medium beige head. Nice lacing. Aroma is of Pinot Noir, fruits, very sligth bretts. Taste is of fruits, cherries, acidity, sourness. Palate: light-medium body. Overall: Very good. Not too cloying. Nice fruits, but they could be more present.
Arôme de cerise, de bretts et de pinot noir. Goût sucré (rappelle celui des bonbons aux fraises), surmonté dune touche de pinot (pourrait être un peu plus présent). Texture sirupeuse.

Bottle (375 ml) batch 010. Traded by totoropanda, thanks Daniel! Slightly hazy amber with a small creamy beige head and intense lacing. Aroma of cherries, pinot noir, wood, red fruits, brettanomyces, cough syrup and slight sweetness. Taste is moderately sour with cherries, red fruits, cough syrup, slight brettanomyces, pinot noir and wood. Mouthfeel is sirupy and slightly dry. Great balance and nice use of the cherries (perfectly integrated to this beer). Very complex. I would like the pinot noir to be a little more present.

Clear light brown, amber, red. Small white head on the rim of the glass. Taste is sour, oaky with some nice vanilla notes, raisins, balanced sourness, some tart vinegar at the end. Outstanding sour! (Will have again and comment more on aroma, was hard to get in tasting glass at RR)
Sour aroma with lots of oak in the flavor.  Brown and murky pour.  The taste is not overly sour.  Mouth is full.  Some tart cherry.  Probably the best sour Ive had.

Bottle from trade with michaelinwa.  Thanks!  Pours a clear dark cherry color with a small amount of fizzy head that quickly fades.  Aroma is dominated by sour cherries with hints of wine of sour berries.  Taste is very cherries with a very wine like finish.  Pretty dry.  Doesnt taste artificial at all like some sours but its still a bit more sour than I like to enjoy.  Im realizing that I wont ever be a big fan of sour beers.  I wanted to try this because it was described as a sour cherry brown ale but I didnt recognize anything with this beer that resembles a brown ale.  Overall, not my favorite sour but still pretty solid.

Bottle, thanks to fredrik_!
Orange red with a white head.
Aroma: cherries, marzipan.
Taste: cherries, chocolate coated cherries, marzipan, wood, a bit artificial flavour, sweet and sour, not very tart.
Medium bodied, sharp carbonation.
Not a personal favourite, I dont like the artificial cherry flavour.

Bottle received in trade. 

The cherrys in this beer are too artificial and it lacks that dryness and complexity that i like.

Tart cherries, lactic acid, sweet malts, vinous, a bit herbal, a bit of funk, and a slightly sweet finish that also packs more sour cherry. Such a great beer. Im not a sour beer fanboy, but I can get behind a beer this good no matter my preferences.

The cherry flavor is too sweet for me.  I can tell this is well done just not my style.  Sour and fruity

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2013 375 ml bottle, sampled at our Californian motorhome tour. Pours clear amber with brown hue. Small white head. Aromas are blended in the most wonderful way and are made of tart cherries, noble Pinot Noir scents (finest Burgundy wines), wood and candy sugar/caramel. Loght body with an excellent balance between sourness and sweetness. Taste is cherries, raisins and gentle red wine vinegar touch. What a beer! One of my all time favourites! 

Compares to the Rodenbach Caractère Rouge, but a few steps higher on the refinement scale.

Bottle thanks to the ever so generous BlackIPA, thanks Shawn! Aroma is full of lactic acid and (subtle) tart cherries with a really good Flanders Red character. Full lactic blast attacks the nostrils and tastebuds with a bit of wood and cherries in the flavor. Mouthfeel is good and pleasant, carbonation is just fine. Feels like a good gueuze/wild ale really, not a kriek overloaded with cherries like my description might sound. Cherries really take a back seat here, only contributing to the sour and not much to aroma/flavor. A really nice sour by Russian River, cant wait to try their Consecration soon!

Batch 007 generously sent from northropfrye!  Clear brown with a pink hue. Aroma is alright, some sour cherry and a little funk but not strong.  Starts very sour but opens up to a really incredible wood, grape, cherry and some Brett. Finishes dry. Incredible beer!

Wine grape, brett and sour... I can see what makes people go goo-goo over this.   Quality wild ferment notes, wood, and pith and tannin.   

Draft in BP, as well bottles here and there.

Brownish amber in color... Aroma is Pinot Noir mixed with Brett sourness...  Rich malts and sourness blended to perfection with notes of oak and grapes.... Really dont know how to describe this, it is just amazing....

Shared by the generous Motherbrother. Pours dark, slightly clouded amber with a light brown semi-thick head. Smells like summer and guess what - sour cherries. Vinous with some citrus. Finishes of really bitter. The same kind of bitter you get, when you eat frozen strawberries. The brett makes the beer much more complex, but dominates in no way.. Semi carb. Very nice beer!

Pour a slightly hazy light amber, with a small slightly fluffy white head. 
Aroma has quite some oak to it, with brett,  sour cherries, slight funk, slight tart, (pinot noir grapes?). Quite delicious. 
The taste is pretty sour upfront, with a slightly fruity sweet aftertaste. Medium bodied, with a fizzy carbonation. Really is a solid sour ale. Really beautiful with the amount of pinot noir barrel in this one. Thanks to the guys at "Bierkoning" for getting me this.

Copper brown color with a fluffy white head, the American Brett perfection. Sour amarena aroma with vanilla hints. Really fresh one with a very long and complex aftertaste

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at 16 Tons Cafe. Im not in love with the aroma, but good lord, is this a lovely beer. Definitely one of the finest American examples of the style. A nice, copper color, and a fruity head that was initially a little off-putting. Well balanced between sweetness and tartness, every sip reveals something different. I should say that draft makes this beer much better.
Clear amber, little head or lacing. Sour cherry on the nose. Flavor has wine astringency, dry, fruits, then fades to nutty flavor, hazelnut maybe. Complex.

Great hue to the body. At first pour, theres no lacing and a thin white head that quickly dissipates into a ring. Overall, vinous, but rather than grapes its cherries really -- a cherry wine quality. Lightly carbonated and sour, but not mouth-puckering so. Its smooth and funky. I like it. Finish the bottle with its sediment and suddenly the body is murky with an off-white head. Bittersweet, sour, and dry. This is nice, interesting and dynamic.

Medium beige head quickly disappears. Clear reddish brown body with light carbonation. Strong earthy cherry aroma with vinous strawberry notes. Dry-sweetish-acidic earthy papery vinous cherry taste with waxy funky notes. Mid-bodied. Mild, soft, vaguely metallic mouthfeel. Dry-acidic lemony cherry aftertaste with earthy funky vinegary salty notes. Nice and very harmonic, yet different. (0.375l bottle, shared by gr0ve.)

Bottle from the brewery. This is batch 006x2, so it's a couple years old at this point, but has been aged properly. Acid and cherries really come to the front, the beer is more balanced than fresh supplication. Really really nice, near perfect cherry sour.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375ml bottled graciously shared by bulldogp04 in line at the CBS release, thanks Dean! Small pour into my Deschutes snifter.

A: Pours a hazy amber and brown combination with a frothy white head. Pretty nice looking and leaves some sticky lace down the glass.

S: Great combination of barnyard funk, citrusy sourness and peels of lemon and lime. Slighty sweet berry in there as well.

T: Very tart with a burst of sour lemon. Very subtle sweetness that is vine fruit in nature as well. Slight vinegar mixed in and it finishes with a funky yeast.

M: So clean and very crisp. Light bodied. It has incredible drinkability and is very refreshing.

O: This was a winner in my book. Very well balanced between funk and sour and the subtle sweetness really rounded it out.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-03-2011
Bottle at Bens. Cheers Ben! Rosy Brown with a white head. Funky, Fruity and well balanced. A lot of fruit, namely cherry. Some winy oakiness. Delicious.

375ml bottle. Pours a rusted brown with a little brownish head that sticks around longer than expected. Lots of oak on the nose with hints of sour cherry but nothing overpowering. Theres also a bit of red wine and some funkiness, but not that much really. Over ripe cherries start the palate off and then theres a nice funky, wood middle with a solid sour finish that doesnt last quite as long as Id like.

0.375l bottle @larsga. Light brown colour. Offwhite semithick head. Crisp sour ale aroma with hints of caramell and oranges. Well balanced taste with sweet malts, fruits, sour lemon. Medium body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle sample.
Cloudy orange color with a small head.
Sour fruits aroma, with wood and vanilla.
Sour flavor, candied fruits, and some hints of vommit. 
Medium body, interesting, long finish.

Draft at tria in philly.   Nice copper color, medium light head.  Aroma of sour cherries, slight grape, slight wood.  Medium light sweetness, medium sour.  Medium body.  Ave carbonation.  Nice mouthfeel.  I do taste lite notes of wood age.  Pretty good.
Sample at Thomas Liqour.  Redish, no head.  Tart red fruit aroma.  Taste is sweet and sour, red fruit, tart, wish it was a bit dryer.

Pours a dirty amber with some sediment.  Aroma is tart cherries, butterscotch, biscuit. Flavor is nice and tart with a nice cherry flavor. Finish is bittersweet. Overall very nice and well rounded. I find this oddly refreshing.

Pours red with with short head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is cherries, brett, and oak. Taste is tart and sour, cherries, pinot noir, and a hint of oak. Body is very light and dry, very fizzy and the finish is mouth puckering sour that lasts. Overall my favorite sour.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2012 Tap. This was my original introduction to sour beers a few years ago, and it is only better now. Pours hazy amber with a small off-white head and nice lacing. Aroma is tart, red wine, yeast, caramel, and dried fruit. Flavor is medium tart and lightly sweet, with obvious wine and wood notes from the aging barrels beautifully balanced with caramel and sour cherry.

In bottle, thanks Ben! Pours a golden amber colour with a decent beige head. Aroma of oaky pinot noir casks, lemon, wet cardboard, horse blanket,  caramel and alcohol. Similar flavours with moderate carbonation, light CO2 prickle and a foamy mouth-feel. Nice and tart. Lovely!
Bottle, thanks Paul. Pinkish red with short lasting had. Sharp cherry and oak aroma, some funk. Similar taste. Pleasantly sour. Very nice beer

Brassy gold with a fine, persistent top. Wet cork, lime, funk, horse aroma- bit of piss: 8. Flavour as above with added mint mouthwash and heartburn. Sophisticated but wrecked by unsubtle peppermint notes on this showing. Or maybe its me.

Smells of cherries. A beautiful looking beer a golden red  cherry coulour. Nice sour taste I like this one 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2014 Poured from a bottle, Khyber pass pub, Philadelphia.   Clear red pour, light carbonation, but obviously natural.  Strong cherry aroma, as expected.   Very sour flavor.   Nice flavor and I?m enjoying more as I drink.  I desk like it needs more , date I say it, beer.

Bottle at the Kitchen, Denver - 03/06/12. Batch 010.
Hazy ruby red/brown colour with a thin white head.
Brett, sour apple, grapes, cherries.
Tart flavours coming straight at you - sour cherries, a little malt and yeast, funk and farmyard.
Lively carbonation, lip puckering palate, well balanced and complex, excellent sour.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: UPDATED: AUG 16, 2014 Hazy brown colour. Aroma of sour cherries, vinegar. Taste is a bit sour, cherries, oak. Nice one.
cherries,wood,sourness,fizzyness. an amzing beer to enjoy if you are a sour ale fan.

375ml corked & caged bottle.  Batch 008, bottled Nov 14, 2011.  Served at around 45F.

Pours cloudy reddish amber with a decent off-white head that leaves very little lacing and recedes to a wispy cap and foamy ring.

Aroma is sour cherries, vinegar, oak, some funk, a bit vinous.  Excellent strength.

Flavor starts nice and sour with a lot of cherry notes, dark fruit, apples, oak, vanilla, vinous, a hint of funk but more fruity and sour than anything.  A bit of sweetness develops mid-palate but finishes mostly tart and sour.  Sourness tapers off the longer it sits in the glass.  Minimal alcohol, lingering finish.

Mouthfeel is light/medium bodied, a bit oily and sticky, sharp carbonation bite on the tongue.

Certainly very excited to try this little treat here, and while it was pricey, it was worth it for having a chance to experience this excellent Sour.  Ive only recently begun to dabble in the style and this is one of the best Ive had so far.

Pours a copper brown, low head, average sour aroma. Taste pretty simple, fairly intense sour that hangs in there through the middle and into the finish. Nice though. Lacks some of the complexity of some other sours, but enjoyable.

Poured from a 375ml bottle provided by adneilsen at weihenheizens tasting. Thanks! Pours a darker copper with a thin ring of foam. Aroma is in your face sour and cherries with some oaky notes. Taste is oaky and very tart with some pitted fruits and dark cherries. Very dry chewy mouthfeel.

Mint up front followed by dominant bubblegum dominate the aroma.  Slight sourness in aroma if you search but it all comes back to a fruity sweetness that resembles bubblegum.  Murky red orange brown that has consistent bubbles that form a  slight white that leaves occasional lacing. Tannic sourness gives way to an elegant softness that has teasing sweetness and subtle notes of the aforementioned bubble gum. Really aggressive carbonation that stings slightly. Aroma just flickered a bit of cherry wood. Just hits a whole other level for me withe the soft intricacies.  Woof.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a tulip.  Pours clear copper with small off-white head.  Little lacing, medium body, low carbonation, and sour aroma.  Taste is long tart, some funk, and some spicy yeast.  Very good.

12.68 oz. bottle, batch 009, 1000th rating, rated Consecration just before- Pours orange to almost ruby with little white particles of yeast floating around, it has a thin light tan head that reduces to a collar. The aroma is very tart and acidic, cherries and other dark fruits dominate the senses. The taste is less woody than the Consecration, and I like that, so smooth, tart, funky, cherries and grapes. Carbonation is high, body is medium. This beer is wonderful, I could drink a case of this stuff, a keg, but Id have to take out a second mortgage!  Absoutely loved it, a beer of this quality doesnt come along every day.

Dusty rose-amber with light (wood-aged), fine-bubbled, off-white head / Bright but complex nose of cherry, apple, wood, and brett / Light to medium body, tart and acidic, moderate wood astringency, dry with just a hint of sweetness, excellent balance and lightly bitter finish / Flavors of sour cherries, rotting apples, oak, hay, horse blanket, and a delightful hint of manure  / A great, beautifully balanced, sour.
Nice sour and somewhat peppery aroma. Very good gueuze like flavour with some carbonation.

375 ml bottle thanks to Gusgus, Batch 009, sampled on August 11, 2012Cloudy brown color, smallish tan head. Acidic, lactic, sweet, some faint almond paste, fruity, cherries, alcohol scent. Sugary, lactic, tart, bitter, green currants, acidic, alcohol taste. Apples, green ones. Spritzy mouthfeel, low to very low bitterness. Bitter green fruit aftertaste.

Batch 009. Soft sweet at first, with mellow cherries. Some leather and a hint of vinegar. More ale-like than sour. 
Flavor is awesome. A hit of different flavors quickly falls together. Soft and sparkling. Loads of crystal malt with hard acids. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft into snifter at KnB Wine Cellars in San Diego, Calif., on July 28, 2012. Two fingers of head when I got it. Honey caramel auburn color. White/tan head/lacing with great retention all around (sides and top). 

Smelled dirty rotten fruit, plum, peach, apple, purple grape, cherry, pear.  

Tasted Sweet Tarts, Smarties, Sour Gummi Worms, tart, sweet. Nothing like the nose. 

Light-to-medium body. Oily texture. Average carbonation. Long sweet candy finish. Consistent and long lasting.

Finally got to try this beer and it didnt disappoint. Smooth, tasted great and sweet.

Thanks to Mike for one of my first sour ale tastings.  pours a deep cherry color, absolutely no head, great carbonation, sour with the flavor of cherries shining through.  Similar to DFH Black and Blue but much better in my opinion.
Bottle. Thanks to adnielsen for the bottle. Pours a reddish brow color. Sour cherry aroma. Damn nice sour. One of my favorite sours.
tap @ city beer tasting room clear red brown, small white head. sour, woody notes and crerry in the aroma. smooth, tart cherry aroma.

Amber gold pour with a delicate fizzy head. Pretty active beer. Aroma is red apples, dark cherries, port, little bit of grass and tobacco. Medium sticky body. Of course its sour, but a sweet jammy character as well. Really nice balanced and complex. Dry finish. Excellent.

Bottle at Blue Palms. Batch 007. Clear, brown/copper liquid with minimal off-white/light pink head. Aroma of cherries, lacto, oak, wine barel, earth, sour apples and some light vinegar. Awesomely sour but still very balanced. Aroma is quite dry and medium sour, tart. Notes of cherries and oak. Really balanced. Medium bodied with low carbonation. Really smooth and puckering. Great, balanced brew.
Effervescent, lightly pink head fades quickly. Aroma of sour cherries. Taste is very sour, though it mellows a bit as it gets warmer. Or maybe my taste buds are maxed out.
Tap. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are sour brett, stable, leather, grass and malt. Nice and acidic.
Bottle.  Pours brown with thick cream head.  Aroma is sour cherries and funk. Flavor is sour cherry, funk, and some oak. Very nice.

Bronze color with small white head fading fast. Aroma is awesomely sour, hints of oak and lots of sour cherries. Some wine can be noted. Taste is tart, deliciously sour and fruity. Well carbonated. The oak can easily be picked up in the aftertaste. Comic sans. No

375 ml, batch 005X1, thanks to Tim. Amber-brown with a lasting small disc of cream. Tart cherry, oak, pinot, scorched brown sugar, earthy funk, light rust, and a dash of acetic acid on the nose. Flavor is the same mix, but more acetic than the aroma indicates, overpowering the funk a bit. Medium body is astringently dry, with medium-high carbonation.

Pours a burnt sienna color with touches of ruby along the edges... Aromas of tart cherry, sour tarts, oak, berry and a hint of earth.  On the palate this is a great beer.  much more balanced than alot of sour browns in the states.  Nice bright fruit flavors of dark fruit, cherries, berries, cider vinegar and lingering earthy flavors.  Nice bit of carbonation as well... Stand out for a wild brown no doubt !

True to its name as a sour ale. Its fruit notes balance well with the sour-ness and the carbonation help facilitate this inter-mingling. The fruit (cherry) flavor does not push it too far to be as sweet as most lambics but it is definitely there. Well-rounded. No hop notes detected. Very little head for obvious reasons.

Pretty much sets the "high-water" mark for sour beers.  It has a dark red brownish color when poured and not much head. Like all good sours it packs a strong punch during the first couple of sips and just gets better as you sip.  The cherry taste in the beer is not sweet but there.  This beer finishes without leaving any lingering flavor on the palate, which I believe, adds to the desire to take that next sip.

On tap at Uber. Pours darker crimson with minimal head. Smell is tart cherry, vinegar, vinous. Taste is sour grape, juicy, and surprisingly drinkable. I prefer Consecration in their regular line up but this is also good.

Sample from a 375 ml bottle (batch 006X2), thanks to Jay. Hazy darker amber color. A light off-white head. Very nice tart nose-smell, with perceptible cherry. Really nice tart taste, not too sour, not offensive at all. Good tart cherry aroma. Nice smooth carbonation, dry finish, great aftertaste. Very nice, a couple of sips is the perfect amount to savor for this. From Russian River, Ive only tried the consecration I think, but I definitely enjoy this much more. Much more mild, easy to drink, and refreshing.

Great two finger head that dies pretty quickly.  Aroma is a great sour apple with hints of other dark fruits.  Taste is a pretty sour apple with the alcohol very well hidden.  Sourness mellows out as the beer gets warmer.  Great example of a sour.  Not my favorite style of beer but I am warming up to this style.  This is a great beer that makes me want to drink more great sour beers

(37.5 cl bottle courtesy of GT2, Thanks!; Batch #9) Pours a clear, fizzy amber with quickly receding, white head. Aroma so tart and dry that it almost makes me cough. Theres definitely some leather in there. Watery texture, fizzy carbonation, medium body and bone dry finish. Tart and dry taste. Remniscient of cider but more smooth to my mind and less complex or wood-influenced.

Batch 004

A: Beautiful amber/orange hue with tiny cherry particles floating everywhere (I emptied every last drop of the beer), creating a speckled appearance similar to a robins egg . Nice head retention and lacing.

S: Mouth watering. What an enticing pleasant sour aroma with prominent fresh cherries.

T: Even better than I hoped for. This is exactly the sweet/sour balance I have been looking for in a cherry beer. The cherry flavor is so delicious, it floored me. The beer is sour, but not overly so, and has hints of sweetness that meld brilliantly. It just tastes so clean and fresh - I dont know how else to describe it. I could go on and on singing Vinnies praises...

M: No alcohol detectable whatsoever. The finish is fantastic, with a light wild yeast and cherry pie aftertaste.

D: This beer is chuggable and dangerous. I wish I had an entire cellar full of this. Easily one of the best and most enjoyable beers I have ever had.

Pours a hazy cherry amber with a 2 finger head that quickly fades into a ring.  Aromas of oak, sour cherry, blunt objects and sharp knives.  First sip reveals ample carbonation, tart cherries, wood, cobwebs.  No alcohol detected. Finishes dry and quick.  Not as sour as consecration. In fact, not as good as consecration.  Still, this is a world class sour but in my opinion takes a back seat to consecration.
Bottle. Rosy copper, tart cherry nose, copper-metal. Big tart body, very full and fruity. spritely. medium body, nice darker sour. Good

Not a whole lot on the aroma, except a little sour note. Then, Bam! Very nice sour fruit and back of the mouth flavour. I got some raspberry and slight ginger in the aftertaste. Very complex and yet, very clean. One of the best American sours I have experienced.

my first foray into the sours. pleasant tart cherry aroma. beautiful hazy dark ruby in a tulip glass. taste is cherry vinegar champagne. Im a little offput at first, but it was a perfect pairing with the Italian dinner. no other type of beer would have stood its ground against the seasoning of the food. I am not sold on drinking it as a stand alone, but would pair it with a lot of meals

Bottle @ home (batch 005X5). Off white, reasonable head on top of a hazy amber colored beer. Fruity, soft sour aroma with a hint of caramel/toffee. Fruity sour, but  not sharp. Red fruit; not only cherries, more berries. Good, but not that special.

Cork popped 375ml bottle of batch 004x5 shared with ck1 - cellar aged 3 years (we calculated, but possibly 4 as the aging system does not include dating), somewhat accidentally. Thanks to Ken for driving it from CO. Pours reddish brown with a white head, nice lacing. Aroma has tartness from cherries, oakiness and perhaps some wine. A bit surprised and very happy to not get any vinegar. Taste is of sweet and tart cherries with faint oak. Sweet and tart in a well-rounded fashion, without earthiness. Finishes sweet and tart, and with some length. There is a lot of depth to this, without it turning at all, and it was extremely tasty.  RRiver comes through with another strong offering!

stealing another users words as they are apt: "Bottle. Pours reddish amber with a thin head and lots of fine bubbles. Aroma is brett, mild sour cherries, a soft-grained yeastiness. Flavor is mild brett, sour cherries, some woodiness, mild bitterness. Really delicious. More mild and subtle than most Belgian sour ales. "
Absolutely amazing. Not sure why Pliny the Elder gets all the fuss when this is about 3 times as good

UPDATED: APR 15, 2013 At FWIBF.  Reddish brown pour with very little head.  Aroma is oak, Brett, sour cherries.  Flavor bomb with a little Pinot and Nice sour fruit, and oaky wood.  Some tart on the finish.  Excellent brew!!

Bottle.  Pours reddish amber with a thin head and lots of fine bubbles.  Aroma is brett, mild sour cherries, a soft-grained yeastiness.  Flavor is mild brett, sour cherries, some woodiness, mild bitterness.  Really delicious.  More mild and subtle than most Belgian sour ales.  Sampled at a tasting.  Would love to sit down with a big tulip glass of this and sip it gingerly.

Batch 8: Pours a brownish-orange with ruby tones and virtually no head and retention. Aroma is sweet with hints of vanilla, oak, dark fruit, cherries and a wine presence. Flavor is a mouthfull of sweet and sourness with cherries, oak, and vanilla. Has a creamy texture and a mild dry bitterness in the finish. Simply delicious!
Bottle @ 2nd Tuesday tasting @ De Molen. Aroma is huge fruity and funky notes. Loads of red grapes, touch of barn. Flavour is thick fruity sourness, some barn. Lingering on and on. Very nice.

Almost clear red and a small but very much present tan head. Clove, fermented fruit, cherry, red grapes and citric. Fierce sourness, sticky grapes, getting more complex towards the end. Thanks to PP for bringing this. (At the De Molen tasting)
Bottle at De Molen beer tasting.  Hazy amber pour with a small white head.  Aroma is sour cherries, brett sourness.  Flavour is Brett, sour cherries, oak,light sweetness, fruit, long tart finish.

Bottle at the molen monthly tasting.
Sour aroma.  Decent white head.  Clear amber pour. Tart sour taste. Not really my sort of beer but still good.

On tap at RR. Nice light amber and orange with hints of ruby. Light head with little to no retention. Tons of cherry and a sourness. Nice light brown ale scents. Light oak. Again, tons of cherry up front. The sourness blended well with the cherry to dominate this ale. Light oak through out with subtle hints of vanilla and dark fruit. Nice medium body and moderate carbonation. Dry through out and in the finish. This is one of my all time favorite beers. The tap version blew my mind, so much flavor. I am assuming I had batch 5 which is the latest batch. Well done! This is world class. Reviewed on: 08-17-2010

Batch #10 

Pours orange and red. taste of vinegar and Pinot Noir w/ a mouth full of cherries. Simply amazing Beer.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2014 Pours a hazy red amber color with little head. Cherries, fruit, sour. But very smooth. Drank this at Najas overlooking the pacific. This is the best sour beer I have ever had. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured from a bottle into a tulip with a thin layer of bubbles.  Smells of oak and cherries.  Tastes the same as the nose with some funk and tartness.

375 ml bottle courtesy of Marsiblursi. Batch 003. Pours hazy pinkish red with a small bubbly white head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace. Smell is sour with sour cherries, red currants, wild strawberries, raspberries, red wine vinegar, black currants, dry soil, hay, leather, barnyard, perfume-like dried yellow flowers, dark grapes, wood, dark bread, marzipan and some rather prominent hints of oxidation. Taste is sour, tiny sweet and malty with sour cherries, unripe raspberries, strawberries, hay, lemon juice, black currant leaves, wood, grapes, plums, wet leaves, barnyard, leather, red currants, wet soil, red wine vinegar, plums, grapefruit juice and hints of grape zest and horse blanket. Mouthfeel is fruity, dry, tart and medium bodied. Finish is sour and tart with sour cherries, unripe raspberries, red currants, hay, lemon juice, barnyard, wood and grape zest. Fruity, complex, balanced and fantastic!

bottle from Marina Market.  Poured a nice brown with no head.  Smell was sour cherries.  Taste was very acidic with tons of woddsy flavor.  It wasnt as pungent as I expected.  Taste was very smooth.  Nice sour.

A - Pours a cloudy copper-orange with a half-finger of frothy off white head atop. The head fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some light lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of sour cherries with some dark grape sweetness, oak, vanilla, Brett funkiness, and just a touch of brown sugar.

T - Starts off with some sharply sour cherries with some dark grape sweetness and tannin with some vanilla. Through the middle, oak flavors come through with some more mellowing sweet cherry and grape with some Brett funkiness. The finish is a mix of sour cherries with some Brett funk and tartness, alongside some oak and vanilla.

M - Medium bodied with moderate-plus carbonation. Feels smooth with a very sour and dry finish.

D - Very drinkable. The sour cherries come through really nicely without being overpowering. The balance is very nice with the barrel flavors adding some great complexity.
Great appearance and nose. Flavour packed with cherries, dark fruit, red wine and funky yeast. Delivious!

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2012 Batch 10 bottle to oversized snifter.  Looks good; brown with ample head and carbonation.  Smells good too; fruit and pinot.  Tastes great! A really good American sour thats nice on the palate too.  This is great stuff!

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2012 Draft from a batch 2 keg at Monks during pliny the younger day 2010. This was my favorite glass of supplication to date. Pours a hazy red amber color with medium white head and lacing. Aromas of dark cherries, dates, brett, biscuit, red wine. Taste was a sour and funked out cherry dominant flavor with notes of wood, coconut marshmallow, pinot, coriander, pine, and lactic acids. One of my favorite sour ales. Amazing.

Ar: Cherries and a bit of vinegar - some hay and barnyard funk.
Ap: Cloudy orange - small off-white head with moderate retention and some lacing.
T: Plum, lemon, lots of fruit, all very sour - lots of dark caramel and cherry mid-palate with very low bitterness - lots of lemon and cherry on the finish. 
P: Medium-light body with high carbonation - finish is dry.
O: Tasty and very fruity sour - nice funky complexity with some very prominent sour tones.

Pours a beautiful red orange with no head but some lacing is left. Aroma is of cider, vinegar and cherries. Taste follows the nose, tart in the best way possible. Leaves cherries in the finish. Mouthfeel is very carbonated and dry but not too dry. This is an excellent wild ale!
Sour,sour and still sour. You must like sour o and cherry. This is a very cool and unique beer that would go great with beef and salty foods.

12.68 oz corked and caged bottle. Aroma is sour funk, woody, wet river rock--overall, not as aromatic as other sours Ive been drinking lately. Pours hazy orange with a medium beige head that collapses into a blanket of foam. The taste more than makes up for the somewhat lackluster aroma. Its very tart and acidic, making my mouth pucker like I prefer sour ales to be. Has a flavor of fresh chopped wood along with the sourness. Mouthfeel is creamy, but the body could be a bit fuller; leaves the mouth dry. Nice beer.

bottle thx Heather and Frank shared with Jf A: cherries, winy, vanilla App: hazy copper with sparing white head. T/p: light body with acidic medium long finish. Average carbonation. O: Amazing like the complexity.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2017 Draft and bottle many times. Deep full syrupy sour out of Merlot barrels. Dark amber with a foamy head. Great full, fruity and quite tart. One of Russian Rivers best sours. Newer vintages seem to taste a bit more vinous while older ones taste smoother and have more caramel notes. All versions are delicious! UPDATE: Have the opportunity to try several older batches at a sour event at Bru Craft. Noticed that the oldest one 10/8/15 was the most juicy and flavorful.

Great sour with all the right notes mouthfeel is great and makes the palate salivate like a good sour should great beer had this at Russian river brew bar in Sonoma 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours hazy gold with some redish hues to it.  Small white head.  Nose is light cherry, vinegar, grapes, grass and wood.  Taste is sweet up front but a big sour tidal wave takes over and finishes as such.  Mouthfeel is crisp and clean.  Big aftertaste and light body.  Solid.

Sampled at WTWBA 2012, Brooklyn.  The aroma is sour fruit, cherry.  The appearance is hazy light brown/red, light tan head.  The flavor is the same as the aroma, sour cherry.  The finish is tart cherry.  Quite good.  Nice representation of the style.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Tap at Russian River. Clear rich amber pour. White head. Sour cherry and a touch of Brett on the nose. Taste is a highly balanced sour - good flavor without puckering the bunghole.

My first sour beer, ever. This was a complete kick in the tail, a shock to the system. I was unaware of what a sour  actually was. This had hints of wine and cherry, covered by vinegar. The strength of the sour was notable in all aspects: appearance, aroma and taste.
Bottle from 2008. Soft notes of Cherry on the nose with some wood coming through as well. upfront sourness on the palate with some malts present, fruit and funk. Mellow and very enjoyable.

Well worth the hype and the price.  $17 for a bottle on the East Coast.  The pour is amber with a constant fine stream of bubbles.  No head or lacing.  The scent is earthy with the subtlest hint of cherry.  The taste supports the backstory, wine-like in nature, with a sour cherry taste and a nice, warm alcohol bite on the end.  Excellent!  I was very disappointed in the Russian River Damnation, but this has greatly redeemed the esteem with R.R.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, batch 04x5, 05/06/2012.  Muddy copper pour, small head quickly burns off.  In the aroma, light tart fruitiness, mostly cherries, overshadowed by soft lactic sour notes reminiscent of an oud bruin, and dark sweet bread maltiness, some oak in the end.    Taste begins with bright, tart dark fruits, sherry vinegar, darker sour malts, and an almost clean cherry finish, slightly vinous.  Medium thin palate, sourness just right to leave me wanting more, very lively in the mouth.  Quite a nice sour in every respect.

Rating #1400, 350ml bottle obtained in a trade and shared at DLD. People loved it and so did I. Orange/amber coloured. Unclear. Beige headed. Aroma is somewhat dry and acidic. Has notes of cherryfruits and is light sour. Flavour is very grapish and light fruity. Some woody notes is there. Is acidic and really cleanses the palate. Quite refreshing and sour in the end. Good one.

Tulip at Brewpub.good.aroma, tart, sweet . Fruity. Clean brownish orange. Small.head that faded quick, no lace. Tart flavor. Lite body, smooth mouthfeel, tart finish. Tasty. Aroma my favorite part. Rye tart fruit thing.. drinks easy  7%. Good stuff.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours copper with a nice beige head. The aroma in this one is very dry and champaigne(ish) note with lots of brett, lactobacillus, the cherries are very present, some brown alish sweetness, floral notes, funky, barnyard, oaky wood, vanilla and pretty tart smelling. The taste is also has that dry champaigne note, dry white wine, brett, wood, straw, cherries, lime, apples, very tart, gooseberries and a bit of alcohol in the aftertaste. Very pleasureable!

Wine in appearance - dark amber with no head at all. Aroma is of brie cheese, sour cherries, and oak chips. Flavor is quite mellow with sour cherries really overwhelming everything else. Some notes of caramel and other malts in the finish but mostly just sour, like it should be.

Batch 9. Pours Amber with a finger of head that quickly dissipates. Aroma is cherries and sour funk. Taste is very sour with some cherry with a lot of wine dryness on the tongue with some sure apple on the finish.
Amber red with a small off-white head. Aroma is of cherries with a sharp tartness, funk and wood. Taste is quite sour with some funk, oak, and a hint of cherries and berries.

One of my favorite sours! Sour cherry nose, thin white head and amber brown in color. Tart, cherry, wood (oak?) lingers in the taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

It poured an amber brown color with a little head. The aroma was of cherry, yeast and has mineral notes. The taste was somewhat sour and the cherry is only there initially. There is a nice malty brown ale finish.  Very tasty.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2014 Batch 009. Endless layers of berries and tart fruits in the aroma. The vapors emanating out of the bottle tell beautiful fables of times past, featuring funky Brettanomyces; barnyard; old wood; dried manure; overripe cherries; dust; molten candi sugar; plump, ripe strawberries; a whisper of old leather; and lime. It is magical and it reminds me a lot of my dads farm back when I was a child. But it doesnt stop there: pour it into your glass and youll get fresher esters suggesting something like a sort of local cherry cola, not the multinational kind, but something youd drink out of a clear-glass bottle. Id call it artificial, but I know its only part of the picture. It pours a beautiful, very deep amber. The head, off-tan in color, is fizzy and gets out of your way pretty quickly, with no remnant of it sticking around. The taste is tart and sweet, like ripe berries bathed in lime juice, with accompanying bitterness that feels old and funky. It goes down and greets the stomach with burning sourness. The mouthfeel is medium, somewhat sticky and with carbonation that feels natural and lively. The aftertaste is a bit funky and barnyard-like, but mostly it is fruity, red, and tart. Its hard to get over how good it is.
Excellent sour. The nose isnt as vegetal as I like, but oaky and aromatic. Medium bodied with tart cranberry and meyer lon permeating the palate. Long, classy drying finish.
Bottle from Total Wine Sacramento; slightly oversweet.  Nice fizziness and tang.

pours a clear copper color with small head. Aroma has notes of sour cherries, bret and vinegar.  Taste is sour and has hints of oak and fruit.
Palate has average carbonation with a thin slick texture and refreshing crisp finish.  Overall one of the better sours i have drank and worth every penny.

Fantastic beer, clearly lives up to the reputation with just the right balance of fruit, oak and tartness.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Reddish brown appearance with a thin to non existent white head. Aroma is cherry with some notes of pinot noir. Flavor is basically a strong pinot noir with heavy hints of sour cherry. Its a bit strange after having a few other beers, but it makes more sense if you think of it as an ale version of a pinot noir. Makes sense for a beer made in the heart of wine country. Interesting, not like anything else Ive had, and not something Id reach for all the time but definitely original, extremely well crafted and a really good cross between a strong ale and a strong wine.
Hazy amber/copper color with a really nice head. Aromas of sour good smelling funk, some oak and a wine.The taste is predominantly dry, woody, and tart and very complex. Well done.
Fantastic. This beer is wonderfully complex, with stand-out notes of cherries, oak, sour apple, oak and yeasty funk. A must-try.

Not so humble after all. Aroma is initially somewhere between a Belgian tripel and a saison.  Bananas, clove, orange peel, bubble gum.  Then you take a sip and get smacked in the face by the bitter, tart and sour.  Overly ripe orange peel, concentrated grapefruit bitterness, big bretts, champagne like carbonation.  This is a seriously fun sour.

Bottle shared @ 5 Seasons Pours a hazy amber/copper color with a smaller off-white head.  Aroma is heavy tart cherries, musty, vinous.  But the cherries are big and bold on the nose for sure.. Lightly musty, and quite vinous and tart aroma. Taste is very sour cherries and puckering acidicy.  There is some funk in there and finishes quite dry.  This is a very special and dangerously drinkable brew.  Too bad the price tag, but I still have one more sitting down in my basement.

From notes. Pours a nice deep redish brown with orange hues when up to the light. I got a one finger head from a pretty vigorous pour that then disappears to nothing with no lacing.
Nose is bright with fruit, candy sugars, tart apple, cranberry defiantly a little yeasty funk, and a hint of oak. 
Flavor defiantly shows off the tart cherries. I get some nice sour apple, and cranberry but it has an interesting fresh fruit juice in the middle. I can defiantly pick up on some oak. 
Mouthfeel is pretty nice, almost a cider like feel with a medium high level of carbonation. I defiantly get a nice lingering bitterness and tartness.

Pours a hazy brownish-red color with a thin, even white head and lacing. Aroma is light, funky Brett with cherries, orange and hints of Pinot Noir. Tart cherries and delightfully even sourness dominate the taste with a very dry finish. Light body (a bit woody) with prickly carbonation that causes some astringent mouthfeel. Overall, an extremely balanced sour ale with just the right amount of tartness.

Another amazing sour ale from Russian River.  Based on my limited exposure to sours, I feel that there may be a much finer range of techniques and ingredients that result in a well-done ale.  This one pours reddish-brown, little head retention.  Taste is immediately sour, with notes of figs and raisins following, and a sour finish.  Worth it, again!

Pours golden brown with a small ring of fizz. Smells of cherries, red wine, and hints of sourness. Taste is strongly of sour cherries with a red wine kick. Medium-to-full bodied with a slick texture and prickly mouth-carbonation, Russian River Supplication finishes with a nice lingering sourness.

Dark amber in color with one finger of light tan head, fading into a nice cap and lacing. Smells of oak, tart cherries, and funk, but primarily cherries. Taste is mouth puckeringly tart: sour cherries, oak, and a bitter, tannic finish. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with ample carbonation.

375 ml bottle. Batch #008. Brewed on 20.04.2010. Bottled on 14.11.2011
Pours clear copper color with small head. Aroma of sour fruits and berries, herbal notes, nettle, cherries and yeast. Flavor of yeast, sour fruits, cherries, rose hip and herbs. Sour and fruity palate with a dry finish. Excellent sour brew
3356

375 ml bottle. Batch 008, brewed on 20.5.2010, bottled on 14.11.2011.
Pours a deep copper colour with a white head. Aroma of strong funky sour cherries, Pinot Noir and vinegar. Flavour of strong sour cherries, oak, smooth Pinot Noir notes, vinegar, lactic acid, sweet raisins and some tannin from the barrel, which feels especially in the aftertaste. Medium bodied, dry mouthfeel and a long, tart and fruity finish. Complex and awesome.

37,5 cl bottle @ home. Batch #008: brewed 20.04.2010, bottled 14.03.2011
Aroma is sour with oaky notes, cherries, grapes, blackcurrants and lactic acid. Some earthy notes too. Flavour is rather sour with oak, tart cherries and blackcurrants. Also some lactic acid. Sour and nice. Adding the yeast makes this more round and worse.

I absolutely love this beer. The cherries add such a wonderful balance to the beer and go perfectly with the traditional sour flavors. It is an awesome red color with a pinkish hue. I will have this as many times as I can.

Tap at Toronado SF. It pours cloudy amber, with a decent white head. The nose is farmyard, floral (particularly chamomile), tart cherry and Granny Smith apple. The taste is quite like unblended lambic actually - lemony tartness, vinegar, white grape skin, white currant, tart cherry, egg-white sourness and floral, with a dry-tart finish. Medium body and fine, prickly carbonation. Its certainly good, but doesnt quite stand up to a whole host of Belgian lambic offerings.

On draft at Freshcraft in Denver

Pours a clear brown body, 1/2 inch off white head. Lacing and head retention were good.

Smell is of very light vinegar but dominated by tart fruit like cherry and kumquat. There is also some oak at the end.

Taste is of straw malt mixed with sour apples. Sour pickle brine is also present along with some puckering tannins youd get from a dry chardonnay. No hops or alcohol was detected.  

Mouthfeel is light, puckering and finishes dry. Carbonation is perfect but the head was only semi present. 

Overall this was a good refreshing beer. Would love to have this in the mountains on a spring day. Not too much into the particular style but would definitely buy another bottle whenever it rarely pops up.

From notes.  First reviewed 9/5/2011.  Poured from a 375 mL bottle into a tulip. Batch 04X3, caged and corked bottle. 

Supplication pours a deep ruby color, mostly transparent except for the yeast particles floating around. A dollop of beige foam rests on top and laces up the glass nicely.

There is a great balance of sour and funky in the aroma. There is so much going on here. A bit of dark malt, lots of cherries, some lemon, and a nice level of funk, horse blanket and a little stinky cheese.

The brief sweetness in the taste is accompanied by tart cherries, and the flavor grows even more sour as the sip progresses. Tart, more acetic than lactic, and vinegary, totally bold without killing my palate. Each sip waters the mouth just enough to make me want to go back for more. Notes of pinot noir come in toward the end, as if this beer needed any more complexity, along with some spicy oak tannins. The finish has a nice funk to it, giving me an extra smile.

The carbonation starts with a bite but is smooth throughout each sip. A sour puckering sensation causes me to salivate without being overpowering. Lightly vinegary and acidic. A light astringency comes with the barrel but is barely noticeable. The body is on the lighter side of medium. Russian River knows my sour sweet spot. 

I cannot believe it has taken me this long to try my first Supplication. This is everything I want in a sour, I will be coming back to this beer again and again.

Giant magnum bottle thanks to pantanap for bringing to the brewery and sharing. Pours brown with a small white head. Aroma is nicely funky and sharp, great infection note, good balance of tart and funk. Flavor starts and ends with a nice earthy funk and a tartness. Nice crisp bite in the finish along with some sweetness that balances the funky sour. Medium body and a soft carbonation. Very good beer

Tap @ Tapnhandle pub. A stop on grand tour of Fort Collins breweries and bars with Tim, Aaron and Armin, Thanks !! Pours golden with a white head. Aroma of sourness, brett, funk, green apples, grapes. Taste is very sour with grapes, green apples, brett, funky. cherries, light oak tartness. Thin body, lively carbonation, mouthdrying sour finish. Lovely. 250212

Batch 04x1, bottle thx to Michael!
To me this beer tastes like a flemish brown, more of a Rodenbach then a geuze. For a cherry sour ale I rather like some more soureness then sweetness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

355ml bottle shared by jsprime. clear light red, white head. nice soft lightly sour nose, light fruit. very straight forward flavour. not as layered or complex asid like in a top tier sour, little to no wood influence. nice beer but not tops for this style.

Bottle.  Pours a deep amber with no head.  Aroma is wood and wine.  Tastes like wine as well with a lot of sourness that does not linger too much.  Sours arent my favorite which explains the low rating.  I think it is better than the Jolly Pumpkin sour that I had recently.

Draught at Monks Cafe SF.  Grape skin, green grapes, and brett aromas from this dark caramel colored near headless beer.  Extremely tart sweet and lovely spectrum of flavors. Velvety texture.  Superb. Works well on all levels.

Poured into Russian River glass from corked bottle. Deep amber and very hazy. Little to no head that quickly disappeared. Smells of yeast, sourness, and that unmistakable brett funk. Very thin body with high carbonation, but sour as hell, with a lingering acidic finish. Just the way I love my sours, mouth puckering. This is a very good beer from RR, and definitely worth seeking out.

skunky, citrus, orange, hazy, frothy, heavily sour, medium body, slick feel, fizzy, bitter, This was my first sour beers that i had and did not like it at first. tried it again and now i cant get enuf of it.

Review 600! 375 ml bottle into tulip, batch 006X2.  Pours hazy red orange color with a nice 1 finger light khaki head with great retention that reduces to a thin cap that lingers.  Some spotty lacing on the glass, with a good amount of carbonation streaming up.  Aromas of huge tart cherries, green apple, grapes, pear, light vinegar, oak, red wine, hay, light spices, and a lot of funk.  Fantastic aromas with great balance and complexity,  Taste of big tart cherries, apple, grape, pear, red wine, citrus, oak, vinegar, spiciness, earthiness, hay, and funk.  Lingering notes of tart fruit, oak, wine, and spices on the finish for a bit.  Fantastic balance of sourness and sweetness makes this very smooth on the palate.  Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with a slightly creamy and acidic mouthfeel.  Slightly prickly carbonation, but still very smooth drinking.  Alcohol is well hidden with only a slight warming after the finish present.  Overall this is an outstanding wild ale; with great balance, complexity, and smoothness.

Batch 007 poured from a 375ml to a snifter:

Pours a BRIGHT ruby orange.  An off white thin cap of high carb head that sits off to one side.  Brilliant, consistent beading.  Lacing is lovely.  Nose is complex to say the least.  Lots of fruity red wine funkiness backed by the bright clove/sweet bread of a good Belgian golden.  On the tongue theres a surprisingly pungent earthy sour wallop that gives away to a beautiful floral array of sweet complexities.  Theres a lingering tart presence on the back of the palate.  Sour cherries, of course.  The feel is smooth and a bit dry I think.  Wonderful.  Overall, this is a sour that might even appeal to the non-sour beer drinker.  Yum.

Batch 3, bottled 3/4/200, and the last Supplication to use the R.R. wine yeast.

A - A deep amber with 2 fingers of khaki head, excellent retention, some legs.

S - slightly acetic, brett, and malt. cherries arent really apparent in the nose anymore.

T - starts with nice sour cherry, but the belgian brown base is more noticeable at this age. Has a nice sweet finish with a bit of oak.

M/D - Medium carbonation with a medium body. Highly drinkable after your palate adjust a few sips in. Reminiscent of a Flanders Red, especially at this age with the cherries sitting further back. 

A great beer at this age, but Im not sure if aging it longer will do it any good.

Bottle. The pour was a medium murky chestnut brown with an average sized (1-2 finger) creamy light beige head, that reduced slowly to a thin layer of foam with a collar producing some mighty fine sheeting of sticky lacing.

The aroma was bold and fruity with a dark bread malt and some Brett yeast along with some notes of cherry, oak and a bit of red wine.

The taste was incredibly sweetly tart and very malty with a slight hint of wine in the beginning, then becoming boldly sour with a nice strong malty cherry presence and a hint of oak at the end. The flavor lasted a very long time allowing for the sour cherry wine flavor to be fully enjoyed as it relaxed on the taste buds.

Mouthfeel was a solid medium in body with a creamy dry texture and a carbonation reminiscent of champagne.

Overall, all that has to be said is WOW what an incredible brew. This brew was most likely one of the best things I have ever put to my lips. Just sayin...

Bottle.
Very clear brown. Sour, vinegary, typical gueze flavour. Redcurrants, lemon. I did not get too excited.
UPDATED: FEB 21, 2015 Tap at RR, brown pour, white head, nose is sour, taste is sour, lots of brett, amazing

I love the mild sour and cherry notes. This is in my top 3 beers. Great for sipping. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375ml bottle. This is a fantastic beer. There are woody notes, fruity, vinous, malts are still noticeable. A very well made sour.  I really enjoy the wine character in this beer. I will have to get more of this.

Batch 009. Aroma of cherries and some funkiness. Looks clear, with a nice reddish color with a decent little white head. Pretty sour, but not puckery.  First sour and cherries, and then the oak and vanilla come in. Great finish with almost fizzy mouthfeel at first. Medium body. Awesome. One of my favorite beers. Could drink this all day if it wasnt $12 a bottle.

Intense but refreshing. Red berries, wine, vanilla, chocolate and intense brett. High sourness. Drinkability is high so you cant stop drinking it until you remember the price... Exciting experience which Id like to do again.

Supplication lets out of a huge pop when the cork is pulled.  The pour on this beer is full of white fluffy head as you can see in the picture.  Great retention and lacing throughout the glass.  The color of this one was a murky dark reddish brown color.  As the beer settles, the beer becomes more clear.

With Supplication I was expected a rather sour aroma but instead its toned down a tad bit.  Definitely not their more sour beer.  Instead the cherries come through more with the oak and slight musty funk.  The beer also had some nice wine characteristics from the Pinot Noir. 

Once again I was expected more of a sourness but it held a backseat.  What this taste is though is a very drinkable American Wild Ale.  One that wont make you pucker, but make you enjoy the cherries, the balance of oak and wine like presence.  Its a great mixture of slight sourness, slight tartness, funkiness, cherries, and what the barrel has to offer.  Turns out to be just drinkable and before I knew it, my glass was empty. 

Mouthfeel is very alive.  Well carbonated.   Bubbles smack your lips.  Crisp, light, and dry.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2012 "Thanks to my new friends for sharing this with me! Very exciting to finally have this beer.
Poured into a Riedel Snifter.
A - The appearance is a combo of Gold, Hazel and Amber. Its a very deep woody tone. Two finger head appears but quickly leaves.
S - Pinot Grigio, Cherry and Honey. Im getting that sour bite that lambics provide and a lot of fruits that are all over the place!
T - Raspberry, sour, grapes, cherry. Everything tastes so light with a red-wine finish! Very refreshing! Id love to serve this at room temp on a sunny day! 
M - HUGE bubbles on the swish but light and very easy to drink!
O - I really loved this beer. Would love to have it again."

375mL bottle purchased at Total Wine in Sacramento.  Batch 008.  Wow, the aroma on this is really impressive with significant amount of tart cherries.  Lightly musty, and quite vinous and tart aroma.  The cherries REALLY stand out in the aroma of those.  Really nice.  Moderately hazy light amber-copper body with a smallish off-white head, that dissipates fairly rapidly.  Starts moderately tart and acidic, but not over the top.  The middle has some more of the sour cherry flavor present.  There is a nice amount of acidity in the middle with good barnyardy funk.  Finishes a little dry with more light tart character.  I dont think there are many other flemish reds out there that could compete with this.  Perhaps the 2007 Rodenbach Vintage, but this is a special beer.

RBAG 2012. Pours a dark orange with a frothy white head. Nice carbonation. Aroma of hops, sour fruit, citrus, spice, cherries, and some nice oakiness. Taste is very sour up front, but settles to let more flavors out. Nice flavors of hops, oak, cherries, yeast, and citrus fruits. Extremely tart, thanks to all the sour fruit flavors.

On tap at the brew pub

This is one of my favorite everyday type sours. Smells of nice funk and cherries galore! Taste follows in the same suit with a nice sour punch! I wish i could get this is arizona, glad i bought a bunch while i was there!
bottle shared by Steve owner of Kupros Bistro! pours a hazy yellow with a massive smell of spoiled grapes. Flavor is very sour with a tart finish that has you craving another bottle.
Bottled 375ml. Courtesy of magdalar. Fantastic cherry components. Great balance and complexity. A lot of brett. Huge thanks magdalar!

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2014 Draught @ City Beer, San Francisco, CA

Pours dark orange with a small bubbly white head. Strong dark fruity and sour aroma. Taste of sour cherries, malts and spices. Slightly sweeter and hoppier than kriek lambics. Finish is malty and slightly sour and caramely. Well balanced, fruity sour ale. 9-4-8-4-16. 22.1.2012.

Re-rated on 10.3.2012. 375ml bottle from City Beer. Batch 008, bottled on 14.11.2011. Pours dark orange with a small white head. Aroma of sour cherries, oak, vanilla, malts and dark fruits. Taste is a bit more sour than the draught version, with some more tart cherries as well. Slightly more balanced and tastier.

 Draught @ Russian River. Super smooth and tasty fresh from tap. Gotta up the points by one.

Purchased at Bruery Provisions in Orange, CA; enjoyed after a long final day at a trade show, and prior to a 4 am wake up for an early flight.  Appearance like a beer wine, darkish amber/gold with no head.  Aroma of stinky cheese, sour cherries, oak, a very light touch of malt, smells delicious and complex.  Taste of vinegar, sour, cherries, I really dont taste much of the brown ale that was made, not much malt flavor at all, but thats not a problem because its delicious.  Finishes extremely dry, mouth waters after each sip.  Medium body, not really much carbonation.  Very nice!
Nice malty sweetness, cherries, slight springs. Color is a dark Brown, calm but slow head. The sourness is like a nice extra gift to what Still is a great malty beer.

RBAG. from brown 330ml.  Orangey gold murky pour, light ring if whitish foam. Funky and sour nose. Tangy in the mouth, lemons and some vinegar. Sour finish, funk lingers. Good fine bubbled carbonation. Nice sour.
batch 3 and 7 next to each other. Fly like an eagle playing in the background. For cam.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2013 Batch 006x2. Had in bottle. Wow really sour smell. This beer is tart, Made my mouth water with first drink. Redish color and great taste left in mouth. One of the best sours ive ever had.
Trade from Luckyhank, thanks man. Clear amber body with a large offwhite head. Aroma is tart, oak, yeast, cherry notes. Flavor is tart, yeast, sour, oak, fruit, flowers. Refreshing beer.

Bottle, thanks to Alex (4:20) for letting us pile into his fridge at 3 in the morning! Think there was just me, Tom, our Paul, Jan and Alex at this stage. No lightweights allowed.
