Hazy amber orange with a thin white head. Lovely aroma, very complex and a lovely amount of sourness. Thanks again, awesome.
Pours a ruby color with a thin white head. Aroma is sour cherry, dark fruits and sour apple. Taste is sour fruits, spicy, cloves and bittersweet. This was delicious. I would highly recommend this.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2014 12.7oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours deep ruby/amber with a thin, lacy, beige head.  Aroma of sourness and sweet tarts, strong red wine, strong cherries, fruit, and spiciness.  The flavor is a great blend of all of the elements in this beer.  Sparkling texture.  A complex sour ale. Edit: 6/1/14. On tap at the brewery. So sour.  Much complex.  Many barrel.  So wine.

Bottle. Pours a light brown red color with a beige head. Aroma is of sour cherries, some balsamic vinegar, red apple, oak, vinous notes, caramel and subtle funk of barnyard. Flavor has a milky like feel to it, from the lactobacillus? Again sour cherries, balsamic and apple vinegar, red apple, subtle oak, subtle funk of barnyard and dusty old flavors, caramel and vinous notes. The body is light with a dry mouthfeel. Overall a solid Sour, but pretty disappointing considering how hyped it is...

Bottle. Clearish brown/red with a small off white head. Amazing aroma of tart cherries, musty barnyard and oak, vinegar and some lacto. The flavor is sharp acetic vinegar, tart cherries and brett with some light malt presence. Light body with average carbonation and a dry mouth feel. Another great Russian River sour, not over the top sourness, very drinkable.

Bottle 375 ml batch 005x01 (trade, thanks to Baker). Amber, cloudy, red, cassock, orange dark and deep, impenetrable. I could just looking at myself watching the glass, and nothing, nothing through. Just a weak head, vanishes quickly, a tiny and pale white circle remains. Aroma... oh my...! Sour cherries, wood, vanilla, brett, brett, alcohol, brett again, grapes, wine, brett, grapefruit and - look whos coming - brett, citrus, dark fruits. Body is apparently flat, but after a nanosecond it fizzle your mouth pleasantly before DOMINATES IT with an extraordinary harsh wave. Grapefruit, tannic, grapes, salt, sour fruits, a little crisp and spicy, all together and extremely concentrating like a punch. The bitterness lasts and harsh every cm of your palate. This isnt hops, this is the aggressiveness of wild ales at its top. Had many RR, but this is probably the best along with Consecration.
This is a very sour beer. Very lambic-like, reminds me of Gueuze Tilquin with an orange twist.

Aroma- overly ripe cherries, oak, funk
Appearance- ruby red with a thin white head, streaming carbonation
Taste- huge tartness upfront followed by a cherry softness and funky/woody aftertaste
Palate- relatively thin, but refreshing and appropriate 
Overall- This is the first real sour that Ive ever had.  It was different to say the least.  Not really too much like a beer, IMO.  It was refreshing, crisp, and had sharp flavors but was pretty one-dimensional.  Cherries, wood, and tartness were really the only components present in this beer and that, to me, is almost boring.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2014 A - Orange/red brown beer with lasting white head. S - definite Pinot aromas, cloves sour cherries light oakyness, nice funk, bretts, hay as well. sour grapes. M - light med body mild carb lightly dry, and wonderfully sour throughout T - Sour throughout. Nice pinot noir and sour cherries with subtle earthy oakiness. Woody nose, sour cherry middle, sweet Pinot ends.Nice funky bretts throughout. O - a great sour ale, nice strong sour and funky mixture. fantastic. 8+

bottle, from batch 5.  Wonderful reddish brown hue, decent head.  Aromas are huge with fresh brett and sour fruits, with a certain level of sweetness.  Palate is absolutely fantastic, the sour notes hit first with a bright acidity, and then a cascading cherry ripping through the rest of the palate.  I can see why this one should be aged however, it seemed a bit young overall, I think the brett needs to integrate better, but what a great offering.

Bottle.  A very murky orange beer with a medium lasting white head.  Very sour, sweet aroma of cherries other fruits.  Taste is sour, with more cherry/fruit notes, and some funk.  Dry finish.  Medium bodied, well carbonated.  Really good.

Poured an amber brown with little head. Smells of cherry, Brett, and has mineral notes. Tastes deliciously sour; the cherry is only there initially. Once the sourness subsides there is a nice malty brown ale finish.

Clear orange-red with an initially big puffy off white foam that settles quickly.  Aroma is sweet malt, oaky, light funk, reminiscent of an Oud Bruin.  Taste is lightly tart, cherry, oak, finishes slightly thin, but overall very enjoyable.

Bouteille de 375ml. bouchon de liège (006X1). Encore une fois merci Patrick. Bière dont le liquide est cuivrée, il y a un mince filet de mousse. Le nez est fruité, du rhum, un touche de caramel (coke), de la rhubarbe (merci Boul) et un boisé bien dosé et bien intégré. La bouche est bien acide, vineuse, un peu moins complexe que la Consecration. Toute une bière.

Bottle found on holiday in Washington DC. Cranberry red color, clear with a slightly pink bubbly head that quickly recedes. The nose is tart, sweet, and a bit yeasty: I know Im immediately in belgian sour territory. The taste is nicely sharp and a bit woody. Dry finish. The mouthfeels a bit too watery and easy. Very lively carbonation. This is very nice work indeed, my first Russian River beer. Still, I cant help but feel a bit underwhelmed owing to the ridiculous reputation that this brewery has.

(Batch 006X1.  Bottle from ontbeermaker, thanks a lot Andrew!)  Une mince couverture mousseuse se dépose sur un liquide à la robe ambrée et trouble.  Le nez permet de découvrir, de façon superbe, des notes fruitées qui rappellent les raisins avec des parfums intenses de cerises surettes et aigres qui évoluent autour dun boisé efficace et imprégné par de délicates vapeurs qui transportent des microbes.  De belles notes douces viennent  se greffer à cet invitant bouquet.  Les saveurs sont efficaces, très surettes, gorgées par des cerises et frappées par des flaveurs subtiles de Pinot et de fût de chêne.  Les levures font un travail remarquable : elles participent à un ensemble harmonieux.  En bouche, le liquide possède un bon corps avec un pétillement modérément doux et une texture à la limite huileuse.  La finale est intensément longue et surprenante par sa très grande complexité.  Une expérience somme toute fabuleuse.

Bottle. Slightly off-white head on a murky ruby brown body. Very oaky aroma  with cherries and a touch of vanilla, and a nice vinegar sourness.  Flavor is quire sour with some dark fruit notes and woody chardonnay bearing on cab and caramel flavors.  Medium to lighter body with good carbonation.

What a great sour.  I had high expectations and this one met them.  Poured from a bottle into a tulip.  Aroma was light funk, grapes, plums, cherries, and subtle oak.  Taste was lightly sweet and refreshingly tart with all the fruity flavors that came through on the nose with a nice bit of funky balance and a dry finish.  Really great stuff.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2013 Bottle 37,5 cl, batch 003, trade. Pours cloudy dark amber with a nice bubbly and creamy tanned head leaving lacing. Aroma is sour, sweet, stable, very fruity, some caramel and acidy. Flavor is very nice; fruity, acidy sour, some lemon juice, sweet, horse blanket, pungent phenolic and bitter with dry tones. Finishes with a fantastic fruity, sour and tart aftertaste. Excellent.

Batch 007.  From a 375ml bottle into a sniftah.  No head or lacing; looks still as a toilet on a quiet summers day.  Great cherry aroma.  Mouthfeel is fizzy... this has waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaayyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy too much carbonation even after sitting.  Taste is extremely tart.  Like super tart.  Touch of lime, sweet tart, cherries and only a bit of wine.  I wanted to like it more but the fizzyness and the overpowering tartness really got in the way of enjoying it.  Oh well, certainly worth a try.
Fantastic sour ale with the added bonus of the pinot noir, pour with a slightly pink colour and has all the aroma and taste of fruity PN wine and a great tart taste!

Poured into my Chimay glass. Aroma is great, sour cherries right away, then noticing the wine. Flavor is a mouth watering sourness, then you taste the cherries and Pinot nior. Highly carbonated, and finished somewhat dry. Color was a reddish brown. This is so complex and sour that it will be one of my all time favorites!

375 ml bottle, divine offering of the gods. Very complex aroma and flavors. I get tart, little funk, cherries, wine, darkfruits, oak, vanilla, even some cranberries in there. Endless flavors. Lingering pleasant tartness in the finish.

Bottle from Hover crossing. Pours amber with an inch of white foam that leaves some lacing. Big sour cherries on the nose. Quite nice and crisp. Big sourness on the tongue along with the crisp cherry taste. Nicely balanced between all the elements

Bottle, 375 mL.  Poured a brownish-red with nice little islands in it.  Has a very sharp, wine-like taste to it, not a surprise given the wine-barrel aging.  Pretty impressive beer.  Less carbonation than I was expecting.
Pours a slightly cloudy orange-copper with little to no head. Aroma is sourness with rich fruit aroma. Flavour with wood, sourness, and dark fruits.  Very drinkable and complex sour beer.

Pours a cloudy, brown with a fairly high level of carbonation bubbles. Rather thin, quickly dissipating head. Fruity, sour aroma. Flavor is a nice mild sourness, with a hint of cherries. Almost more like a wine than a beer. It takes some getting used to, but quite an enjoyable beer, off the beaten track.

Baby bottle in trade with Stefanje.  Shared with brew club at national home brewing day yesterday behind the Dutch.  Nose of sweet tarts.  Intense up front tartness that you get used to quite quickly.  Cherries appear  at back of tongue as plastic cup warms.  Slight sticky malts are ephemeral as is the oakiness.  A great starter prior to food consumption.  Thanks Stefan!

batch 7, 375 ml. pours a coper golden color with a small white head that is gone quickly. smell is acidic malty cherry though not too intense and throughly integrated. taste is acidic malty light cherry sweet tart. fruit flavor is low but present and adds a note of complexity to the yeast ester components. medium sour level just before squinting sourness. mouthfeel is medium light body that is smooth. carbonation is medium and bubbly.

375ml bottle.
One step closer in trying all the Russian River sours.  Had high expectations for this and it did not disappoint.  Muddy orange pour with a small amount of head that didnt stick around.  Aromas of tart cherry, oak, tannic, and funk.  Flavors of currant and cherry- lactic, woody, and wonderfully sour.  Top notch.
easily the best sour ive had to date. loads of sour funk. the sour cherries balance the sourness perfectly. awesome beer! thanks to Andrew for sharing
12oz corked & capped bottle This pours an opaque honey color, musty, slightly sweet aroma, with a nice vinuous & somewhat sweet flavor. Finishes smooth & clean. great beer.
38cl, Batch 3, exclusive American brew, thx to Walt!, complex sour Kriek, sour/woody and slightly fruity/vinous, very balanced, cloudy, small head, very good brew

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy copperish brown with smallish light tan coloured head. Very earthy aroma with sour cherries and some vinegary sourness. The wood also seems to be showing through. Slight acetone as it warms a little but very good all the same. Flavours are dominated by vinegary sourness and a little funk. Perhaps a hint of malt and some earthy funk to wrap it up. Medium mouthfeel. Great beer.

Sample @ RBNAG 11 (live rating). Deep near-black brown body, small white head. Oaky vanilla, vinegar, sulfurous wooden lactic funk tones, very interesting profile. Sweet vanilla oaky tones, hints of red wine, cane sugar and lactic acidic notes. Nice and quite original.
Slightly funky aroma.  Deep golden in color with an off-white head.  A slight tartness of flavor.

Bottle to snifter (batch #7). Pours clear red amber with a off white tight soapy head that dissipates to a tight foamy ring. Aroma is nice wine and oak with a subtle tartness thoughout. Taste is tart and sour with a grape oak and fruity flavor up front with a funk sourness throughout (AWESOME)! Palate is medium to full with great carbonation and finishes dry and some what puckering! Awesome sour! Probably the best yet that I have had!

My favorite of all the russian river (and other) sours we tried on our trip to northern california.  Rating is on tap at the brewery:  grape aroma.  cherry sour, crisp dry texture, buttery oak, acidic.  wonderful.  As much as Im craving the style now that weve returned to the sour wasteland of n. florida -- Id say I actually have the RRs underrated.  Id kill a man to drink these regularly.

Cant wait!!!! Been wanting to have this one for a very long time!! Crystal clear honey brown but then we through in the muck from the bottom of the bottle and now its murky. Aroma is funky SOUR!! White wine, oak, hidden sour cherry, more funk. Oh man this smells neat.  Taste is sourfulllike biting into raw lemon wedge sour. Taste is very similar to the aroma, oak, funk, wine, cherry, lemon, more stuff. This was an awesome sour!!! Thanks for sharing Jeff.
Sour aroma. Brown hazy colour. Sour taste with a bit of wine and cherries. Nice lively palate. A great beer.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2012 Bottle poured  in tulip glass. The scent of ripe sour cherries immediately comes to mind. Beautiful amber colour. I would enjoy this on a cool fall or winter evening. One of the most memorable beers Ive had the pleasure of drinking.

Ooooo. This will be awesome. Love the label. Cloudy orange goodness with a very long lasting light tan head that leaves some ropy lacing. Sour funky awesomeness invading my nose, perfect vinegar, vineous, plenty of oak, lightly cheesy, wonderful cherries, awesome. Smells better on the cold side.  Great taste! Sour cherries, oak, darkness, a bit of leather and tobacco, vineous, light cheese, sour hard finish yet soft. Love!

Bottle. Big thank you to Mike at Crown Liquors for sharing.

Poured pale amber. Big aroma of cherries, oak, and wine. Very effervescent. A little less sour than expected, but pleasant. You can tell great care was taken with this beer, but Im not amazingly overwhelmed by the final product. Solid, but not spectacular.

Damn good beer...that being said, I think so much of the ravenously devout following that RR has is based so much around the hype of the company, and thus societally imposed interpretations of the beer manifest. But, that being said, this is a great fucking work of craft.

The beer looks like Pinot Noir: slightly translucent ruddy brown color, good haziness, nice carbonation visible in the frothiness of the head.

Smells of beautiful vinous cherry, subtle oak, and tangy yeast.

Taste follows smell, almost to the letter. A bit more tang from the wild. very subtle and refreshing, not terribly funky.

This beer is a burnt orange color. It is not as dry as it smells. It has a small amount of Champagne like bubbles. The taste is very nice and lingers on the palate in the back of the throat. Overall, I have really enjoyed having this beer.
UPDATED: OCT 1, 2011 Draft at the brewery.  Poured a brownish color like a flanders red.  More subtle flavor than consecration.  The flavor of oak and pinot noir definitely stands out.

Orange copper color with thin white head. Musty oaky champagne like aroma. Sharp tart flavor with the oakiness of the barrel clearly the hero. Not tasting a lot of cherry here. Palate become more Complex as it sits on your tongue. You can taste the Pinot at the finish.

Batch 007 bottle...pours a reddish amber with a medium tan head...light sediment throughout.  Aroma has a sweet and sour quality...sweet with loads of cherries and wine notes but loads of funk too.  Flavor is intense...sour cherry, nice funk, leather...hint of wineyness.  Mouthfeel is light and very lively with a dry, winey/earthy finish.  Outstanding beer and nice use of pinot barrels.

From a package sent by Tenesseejed420: Pours a reddish brown color with an appetizing tannish head. Aroma is of sour cherries and a whole bunch of funk, then there is also some vinegar and a few other fancy things... maybe wine (surprise). Sourness in this beer comes up strongest right through the middle and then tones down by the end, but leaves a tingling mouthfeel throughout. Definitely more on the sour end of the spectrum for these here kind of ales. In a sense, this beer has every aspect I like of wine, but none of those that I  dont. Perhaps the best thing (and perhaps worst) is that it is ridiculously drinkable, the problem with that is that with the price you kind of go through a good amount of bills pretty quickly. Overall, this is an excellent sour ale and I am thrilled to be drinking it right now.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2011 Amber orange in color with plenty of carbonation and floaties.  Aroma of funk, crisp tartness, apples, light cherries, barrel.  Flavor is a round, crisp citrus tartness, barnyard, light merlot, cherry/apple, and touch of wood/vanilla.  Tart citrus and dry finish.  Very refreshing.
Tap @ Baileys, Portland. Didnt take any notes, but this was an excellent sour in the mad mix that was Portland that day.

On tap at Russian River. Pours dark amber with slight white head, leaves lots of lacing. Not much of an aroma, slight cherry hints. Flavor is amazing, perfectly sour with hints of cherries, can really taste the Pinot Noir aging on the back. Medium body with a smooth sour finish. Overall one of the best sour beers you can get anywhere. Had two more before a left.

Bottle. Clear amber color with a white head that left lots of lacing in the glass. Aroma is spicy, woody, and full of cherry notes. Slightly sweet with very balanced sour/winey middle that finishes smooth with the cherry rounding it out. Smooth mouthfeel, silky, creamy, and slightly astringent. Refreshing.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2011 Sour ales are slowly growing on me more and I was very happy to get a chance to try this one. +++Sampled from a 12.68 oz brown corked bottle this beer poured a hazy orange-caramel color with a huge fluffy orange-white head that lingered forever and left some lacing. The aroma was a lovely blend of tart and sour cherries, berries and cider vinegar. The flavor was incredibly tart and sour with strong notes of cherry, berry and cider vinegar and undertones of wood, must, bread and sourdough bread. The finish was long, tart, sour and fruity. Medium body. A bit too tart for my preference but the complexity of flavors was amazing.

Served on-tap into a mini pint at TJs 7th Anny. Party. Number two of three in my Russian River flight. An amazing party with amazing beers.

A - Pours dark amber, with a bit of red, with a thin film of head that leaves spotty lacing down the entire glass.

S - The sour hits you immediately but it dissipates quickly allowing you to really appreciate the nuances of this complex beer. The cherries are front and center in this one. Not as tart as temptation but still very pleasant.

T - Tart cherries up front slowly giving way to a oaky, earthy, flavor in the middle. Finish is quite funky with a bit of cherry skin texture. The balance of sour and sweet is nearly perfect. This one is nearly flawless. A great american wild ale.

M - Medium body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Tart finish lingers on the pallet but not for long. Nice and light on the pallet with a very nice feel.

D - Very High. The cherrie sweetness helps balance the sourness. Perfect balance of tart and sweet. One of the best wilds out there. I cant wait to open my bottle of this.

Bottle from Cavie.  Reddish pour with a small white head.  Aroma is cherry, sour, leather, and kinda woody.  Taste is really sour, tart, vinegar, cherry, and something just a little vile.  Stinging, sour, awkward finish.

Bottle courtesy adnielsen. Pours a clear orangish color with a light amount of carbonation. Aroma isnt as sour as I was expecting, but has some tartness, cherries and woody notes. This is actually fairly gentle on the nose. A pleasant surprise. The flavor on the otherhand is quite sour. Lots of tingling notes over the palate. Woody flavors and I suppose I could taste some sweet cherries in this. Certainly intense, and certainly sour.

Bottle of batch 006. Pours a dark amber with a slightly frothy head. Lots of carbonation coming from bottom of the glass. Aroma is heavy of the tart, sour cherry smells. slight smell of fruity oak present as well. Taste is very tart first and foremost. delicious notes of dark cherries and oak balance out the flavor. Finishes with a great balance between sweet and vinegar. also is quenching, making it very drinkable.

On tap at the brew pub, served in a tasting glass. Pours clear caramel with a small, white head. The head fades slowly, leaving behind a small amount of fine lace. On the nose, it is quite sour with Brettanomyces and Lactobacillus and notes of red wine and sour cherry. There are also notes of oak, flowers and caramel. The flavour is intensely sour throughout, with red wine and oak. The finish is long and sour, with cherry and fruit. On the palate, it is light-medium in body with a slightly dry texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a great sour. It is intensely sour and very complex, with red wine, cherries and oak. The oak is a very nice touch. 2011-06-09

Pours a rich, deep, amber color with thick white head and little lacing.  Aromas of sourness - cherries, lemons, just overall citrus.  Taste is totally sour with some cherry notes.  The wine bitterness comes through on the back end, and I am not a wine lover of any sorts.  Palate is mildly carbonated, but acidic.  Finish is short and dry.  Overall, I find this beer refreshing.  I am starting to like sours/wilds better and this one is pretty good with the touch of cherries.

375 ML bottle. Pours a darkish amber/brown with a thin amount of head. The aroma right away is sour cherries followed by oak and some funk. The flavor is very complex. There is sour tart cherries and brett with oak and wine. There is also vinegar, but not too much. Its pretty sour on the palate, but not overpowering making this an enjoyable beer.

Bottle thanks to johhnyJ. The nose on this one makes my mouth water! Brownish red pour with a tight/light white head.  Nose is leathery cherries, tart lemon like sourness, white wines, oak, nice brett funk.  Flavor is nicely sour with plenty of cherry flavor complementing the wonderful sour flavors. crisp and dry on the palate.  Really a fantastic sour especially for someone like me thats fairly new to sours.

Ill start with saying Im not sure how well this bottle was handled before it got to me, so there may be better experences out there with this beer for me. With that said, I really enjoyed this sour/wild ale. Sour cherries, sour notes, woah.

This is another one that several of us were looking forward to opening. Upon opening the bottle there was a nice POP from pulling the cork and the aroma of sour cherries and sour fruit fill your nose and make you want to pucker up a little. Pours a brilliant red with good carbonation and a mild light pink head. The initial taste is that of strong sour fruit and it lingers for a while before living the mouth. Takes you back to the days of sucking on sour worms and war heads until you tongue was sore. Liquid candy was how many people described it.

Currant and apple nose, with a neat undercurrent of moon pie (banana creme and graham cracker), funky. Clear copper, lots of carbonation, thick yellow head with little retention. Sour apple with currant accents. Subtle graham cracker finish. Alcohol not noticeable, carbonation and sourness are at optimal levels. Not spectacular just a remarkably well made sour with a fair amount of character.

Definitely worthy of rating number 200. 2010 bottle. Pours a cherry amber with very thin head which settles to the rim quickly.  Aroma is incredible - dark cherries, oak, vanilla, and plenty of funk.  Taste is perfection for a sour ale - sour cherry but not overly mouth puckering and this is balanced nicely by the oak and the hint of pinot noir, funk there also.  Amazing sour as usual from RR.  Wish could have brought back more.

375mL bottle 006X1 pours a deep amber with a medium khaki head. Aroma of tart cherries, Brett, can definitely smell the Pinot barrels.  Sour tartness of the cherries hits first, very lively carbonation, gaining some sweetness, into Brett and finishing on dry notes of the Pinot. Very nice!

Poured into an (awesome) Iron Hill 10th anniversary chalice from a bottle. Batch 5.

Aroma- Sour cherries up front with a touch of oak.

Appearance- Bright red, a nice amount of head with excellent retention and lacing. Continuous bubbles rising to top while drinking.

Taste- Sour cherries up front and in the finish. Hints of oak and vanilla are present as well.

Palate- The carbonation provides a soft, pillowly-like mouthfeel. Extremely pleasing. The sour notes sting the tongue a little, so this is not one for the beginner, but any experienced sour drinker should greatly enjoy this.

Overall- One of the best American Wild Ales out there. Anyone who enjoys sours should seek this one out!
Nice sweet aroma, color is reddish,  taste is sour at first with a sweet finish. Great.

Poured from a corked and caged 375ml.

Batch 005X5

A: Ports a reddish amber with little clarity. The head is a think white layer that has nice lacing and somehow stays with throughout the tasting.

S: Sour Cherry, lime, very little oak if any.

T: The sour cherries and overall tart is great. The sourness hits the front of my pallet aggressively but fades away allowing for more of the subtle notes to shine.
The brett/lacto/pedio and apparent but man does this finish so clean. If it were easy I suspect all American Wilds would taste this good.

M: Not to thick. The carbonation here is perfect for the style.

D: Perfect ! I could drink much more than RR would suggest...

Pours a slight hazy reddish brown into the glass with bright Red highlights. Aromas of tart cherry and dark fruit and oak. Flavor is a burst of intense but smooth sourness delivered nicely with the carbonation with a bit of fruitiness and faint oak. Very soft malt flavors stay on the tongue as it dries out on the finish. Not my "Style" of beer, but starting to intrigue me more and more. Just like 2IPAs did a couple of yrs. ago, now they are 1 of my favorite styles. Maybe sours will be next?
Pours gorgeous amber with head that leaves great lacing on the glass. Beautiful sour cherry notes, slight funkiness, finishing slightly sweet. Doesnt get much better than this.

Just an outstanding beer. The aroma is full cherries. The taste is complex is the perfect combination of tartness and sweetness. The palate is almost like a light syrup. Excellent. Possibly my favorite beer.
Aroma of cherry, wood. Taste is tart cherry.  Quite sour in the Initial taste with a sweet finish.  Winelike qualities. Excellent.

On the nose this beer was promising with plenty of cherry and some funk. However the taste was disappointing with very little fruit character coming through and dare I say it a bit bland and very little sourness.
on tap at choice city butcher in fort collins, and a few times in bottles before, this is an excellent sour so refreshing and tasty, one of my favorite sours i have had

375 C&C bottle of batch 5. A perfect summer sour to enjoy on a cooling evening. Pours a reddish orange with a fluffy head. Aroma of sour cherries, wood, wine and green apples. Flavor is a bit  funky with a medium sweetness and touch of sourness. Medium bodied with nice carbonation. Well balanced. Finishes sour and tart. Velly nice stuff.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Strong earth aroma with leather, cherries and hints of grapes. Light brown, off-white head, good lace. Starts dry, leather, earth, Brett. The middle is sour but soon it gets sweet with cherry and marzipan. Sticky mouth feel. Very well balanced.

Bottle at home shared by oj83! Thanks man! Aroma is of sweet cherry but there is not much on the taste! We had been drinking lambics along side this and this didnt really compare! Was quite weak in aroma, taste and palate! Its maybe a harsh comparison but the Malvasia Rosso kicked its arse! Interesting to try!

Bottle from South Bay Drugs and Liquor: Finally, I find a bottle of this sought after recipe from Russian River. I just never gave into the ridiculous prices the local bars were charging to buy and drink this beer in their bar. Starting off, this created a beautiful topping of head while the liquid was a perfectly tinted brass color with a lot of violent carbonation bubbles. In the nose, there is a bold aromatic scent of tart fruit and a woody sour barrel smell similar to Flemish ale. The flavor is tart with notes of sourness and sweetness, but is remarkably delicious and robust with flavors of tart cherry, wood barrel and a healthy serving of authentic blend of Flemish yeasts.

bottle from a trade with Norcalgrowler - - huge fruit, cherry, syrupy sweetness. Very aroumatic, earthy, caramel sweetness, touch of vineous notes, packed with tart/lactic acid, tingly carbonation effervesnt. Finish is slightly dry, with light hop notes and cherries raisin syrup  slightly medicinal. Some throat burning. Tasty mf beer.

375ml bottle batch 5/5. Pours an orange amber with an off-white head, fading to a light lacing that has great staying power. Nice tart and funky aroma, brett, cherries and oak. Nice balanced sourness on the palate, full-bodied, good carbonation, tartness grows into a great finish with sour cherries with a nice bitter barnyard taste throughout.

Rounding out my Russian river ratings. Pours a hazy brownish red color with a large creamy canvas colored head. Nose is vanilla and toasted oak, red wine vinegar, black cherries, and something like milk chocolate. More cherries on the taste with a semi sour tannic finish. Pretty good.

375ml bottle. Corked and Caged. Light brown color with a very thin head. Aroma has a good bit of sour funk along with cherries and spiciness. Flavor is a little bit acidic with a nice bitter sweet tartness. Not over the top sour but right on the fence.  A great sour!!

On tap at Belmont Station on 5/10/2011. Pours a reddish amber color with a thin, dissipating white head. Aroma is tart cherry and oaky wood. Flavor is very sour, tart cherries, and a mild sweetness towards the end. Mouthfeel is thin with a very sour/sweet finish. A little too tart for me, but this is definitely more drinkable than some sours Ive had. Good stuff.
While this is a great sour beer I prefer softer rounder sour. This is very sharp and acidic. The aroma is awesome. Really straight forward. Not as complex as other sours I have had.

Pours a light brown, crystal clear. Smells minerally and very sour, vinegary.  After much smelling and some help (still new at this) some cherry tones.  Tastes very sour, with a disarming sweetness.  very complex, delicious beer.

Attraktiv saurer Antrunk mit bedeutenden und gut erkennbaren Kirschnoten. Hierbei ist die Säuerlichkeit trotz ihrer Intensität ausgewogen und keinesfalls aufdringlich, süffig. Die Säuerlichkeit bleibt konstant, wenig Essig. Die Kirschnoten werden mit der Zeit stärker und sorgen für zusätzliche Frische. Spritzig, gut! 11/12/13/13/11/13

I really do love this beer.  So much has been said about it already that Im really going to leave my rating to do the speaking on this one.  It really is that good.  Definitely has thinned out in the past few years with the bigger batches, but goddamn son, I could drink this daily!

Bouteille de 375 ml, batch 4. Arômes très complexes de chêne, de vin rouge et de brettanomyces. Robe ambrée et légèrement trouble, très belle mousse qui tient bien et effervescence assez active. Très complexe et vivante en bouche, le fût de pinot noir est relativement à lavant-plan, apportant de belles touches boisées et de fruits rouges. Belle présence de pépins de cerises. Les bactéries et levures font preuve dun bel équilibre, montrant de très intéressants aspects citronnés. Longue finale lactique et légèrement astringente. Vraiment très bon !

12.68oz corked and caged bottle, Batch 006X1, from a trade with thome50.  This pours bright cherry red, slightly hazy, and very lively and effervescent, topped with a 2.5-finger creamy light beige head.  A slightly pinkish spot is present atop the foam from where some yeast dripped out during the pour, and the head slowly collapses inwards while a mesmerizing stream of bubbles shoots upwards.  The aroma is sour cherries, oak, tart berry and Brettanomyces, and moderate funk and mustiness.  The flavor is tart cherry, yeast, barnyard and horse funk, and straw.  The finish includes lightly puckering cherry and raspberry, with some bitter grass and horse notes.  The carbonation is moderate, despite the lively nature of this beer, and its medium body makes this both smooth and refreshing.  This is very drinkable.  Overall, this was incredible.  I could drink this stuff all the time.  Thanks Justin!  [693]
Bottle. Pours orange/brown with a medium white head. Aroma is pineapple, apples, pears, cherries, and grapes. Flavor is pineapple, pears, apples, and grapes. Very fizzy, thin/medium body.
Bottle from Verdugo Bar, Los Angeles. Hazy, red copper with a rocky head. Sour fruit notes, yoghurt and wood. Tastes quite sour with woody dryness. A great piece of work.

Beautiful leathery amber color, with frothy head.  Some chunkies in the beer because I wasnt careful pouring.  Aroma was that of cherry and vinegar.  Sour flavor with mild cherry sweetness and a surprising amount of bitterness as well.  Smooth mouthfeel coated the mouth.  Good beer.  Not sure Ill buy again at the prices Ive seen, but worth a shot once.
Smaller bottle. Poured light hazy brown with small head. Light sour flavour with small fruit/cherry flavours coming through. This was excellent and I wish I had more.

Another amazing sour from RR, these guys know how to do it. This poured a nice looking sour and it had a good souriness too it, Sadly I cant get my hands on this stuff easy. I would be a frequent purchaser of this one. Very nice offering
Bottle with Carla. Pours a brownish ruby red  with a tan foam. Smells sour of bing cherries and a bit of grapes. Tastes very sour with lots of cherries and a lingering sweetness at the end.
Great beer, sour with a great twist, just had the consecration rather similar, but I enjoyed this one slightly more.

375ml bottle. Rating #809. Batch #6x2. Nice bright orange/red pour with a light white head. Tart, dry fruit aroma, cherries of course and a little vineous. Really dry, more tart cherries and a real light aftertaste that left my mouth watering, really quite an exceptional beer. (1682)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Oh yeah... Clear amber, small white head, light sediment, lively... Sour cherry barnyard, funk, sour tart lemon, complex, balanced in the sour ale way... Tart sour cherry flavor, nice balance of sour and just enough sweet, fruity... Very lively medium bodied dry finish, amazingly complex... There is a reason this beer is as sought after as it is, deftly balanced and masterfully crafted...

If you can find a better sour beer anywhere, please tell me where.  Consecration is a very close second but nothing out does this brown beauty.
The amazing thing is how consistently good Supplication is.  Cantillon eat your heart out.
cherry, citrus, pineapple, pears.  amber color with light head.  sour, pineapple, cherry grapes. good bodied a little wet though
Has this on Sunday afternoon relaxing on the patio.  Woody cherry nose with mild sourness and the defining barnyard aromas.  Its both tart and sour, refreshing with an astringent finish.
Pours a clear golden orange with a medium white head. Sour cherries and pineapple. Wood and cherries on the taste.  Palate is good. Acidy but an eaasy drinker. Really awesome.

At a tasting, many thanks to tomer, pours hazy orange with a medium head, sour aroma with olives, sour cherries, fresh leaves, horse skin and wood tones, nice acidity in flavor with bret, vinous tones, cherries juice and wood, medium to full bodied, great.

Poured from 375ml btl at Euclid Hall into a white wine glass.

A: High head that recedes fast into just a little over the top of the beer. 
Low lacing. Pours Copper with brown hues.

S: High sour and acidic aroma with touch of wood and small wild cherries.

T: Deeply complex but balanced. Sour notes are high and very tart, finish is long and delicious and dry.

M: Wonderful carbonation and medium to full bodied. Tart on the back sides of palate, finishes dry.

D: Fantastic sour meant to be sipped just like a fine dry red.

Courtesy of Oakes, 37cl corked bottleCloudy light amber color; small creamy head. Harmonious aroma, some Bretts, perfumy, a bit spicy. Juicy mouthfeel, smooth, with citrusy sourness, woody astringency. Dynamic, sour final, agile. It wins for being well harmonious overall.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2012 Aroma of Pinot Noir and Olives.  Taste is complex.. An amazing aged sour cherry wine taste with a pleasant lasting finish.  One of the most unique and best beers I have ever tried.

Update: 2nd batch I tried via bottle on New Years Eve, not quite as good as first.
heavenly Pinot and sour cherries, sour apples, oak, amazing depth. Sour sour mouth. Well balanced not too heavy.

At a tasting, many thanks mom and dad, almost no head, very hazy dark orange colour, sour fruity nose with lemon, overipe oranges, some berries amd a pronounced oaky presence, flavour of orange,  peach with strong notes of oak and vanila, strong mellow sourness, excellent balance between the sourness and oak. Truely excellent.

Beer is brown and slightly hazy. Form an off white head of small bubbles that falls away leaving some lacing on the glass. Carbonation is moderate to low. Looks good, not sure what I expected.

Aroma is sweeter than I was expecting for sure. There is also a funky spiciness to the whole thing. Im interested for sure. Whats going to happen next.

OK, I like this beer but this is not my favorite sour, not at all. This was sweet and there is a lot of carbonation in the mouth that accents the sour notes. It ends rather tart but overall its not as sour as the other offerings. Its citric and lactic in nature with a pretty dominant sweetness overall. Mouthfeel is good and drinkability is high. Still a great beer.

Serving type: on-tap

Bottle from Healthy Spirits, San Francisco. Shared with Mes&Sim. A reddish orange pour with a thin off white head. Wonderfully sour nose. Tart cherry and barrel notes with a dash of da funk all add up to one sniffable mother. Superb medley of flavours. The sour cherry was the best Ive tasted with the barrel aspect taking things to another dimension. Delicate and smooth. Warmed up a treat with every sip a pleasure. Dried out towards the finish whilst retaining a whole hunk of tartness. Super good.

I drank this batch 003 from a 375ml bottle into a Rochefort glass.

The beer pours a brownish ornange more of an orange tinge with a about 2 fingers of head that has a dark orange tint to it. The retention is great, the head lasts about 5 minuts but even after that is a heavy head that lasts forever. The lacing is great as well. 

The aroma is slightly disappointing because its relatively light and not overtly complex. Mostly you just get some tartness overall with a little oak at the. 

The taste is good not great. Just like the aroma its not complex just a very nice sour note from start to finish. I love sour but I want to be rewarded as well. At the end I get a little wood.

The feel is nice and coats well, drinkability is down a tad.

375 ml bottle.  I forgot which batch number.  Poured a hazy reddish brown color with a nice white head.  Sour aroma with some cherries in the background.  Sour taste with moderate funk.  The cherries round out the flavor nicely.  Nice prickly carbonation, with a dry puckering finish.  This is a good beer but not my favorite from the "tion" line.

375 ml bottle, batch #004. The body pours a hazy reddish orange color and topped by a small head of off white that quickly settles to a thin film and leaves just a small ring of lacing around the glass. The aroma is really nice with tart sour cherries right up front followed by soft oak, lactic funk, and vinous pinot noir grapes. The flavor follows suit and is based mostly in the soured cherries but the pinot grapes add some signature vinous flavor as well. The soft oak imparts its signature vanilla flavor while the brett really dries things out and lets the other bugs sour things up. The pinot noir barrel lends perfectly with the sour ale base. Medium bodied with lively carbonation, but still very smooth and easy to drink with a dry thirst quenching finish. Each sip begs for another. This is an awesome beer. Another fantastic sour ale from Russian River.

Bottle, batch 005x2.  Aroma: sour cherries, some fruit and malt sweetness, bit of citrus.
Appearance: a rosy-amber color with slight haze, unstable head dissipates to a thin ring quickly.
Flavor: sweet malt and fruit followed by a large dose of sour cherries.  Tasty, puckering sourness and a hint of oak.  Dry, sour finish.  
Palate: medium body and high carbonation, effervescent.
Overall: nice complex sour beer with a great fruit profile, enjoyed this one quite a bit.

Just realized as I was looking at my notes that I didnt write down what batch this was, but I know it was from one of the last 2 batches.  Glowing reddish orange color that is mildly hazy.  Large white head present as well.  Lightly sour aroma with cherries being present.  Taste is rather sour and acidic.  Cherries make an appearance towards the finish which gives this beer a lightly sweet flavor.  Fairly lively carbonation, with a slightly prickly mouthfeel.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2014 12.68 fl oz brown corked and caged bottle. Batch 005x5.

It pours with a fizzy white head that dissipates quickly, then slows down. It doesnt leave a whole lot of lacing. The beer is a plumb skin/passionfruit skin color with a nice bead of orange.

The smell is sweet but tart. It has a ncie fragrance of sour cherries, but also a sugary sweetness. There is so,e lemon rind coming form the yeast as well. The oak isnt that well-pronounced in the smell.

The flavor is at first of sweet cherries, then then it turns to to a dry, lemony pucker. There is a int of funkiness to it but nothing overpowering. Te cherries really shine here, with both sweet cherry flavor and tartness. The oak lingers in the background, accenting the beer just enough. There is an overall hint of mineral water which makes it lighter, but also a bit more blunt with the flavor delivery. I think it lacks a midground between the subtle sweetness and super sour. 

Overall it is a pretty good sour, perhaps overrated, but great for people who love a ton of sourness.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-09-2010 23:37:26

Tried a batch 2 magnum and wow, one of the best sours I ahve ever had.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2011 1. On Tap at Oskar Blues Home Made Liquids & Solids, Longmont 15/09/2010
Slightly sour aroma. Amber coloured strong in alcohol sour and fruity with a hint of dryness in a lasting finish.
2. On Tap at Star Bar, Denver 19/09/2010
Sour fruit aroma. Bronze golden coloured fruity and sour with some alcohol present. A hint of dryness in a lasting malt finish.

Brown amber beer with a nice high-retention off-white head.  Aromas of tart cherries and a slight musty funk like your grandmas closet with some barnyard notes.  Flavor is rich and then sour and then finishes somewhat clean but with a finishing flavor profile that I cant begin to categorize.  Fascinating in its deliciousness.  I had this next to an authentic gueuze, and following it I had an oak-aged Dogfish Head 2IPA, Dogfish Palo Santo, and then finally (after dinner), Lost Abbey Angels Share.  And of all those, THIS is the one I wanted more of.   Could drink it all night.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy amber color with white head. The aroma is cherries, oak, a nice tartness and a little brett. The flavor is sour cherries, oak tannins, leather, and a little bit on the pinot peaking through. The body is a little thin and the beer is dry on the finish. Excellent brew.

Bottle courtesy of Largiari. Batch 5. Ive had aged batches of this, and I always prefer it young. Pours a hazy ruby red with a medium white head that dissipates to a thin layer that sticks around leaving a little lacing in my snifter. Aroma is bright tart cherries with vinegar, and acidic notes. Body is light, but not thin. Flavor is much the same as the aroma. Nice tart cherries up front with a very sharp acidic sour finish. Intensely sour, but not at all harsh. One of my absolute favorites!

This is cherry beer champagne. Very high bubbly carbonation with strong but sweet acidity. Brownish amber color with small bubbly head. The cherry flavor is really well balanced - well-flavored yet not too sweet. Really nice.

Courtesy of ygtbsm94  Thanks for sharing this gem, Brad!  Dark brownish amber, creamy white head.  Sour cherry and musty wood notes warm to a citric-vinous swirl.  Deep sour lactic cherry and vinous-like tones balance well on touches of bready yeast and funked oak throughout.  Medium to full bodied, zesty carbonation, drying sour cherry finish.  Fantastic

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2011 had this beer during russian river tap takover at Surly Goat, ...great beer, sour with sour cherry taste very prominent. I loved this beer, it was a very complex brew with the brett taking a bit away from the rest of the taste.

Draft. Pours hazy brown with a big off-white head. Aroma of dark cherries, barnyard funk with some sweetness in the nose. Flavor is dry with a pleasant tartness dominating the finish. Very refreshing and very sessionable.

375ml bottle poured into a tulip glass.  The aroma is sweet and sour....getting notes of dried apricots and cherries with some funk.  Not too sweet though, very inviting.  The beer pours a brown color with minimal off white head that leaves nice lacing on the glass.  The taste is sour up front, lactic but not overpowering...and not sweet.  Not so sour as to pucker, but just tingly on the taste buds.  The palate is is thin with medium carbonation and a sour finish.  Overall, this is a terrific beer that has many different facets.  Drink cool, but not cold

From a small bottle, pours a nice brown color with a thin head. Smell of cherry, oak, sour, molasses, and a subtle wine character. Taste is sour cherry, oak barrels, slight dried fruits, and a bit nutty. Palate is thin and bitter and funky sourness with an alcohol finish. Delicious.

Got this bottle from Santa (Prototypic), thanks for the opportunity. Batch 003 375ml sampled 12/10/2008

Pours a slightly cloudy orangey amber with a bubbly white head that sticks around forever. I can smell the sour from here while Im pouring, yum. Upon closer inspection many layers reveal themselves to my nostrils. Theres the sour funk, the cherries, the spicy Belgian yeast, bready malt. Just wonderful smelling really. Taste is sour lemons, limes, green apples, some cherries, a bit of acid. Any trace of malt or yeast gets buried in the sour while tasting. Sour fruits galore, but not overpowering. Incredibly drinkable. Very dry finish. Crisp Carbonation, medium body, Creamy dry mouthfeel. Wow this is good! One of the best Ive had, although a little more cherry wouldnt hurt.

Bottle from 2006, pours a gorgeous muddy ruby color with a this pale white head. This beer is amazing, tart berries, peaches and lots of brett in a nice thin perky body. The flavors are so foward but the sourness is perfectly balances. I wish I bought a whole case of this. Yum!

This had a better aroma than some of their other sour ales. Although the wine was still a bit too prominent, it had a fresher taste than Consecration. Cherries were a pleasant touch, they added a slight sweetness to compliment  the sourness. A good beer, that I am glad I tried, but may not be for the conventional beer drinker.
Another big winner from Russian River. I love this almost as much as I adore Consecration, if thats at all possible.

Rating #500. Sent to me from changeup45. Super tart and sour aroma and flavor full of Brett.  Intense yet smooth. Im not sure if this is better than Consecration. I would love to try both side by side. Overall, a good choice for #500.

Bottle thanks to bigmmartin.  Pours a reddish brown with a nice white head.  Aroma is sweet malts and cherries.  Notes of sour yeast, bread, and a bit of dark fruit.  Palate is stiff.  The taste is sour....what was that candy or gum, tear jerkers, compare to that?  The aroma couldnt even come close to warning me about that.  It finishes dry, leaving a sweet cherry flavor.

Bottle. Batch 1, 2005. Quite hazy amber colour with a small white head. Aroma has lots of red-wine-ish oak, sour cherries, acetone, vinegar, funk, some rum/brandy notes as well as grapes and raisins. Quite fruity with a banana-like end. Taste is moderately sour with a strong oak body. Quite vinous and thick with some brett to provide the relatively modest sourness. The sweetness is fruity and carries the whole thing along nicely. There is some tartness, but the underlying oak components sweetens it out. Low carbonation, long duration. A very niec beer, but the harmony between aroma and taste isnt exactly on key. The aroma promises strong tart and sourness, while the taste is more sweet and oaky. Nonetheless, this is an extremely enjoyable and interesting beer!

Draft at Obriens. Dark red with dissipating head.  Nose is subtle with hints of sour cherries, oak, and darker malts coming through.  Flavor is sublime, chocolate cherries followed quickly by a blast of acetic sourness that borders on puckering, solid base of nutty and caramel malts, finishes dry and sour.  Medium body, modest carbonation, watery texture. One of the best sours out there, wonderful combination of malt base with fruity esters and aged oak accents.

This by far my favorite sour. The balance: tart fruit, sweet fruit, wood and that awesome dry finish cant be beat. The color is amazing. Crystal clear. The only beer that poured more beautifully for me was the Isabelle Proximus. This beer is one of the big reason why Russian River is, to me, the best brewery in the US. Perfect Sour. Perfect 5.

Poured into a tulip. Big thanks to DaveJanssen for this. Batch 04x5.

5.0 A: Hazy orange amber color. Two fingers of cream colored creamy head with pretty good retention and complete coverage of lacing.

4.5 S: Tart cherries from the start. Tannic astringency and oak. Moldy basement, lactic acid, and acetic acid. Lots of crazy funk going on, but balancing wild and tart fruitiness.

4.0 T: Lots of funk again, with emphasis on the brett contributions. Horsey, dank basement, a touch of wet cardboard. Lots of oak again with tannic astringency. The fruitiness is much less apparent in the taste. Some of the tart cherry remains, but not much of the other fruity complexity that is found in the nose.

3.5 M: Lighter medium body. Carbonation is a bit too aggressive for my liking. Could be creamier. Not bad, but nothing special.

3.5 D: Good, but would prefer some more fruitiness in the taste. Toward the end, the tartness seems empty if that makes any sense.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-03-2010 02:27:22

Batch 1, 2005. Pours chestnut amber brown with a small disapating head. Aroma has clear oak impressions at first, vanilla, almost balsamico sweet and sour, the cherries are evident, very tart.  The brettanomyces stands out very clearly, faint hints of banana and brown sugar. The oak character is reminiscent of french red wine oak. Very delicious aroma, the things play out very well together. 
The taste is a lot sweeter than the aroma suggests. There is a lot of cherries and oak, the oak being sweet and a bit vanilla-ish, almost caramel sweetness, malts are more evident than expected. Below the sweeter notes, there is a clear brett component, and a stinging tartness that might alos be found in lambics. I guess its the oak and the funky yeasts. It reminds me of Rodenbach. Very good, but I guess I had expected a lot more tartness than this. But I enjoyed it a lot anyway.

Bottle (Batch 1 - yes it is). Hazy brown with a thine white head. Sour lactic aroma with notes of caramel, sour winegums, acetone and pineapple. Surprisingly sweet taste and bit salty; not as sour as the aroma indicated. The flavour is more earthy and very fruity. The finish is sweet and a little sour. I loved the aroma, but I think the aroma and flavour doesnt balance very well. But still VERY good.
375 mL bottle.  on recommendation of HB Mason.  Excellent sour,  great taste and complex nose.  little head and little lacing

Pours a dark reddish brown color that is easy on the eyes. Had this a few days after having consecration, and in comparison this beer was just about equal in taste. Sour cherries dominate aroma along with taste, with a nice dry finish on the palate. Sourness is well balanced with flavor. Tastes very much like wine at times (in a good way), and the tart fruity flavors complement that taste well.

Bottle I won with a haiku!!! Poured a near clear amber with a light brown head that dissipated slowly to the edges. Aroma was full of tart cherries with oak, a slight funk and a bit of a grain backbone. Flavor started with tart cherry that grew towards acidity and was joined by oak and funk.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2011 Tap @ Brouwers. Clear ruby-amber pour with a minimal white head leaving moderate lace. Sour, Brett nose. Sour, cheesey, funky blueberry, lemon, lime and cherry medium body, with a short, tart finish. The butteriness of the Brettanomyces manifests mostly in the aftertaste. Light, very fine carbonation. Outstanding, even among other RR sour ales.

Notes, 07/2010.

Batch 05x01.

Dark Persian red that leaves a thorough lace trace of itself, like the indented cushion in a prayer bench. Only here, Im coming to, not going from. 

Decadent nose comprised of dark cherry, fruity vinegar, and woodiness, with a subtle but present balancing vulgarity from the brett and bacteria. Sharp, clean balance of lemon-lime, fermented-through cherry, funk, and fresh, tangy summertime berries. Dry oak finish.

Im not sure why, but Im having a moment with this beer. Brown malt, lactic acid, clean citrus-berry, light tannins, some acetic acid, the brettiness, the abrupt dry finish, like a dramatic anacoluthon in mid-sentence. It tames as you drink on, which, strangely, provides an added layer of complexity.

I wove this beer into the narrative of my life and it rewarded me. Just a masterful beer by RR.

I am not normally a sours guy - but this is class. Really refined. The wine barrels impart a lovely oaky grapey nuance. Funk is a perfect accomyment, rather than feeling tacked on as it does for some beers. Fantastically put together and a true masterclass.

Bottle.
Pours brown orange with a small yellowish head. 
Sweeter than expected aroma of oranges and cherries.
The taste is more tart than the aroma suggests,, finishes in a dry wooden note.

Bottle. Pours brown orange with a small but long lasting off white head. Sweet and sour cherry in the aroma. Notes of currant seeds and rose water. The taste is sweet like strawberries with dry wood notes in the finish. Sweet and easy to drink, yet complex.

Big thanks to Kevin for sharing this one!
A-pours a vibrant dark amber with nice red glow to it.  The head is a thick and creamy off white leaving a strong lace on the side of the glass.

S-light acidity up front, notes of oak and brett play together, sour cherries come in behind.  the aromas are simple yet well integrated.

T-here the brett comes in first, light leathery notes, good dry oak presence that doesnt detract but adds to it, sour cherries are so juicy and vibrant.  almost no acidity but a nice bit of sourness to it.

M-medium to light body, very smooth and creamy with a decent bit of carbonation and a semi dry finish that prickles on the back of the throat.

D-this is very simple and straight forward but still very tasty.  the flavors blend together very well and it goes down so smooth. it has a great sourness to it with virtually no acidity.

Pours a clear brown with a light foamy head.  Really just a wonderful aroma.  Smells of sweet cherries and oak come through as well as a barn yard type quality.  Im impressed with the amount of cherries that are coming through.  Very lively carbonation.  The flavors are just terrific.  An outdoorsy barnyard flavor is accompanied by the tart cherries.  The oak is slightly noticeable and the sour notes are strong being both tastey and felt, but there is a definite vinuous quality that really is spectacular.  The finish is rather dry and very sour.  This is just an overall outstanding beer.

Bottle from a trade with phaleslu. Batch 04x4. Pours clear copper color with off white head. Sour cherry aroma with some oak. Mouth puckering sourness. Tart cherry flavor with some woodiness and vinous notes. Light to medium body with effervescent carbonation and a dry finish. Excellent brew. Thanks Peter.
Hazy orange pour.  Oaked cherries, tart and gueuzy.  Very tasty stuff.  Id like to have it again when I can try to enjoy it a bit longer.

courtesy of fiulijn - amber-brown colour with a little beige foam left; solid aroma of wood, dried cherries and vinegar; creamy mouthfeel, quite full-bodied and fairly tasty, a fair acidity, long aftertaste of cherries, wood and vinegar - superb work again from RR

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2013 12.7 oz. bottle, pours a clear bronze / orange with a tiny head. Nose is very complex, full of sour cherries, red wine, and brett and other wild yeast. Flavour is similarly complex, with loads of red wine, a little vinegar, brett, and some slight sour cherries. Highly complex and wonderfully well-integrated. A classic sour. Excellent stuff.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2011 Bottle from La Bodega Wine & Spirits.  Batch 04x2.  First taste of this beer.  Pours a hazy amber with a thin white head and minimal lacing.  Aroma is sweet and fruity.  Medium body on the palate with heavy carbonation.  Taste is oak and sour cherry, with what seems like the perfect amount of tartness.  Any more would probably be too much.  Finish is very dry.  I would drink this all the time if money and availability would allow.

Finally got this one delivered today. Poured from the new 375mL style bottle into my tulip glass.

A: Pours a copper/ruby color with a nice two-finger head that is ever-so-slightly pink. Plenty of lacing initially as the head recedes, and some nice legs as it goes down.

S: A good amount of cherry in addition to a hefty amount of lactic sourness. Some oak. The cherry itself isnt over-the-top, but is somehow soothing as I inhale. Also detecting a very modest amount of earthy funk.

T: The cherries bring this beer to a completely different level. Absolutely beautiful how they are integrated--both sweetness and tartness--with the lactic sourness of the base beer. A bit of brown malt underlying the entire brew.

M: Fairly low carbonation on a medium body. Not terribly mouth-puckering, but fairly dry with a nice acidity.

D: Very drinkable, especially considering the style. Good carbonation levels, beautiful fruit, and a beautifully-balanced sourness.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-18-2010
Tap at the source, in the company of new friends.  Amber color, white head, solid lacing.  Aroma of butterscotch.  Taste is very malty, red wine vinegar but more mild, malty and sour.  Decent.

Pours a soft red with a luscious but quickly fading white head. Very pungent aroma. The intensity makes it hard to discern, but the cherries are definitely there with some lemon. Sour but not overly fruity, and the pinot noir does a good job blending with the cherries. Near the end it almost feels like a wine if not for my tongue being numb from the sourness. Complex and quite enjoyable. Thanks Dan!
375 ml. bottle.  Pours a cloudy gold/orange with a small biege head.  Aroma of sour cherries and wood.  Tastes of the pinot noir balanced by the cherries, somewhat dry.  Superb.

Ruby red pour with a massive off white head. Aroma is sour funk, cherries, oak. Flavor is wonderfully tart on the front end with some good vinious notes and a subtle yet outstanding oak hint. Really excellent beer.

Bottle: Pours a hazy Dark Golden, almost brownish in coloration. Nice creamy off white head with average retention- amazing lacing on this brew in my Lost Abbey tumbler. Aroma is of vinegar and cherries, lemon peel and spices. I started a bit too cold, but the flavors are unlocking for me here - fantastic blend of sour cherries and lemon peel; oak and vinousness are present -  the head gives it a creamy feel in combination with the tartness that you expect on the sour. Fantastic really -  And now on to the next : Consecration!

12oz btl thanks to Kristina. Poured a hazy amber orange.A refreshing aroma of fruit, some lemon, and a that cherry element. Can grasp a definite tart or sourness from the aroma alone. A great sour, all that tart fruit element from the aroma reflected, sour but incredibly drinkable. Palate full and crisp. The sour is excellently sour but doesnt make you pucker. Wish I had some more to drink, but thankful for what I got. Sweet sweet.

On tap.  Copper color with white head.  Intense brett character with cherry flavor.  Very tarte, acidic, and delicious.  An excellent beer that is very unique and should be regarded as a top 100 beer.

375 ml bottle courtesy of trade with mobz24 (thanks Rich), poured into a Petrus goblet-type glassware. Cloudy light brownish/copper color with a average size head that sticks around for the entire serving. Lots of bubbles rise up from the bottom of the glass. Tart vinegar aroma, in a pleasant way, with a little fruity notes as well. Very acidic tartness with some sweet cherry undertones to balance the beer. Also some woody and wine characteristics add to the wonderful complexity of this beer. 
Medium bodied and well carbonated, almost like a sparkling wine. Theres a very nice, loud pop when opening the bottle. Relatively new to sours, but this one is my favorite of the ones Ive tasted to date. Theres a pleasant wine and oak flavors that linger in the mouth long after the beer is gone leaving you wanting more.

Bottle pours orange-amber with a slightly tinted head.  Aroma is full of lactic goodness with notes cherries, white peach, lemon, oak, and a touch of brett.  Flavor shows the same with a slight creaminess that lies under the well balanced battle of sweet and sour.  Finish is dry with crisp, bright acidity.  Damn good stuff!!!

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2011 Bottle @ home, batch 7. Reddish maroon appearance with a small, off white head. Tart, red cherry, mild red wine, mild vinegar, sour, lightly bretty, oak aroma. Moderately sour, cherry, blackberry, vinegar, oaky, red wine, tangy sour flavor with a dry, cherry, vinous finish. Awesome beer!

Bottle shared with Brie and Turdferguson.  Thanks Slam!!  This is my first Russian River beer and it exceeded the hype.  In a blind taste test, I would assume this was a rare Belgian beer.  It was quite a bit sweeter than a nice Lambic, but not quite as sweet as the Flemish sours that I have had.  There was an upfront citrus hop flavor and a complex sour finish.  This was the perfect balance between sour and sweet.  It was so complex that I need to purchase a case to study it a little more.  Damn, I need to take a vacation to California.
Bottled sample from Fathers office. Should have had Piscator with me. He would have appreciated this one.  Sour ales are not my fav, so cant say to much.  Lots of flavour though.

375 ML corked and caged bottle poured into a Snifter at 42°.  Color is a deep amber with very active carbonation that keeps the floaters bouncing around and produces a thick tall head.  Aroma is sour with the scent of oak and a touch of cheery.  It has a lighter medium body with a crisp and slightly fizzy mouth feel.  Flavor of oak and wine roll out of a bold tartness then as the after taste comes on you get sour cherries that seem to give off a sweetness and on the tail end it leaves you dry.  Wow this a great brew, easy drinking and complex.  This is one of the best Sour Ales I have ever had.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2011 Rerate: sample at sour tasting.  umm yea it took awhile for me to really get this beer.  I appreciated the this well rounded sour much more this time around.  The cherry was well balanced and sour flavor was amazing.

Original rating
Bottle. 375ml. Light amber color with tons of head poured into a wine glass. Sour cherry and vinegar upfront, upon swallowing the bitter taste become more prevalent.  As it warmed, the cherrys seemed to fade away, leaving a sour/carbonated fruit flavor. somewhat like a campaign.  One was plenty for me, as the sour/wild ale flavor is still new to me.

Pours a brownish red with a thick, beige head that dissipates leaving a filmy layer at the top. Smell is of spoiled cherries, hints of oak, and earth. Taste is quite vinegary, almost too much so. Sour cherries and heavy lacto. There is a light funk and light lingering biter on the throat. Pinot very much shines through on the second sip. Finishes very dry, leaving my mouth a bit parched. Heavy alcohol burn on the swallow which is surprising for a beer of only 7%.

0.375 l bottle, thanks vode! Hazy amber color. The aromas of red berries, horse and acidic fruitiness. Acidic flavor with grapefruit, lemon and red wine with raspberry and cherry. Fairly full bodied and carbonated. Great taste which reminds kriek lambic.

Huge thanks to Jean @Moeder for sharing this gem. Clear light amber with a vanishing off-white head. Strong tart cherry aroma, mingling with some leathery woody and lacto notes. Very intriguing as for flavour, starting fruity sweet and than developing in a very long drying sour complex and lingering end.

Pours an opaque amber color.  Thick creamy head. The barrel aging infuse the flavor with wonderful chardonnay tastes and smells.  Cherries are prevalent, with a sour bite.  More like Champagne than beer,  is that possible?

Poured into tulip a hazy yellow-amber with a really nice head and good lacing. Nose of citrus and berries with a hint of wine. Sour taste is immediately present and the good amount of carbonation helps the flavor just explode in your mouth. I knew this was a good beer going in but was blown away by how much I enjoyed this as it is of a style that I have steered away from in the past. The bitter sour astringency tickles the mouth and goes down crisp and clean. I will certainly be having a second go at this one.

375 ml. bottle. Shared with Gabe. Pours a medium, beige head, over a cloudy, plum-amber (SRM 8) body....nose is acid, cherry, barnyard, stable, urine....taste is sour to start, then Brett funk, bit of cherry, grapefruit, finishing tart....mouth feel is medium, carbonation makes for a very creamy experience. This was not as interesting nor as complex as expected. BJCP 8/3/15/4/7

Not sure if theres a more perfect sour beer.  Great head, amazing aroma of cherries and wine notes.  Flavor changes as beer warms up. I wish we could buy Vinnies creations in Arizona, I have to make more friends in Northern Cal to send me more!

Bottle courtesy of Hophead22. This followed the Pliny the Elder in the tasting (after ribs and grits) and was back to back beers that absolutely blew me away. Cherry, Lemon, crabapple, and watermelon with funky earthiness that just makes you smack your lips in anticipation of more. The brett and wood combine in a lovely way to transcend the typical barrel aged phenomena to become a work of art.
Pours a chestnut brown with a reddish hue.  Nose had presence with sour cherry and vinegar.  Flavor is big on sour with cherry with a medium body,  Just exceptional.

Had this one in three different barrel aging and tasting them next to one another. So nice. Thank you Eclectic22 for providing these beers.
The first 12 mdr/batch 1, next 14 mdr/batch 3, and finaly 15 mdr/ batch 2

The official rating of these beers I have taken from the last and best one.

12mdr/batch 1
Golden orange pour with a hazy glow and a tiny edgy head. The aroma har lots of cherrys in a balanced and low key way, there are some barnyard stuff going on and some notes of strawberries. The taste is pretty bittersweet, with some cherries that seems to have been over the hill and some strawberries. Should I have guesed of the main berry in this one I would have guessed on strawberries. There is a nice touch of wood in the taste. The palate is watery and with a bitter but also pretty anonymous finish.

14 mdr / batch 3
Compared to the first one this has a much higher carbonation level and thus a much finer appearence with a frothy crown on top. It also tends to be more amber coloured. In the aroma I find more oak, some lemon and even more strawberries. The taste is more sour than the first but still rather singleminded without much complexity. The finish is longer and more sour still im missing a bit thicker palate.

15 mdr / batch 2
The pour is still getting darker which is pretty natural due to the longer barrel-aging. In the aroma the cherrys tends to balance way better with the wodden notes than the case is in the previous two bottles. Its is now not only sour but has a fine sweetness. The taste is very balanced and the berries gets way more in focus. Its more sweet and with a palate that tickles your mouth with a certain acidic feeling. The mouthfeel is less watery compared to the other two bottles. Very good beer. Thx

small bottle.  Pours muddy red brown with persistent, fizzy beige head.  Tart aroma of sour cherries, a subtle breadyness, and pinot noir is also definitely noticeable.  Notes of raspberry and brown sugar also on the nose.  Flavor delivers a blast of tart cherries, which I must say is quite dominating, although pinot noir surfaces very subtly on the finish.  It is certainly very sour and tart, yet still elegantly drinkable.  However, the overall entertainment this beer provides is comparable to other beers 1/3 of the price, although I understand alot went into creating this.  Still very glad I tried this, and i would recommend it.

Bottle (2009). Deep brown with red streaks - pretty beer in my RR "-tion glass. Nose is musty wood and sweet cherry candy, with the wild yeasts floating around. First sip - as Ive come to expect with RRs sours is completely puckeringly sour vinegar and cherries. The rest of the bottle maintains the sourness @ good levels, which complement the sweetness of the cherries and vinous acidity, though the fruit could be a littl more evident, IMO. All in all a nice beer that I want to drink again, so there you go.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2011 Rerate 8/28/11 375ml bottle from Super Jr. Market in San Diego

Orangey red body; thin beige head. This is a little spicier and spritzier than I remember from last year. Sort of similar to Averys Depuceleuse or Dyhos Dactilion. Lots of oak.

Orig. rating 9/20/10 375ml bottle @ Brouwers Cafe in Seattle

Murky chestnut body; dense medium sized light brown head, settles quickly; sticky lacing. Great aroma, clean flemish sour, cherries. Very excellent flemish sour, moderately aggressive sourness, very light cherry bitterness, wood in the background. Very good.

9 4 9 5 19 4.6

375mL bottle.  The nose on this thing is amazing.  So tart and acidic, and somewhat vinegary (in a good way).  Color is a deep, dark brown with a light brown/tan head that leaves little lacing.  The flavor follows the aroma, and by that I mean its nice and sour.  Its not mouth-puckeringly sour, though, which makes it so easy to drink.  Its definitely one of the most amazing brews Ive had.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2016 Bottle from Aug 2015, drank 12/30/16. Deep hazy Amber copper with a thin ivory cap. Deep rich and complex as hell nose with tones of red berries and funk and champagne yeast and red wine barrels. Crisp earthy tart flavor with red berries and red wine nuances, a kiss of cherry and funk and a earthy barreled finish. AMazing.

Draft at the brewery. Pretty powerful, tart sour. You get a little of the wood, cherry fruit and wine but only slightly. Not complaining, just how I see it. Also notes of the lacto and brett. This will make your mouth water for sure.

Had on draft.  Pours reddish brown with a tan head. The aroma is tart cherries with a hint of wood and alcohol. Not completely overpowering though. The taste is a mixture of sour tart fruits. The cherries do a nice job of balancing out the sourness of this beer. medium bodied with a dry finish. Once again Russian River has produced another quality sour ale.

another sour, another kickass beer from Vinnie. This one was great all around. murky light brown with everlasting tan head and lacing. tiny bubbles... the aroma and flavor are superb (and if not for the awesomeness of Consecration & Pliny, this would be RRs best beer). Complexities of oak, cherries, funk, tartness in the aroma. the feel is great too, due to the lacto. flavor...superb. sour, oak, cherries, a hint of the pinot...this is a superb beer all the way around."

Bottle. Would be most expensive beer Ive ever bought if I hadnt also bought Consecration the same day. Trying to get into the sour ales ... puffy one-finger head dies away quickly. Aroma is almost a sensory assault. Paint, wood, a musty old house come to mind. Wet dog, wet leaves and Lancaster County. Cherry pie. Sweet but almost puckeringly sour on the tongue. A little fizzy, very fruity. Bitterness works its way in there too. Its interesting, definitely, and  Im glad to be working on this sour ale trend, but so far, the emperor has no clothes.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2010 On tap, this brown ale pours an amber reddish color with a bubbly tan head. The aroma is the spontanous yeast smell of the strains used with notes of sweetness from the cherries pleasantly overall rounding it out. There are banana notes as well. The flavor of a Flemish sour brown but with a lighter body is what I taste. The cherry notes, although not sweet, come in smoothly and settle well on the palate with just the right amount of tart to complement it.

Bottle served in a tulip. Pours clear, deep brown-orange with amber hues. Short light beige head that settles and sticks. Minimal lacing. Aroma is sour with some apple vinegar and light cherry sweetness. The brews heavy sour flavor is followed by prickly carbonation and increasing sour astringency. Medium body, oily texture, and a very long, dry finish. Its not too sweet but has a lot of acidity following the attack. This could work well with food at this point, and would benefit from cellaring for a year.

(375ml bottle from Weber St Liquor, sampled 3/9/10). Copper color with light cloudiness and suspended particles. Medium off white head w/ good retention. Moderate sour aroma, with light vinegar. Moderate sour flavor, with light sweetness. Avg duration. Lasting sour finish with light dryness. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.
375 ml. bottle.  Another world class beer from russian river.  hazy reddish brown, med. head.  cherries come through nice with great sour taste,  Awesome beer.

Bottle, with massive thanks to piscator34! This is number 700! Pours clear amber/orange, thin off-white head, ropey lacing. Nose is huge tartness, where are the cherries? Who. The. Fuck. Cares?  Damn, this is really, a perfect balance of tartness, light fruitiness, and a lingering, tingling vinosity. Flavours are tight oak tannin, and mild vinousness, light soapiness, plus tight acidity and rich warm acidity, like sinking into a hot bath. Mmmmmm... So much going on here.So spicy, with acid, vinous fruit, stale, vinegar, God this rocks. I am divided on the Top 50, I either feel the beer is horrendously overrated, or, like in this case, a mere Top 50 list could not possibly do it justice. Kickass.

Smells like crazy brett and sour beer. Hazy and orangey, bubbly, it does remind me of Orval. This says brown ale but its sour as hell!  for a regular beer. Sweet, sour, bitter, this is some beer! Crabapple, but not too, too sour, it is great!

Pours hazy yellow with a thin head. Funky sour aroma.tones of brett. Flvour is super funky and sour. Tastes great. Sour complex bold and drinkable. This is a.fantastic sour beer. It has everythng i  want in a sour without being quelling. It reminds.me of the crab apples in my back yard.

375ml bottle, batch 04x5.  Pours a clear reddish copper with a medium creamy white head that retains well and laces the glass.

The aroma is a little subdued but very nice - sweet and tart cherries with some wood and a touch of alcohol.

The flavor is a huge punch of sour tart fruits.  After getting accustomed to the sourness, some sweet cherries and wood comes out.  It has a dry finish with some sharp sour notes.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied and slightly sharp.

Overall, this is one of the sourest beers Ive had and one of the best sours.  Its very nice - the sweet cherries help balance the sourness and make it interesting.  I picked up very little Brett, more could be interesting.  This is even more intense in the bottle than when I had it on draft.  A bit of an expensive treat at $13 a bottle.

A few bottles shared by the legendary footbalm, thanks! 
Appearance: Poured a brownish amber with a small white head, no lacing 
Aroma: Tart fruits and sweet malts 
Taste: Taste cherries and other fruits, finished like a dry wine 
Very nice and refreshing.

Had with James and Katie. Pour is a deeper copper with some little while head. Sour cherries overwhelm the nose in the aroma. Some aromas of the wine still resonate. Flavor is full of the sweet and sour cherry and yeast.

Great blend of lacto and brett in the nose, juicy tart cherries.  Orange amber, small fleeting white head.  Goodness.  Tannic fruit, sharp with the wood, love the wine barrel.  Intense in the jaw with the first sip, more fruit comes out as my palate adjusts.  Lovely.

Wine like aroma, a bit sweet. Then you get a bit of the funk. Pours a nice amber with a lacing creamy head. The flavor is fruity sweet and then quite sour. Extremely smooth and clean for so sour a beer. Finishes perfectly dry with a very nice lingering taste.

(375ml bottle).  Pours amber color with thin white head.  Aroma is tart cherries, slight wine and funk.  Taste is sour with hints of cherry sweetness.  Lighter bodied with sticky texture.
