Carbonation is prickly on the tongue.  The finish is sour, but also semi-dry which comes from the Pinot Noir barrels.  This is a nice beer  that is easy to drink.

Good stuff
Sour, aroma of cherry medium body, lively, funky, dy-no-mite
Bottled from Liquor Mart in Boulder

Corked & Caged 375 ml Bottle. Aroma is tart and funky with that signature barnyardy wild yeast smell and just a hint of sour cherries. Appearance is an amber honey color with a half-inch of creamy white head and ridiculously thick lacing patterns around the glass. The taste begins with an onslaught of intense sourness and tart cherry flavors followed by bready malt, cranberries, citric acid and earthy yeast. Theres also a very faint woody oak flavor that lingers in the background. Mouthfeel is tart and acidic with low carbonation. It finishes with champagne-like dryness and a final burst of puckering sourness. The overall flavor is extremely well-balanced with a complex array of tart fruit and aggressive sourness.

Bottle obtained in trade from pantanap.  This, without a doubt, is the sour that all others should be rated against.  What is the point of giving the specifics; the reputation speaks for itself.  Simply fantastic, and most worthy of its top 100 in the world rating!!

Draft at the Memphis Tap Room in Philly.  Another incedible beer from RR.  Funky, sour, tart with tart fruit.  The Brett is alive and well in this one.  At happy hour, this beer was $4 each!!?   Are you kidding me?

Pours clear rich brown, with a large beige head, very fine clinging lacing.  Aromas of cherry, fig, wood, leather, toast, spice with a mild farmyard note.  Medium body, tart, velvety and smooth.  Strong sour flavor right from the start, a little sweet, medium sour mid-palate, with a lasting mild sour finish.  A sour delight.

375 ml caged and corked from Bier Stein. Pours a light brown with some hints of garnet and a nice bubbly head. Smells of funk, lots of cherries, light raspberry and peach. Flavor of light funk, big cherries, raspberry, yeast, vinous notes. All in all an excellent sour flavor and a very smooth drinker. Another excellent sour ale from the boys in Santa Rosa.
Draft: amber color, nice sour aroma, taste is sour but not overpowering, very nice

(bottle - corked & caged 375 ml) Got this one in a trade. What a treat. Reddish brown pour with a thick and lasting off-white head. Big sour and tart aroma with lots of that wonderful bacteria funk. Some light fruit sweetness but tons of sour. Flavor starts off with a bitey and sour funk with some mild fruit sweetness, couldnt really tell if it was cherries or not, and moves to a lip-puckering sour and tart finish. A lingering sour and fruity aftertaste comes in at this point. Wonderful.

Bottle Batch 005X5.  Aroma has notes of sour cherries, wood, caramel malts, red wine, sour funk, lemons and green apples.  Medium reddish brown hue with an average sized off-white foamy head that mostly diminished and left a little lace.  Flavor is medium sweet and heavy sour.  Palate is medium/light bodied, slick, lively carbonation and astringent.  Very good with a nice level of complexity as it warms.  Love the well balanced fruitiness the sweet malt and sour tartness.  Sublime!

who wants to lick the spoon?? .. . thanks to Tom for the opportunity... Pours a hazy gold amber .. . great wisps of white foam, some lacing .. . http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=whuhM8AtJcA  .. . delicious beer, with some insane quirks.. . from wet oak, cherry skins, and beyond .. . RR gold! ..
Tart cherry and brutal sour aroma. Refreshing sour taste with clean finish. Medium body.  Nice.

Aroma:Tart with a little vinegar. There is some mustyness in the aroma.

Appearance:Deep amber. Tons of white frothy head. Behind the sourness lies a nice sweetness.

Taste:This tastes like a tart cherry sour patch kid.

Palate:Tart and puckery, with some alcohol warmth.

Overall:An amazingly drinkable sour beer.
At brewery.  Pours clear amber with some carbonation bubbles.  Tastes of sour cherries, like cherry wine.  Absolutely scrumptious.  One of the most interesting offerings Ive had yet.  Delicious!

I love sour beers. If I loved this as a sour beer it would have been rated even higher. It was good, very tart, some interesting flavors, peat and other old wood, green fruit, and something that reminds me of fruitcake. Just not the right kind of sour somehow. . . Still I would not pass up another.

Thanks to ericandersnavy for this one! 
Pours a hazy amber with fizzy off-white head. Aroma of brett and sour with very faint old wood. Flavor of brett, very sour, dry, with very faint hints of cinnamon and/or nutmeg, faint aged wood, sour cherry and acidic. Mouth feel is light-medium body with fizzy carbonation. Overall, a damned good beer! Thanks Eric.

Draught at the Whiskey Bar, Seattle. 
Reddish amber color with a superfine off-white head and tons of rising little bubbles. Hugely tart aroma with sour cherries, caramel, yogurt, a touch of vanilla and some vinegar. Big sour lactic, yogurt flavor with caramel, cherry. Nice. Has a too sweet edge that keeps it from the top levels of this style, but its very good stuff. There is a bit of harsh cardboard in the finish, maybe from the pips, that is slightly unpleasant. A very good, though not great, cherry sour.

Bottle shared at the release of CDC batch 4. Nice clear orange body with a quickly dissipating foamy white head. Aroma is not as sour as I was expecting and seemed more acidic and vinegar with some notes of cardboard as well. The flavor is slightly more tart and sour then the aroma. Solid beer but I still found the sour of the day to be the 2 1/2 year old La Folie hands down.

Batch 005X3 from Hi Time Wine Cellars.  An amazing way to follow up last weeks Stone Sour Fest and an absolutely wonderful beer that Ive had many times, but never rated.  Pours with a reddish brown hue, fine carbonation, and slight tan head which dissipates quickly.  Nose is mostly cherries, pinot, brett, lactic acid, and sour vinegar.  Taste is perfectly balanced sourness with lots of cherries, plums, oak, wine, vinegar and citrus.  Finishes perfectly with lingering fruits and oak.  I just love this stuff.

Clear red-amber color. No head at all. Very faint aroma of sour fruit and yeast. Not overly sour, the taste of the pinot noir shows through and compliments the flavor of the beer well. Lemon and Cherry notes. A bit harsh on the palate, I think in a good way.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2012 On tap at Bobby Gs.  5/17/12.  Batch 10.  Pours a reddish brown amber with a small white head settles to a ring and leaves some very light lacing on the glass. The aroma has lots of lactic acid.  Cherry, funky earthiness, slight hop presence, and a hint of acetic acid.  The taste is tart with a light initial sweetness. Lots of lactic, decent amount of cherry, and just a bit of brett funkiness. The finish is tart and drying with a bit of acetic acid.  Medium body. Medium carbonation.  Certainly one of the best regularly available sours.

Got this one as an unsolicited gift from jale (thanks again!)...

Pours a nice cloudy orange/amber color.  Decent amount of head that lingers and leaves spotty lacing around the glass.

Aroma is excellent. Strong waves of super tart cherry overpower everything - this effect is even more prevalent once you take a taste.  Very lush and bubbly, it feels nice swishing around your mouth with each sip.  The super tart nature of this makes it hard for me to drink alot of, but it is excellent nonetheless.

Not a big fan of sours or wild ales, but I would definitely drink this again if I get the chance.

Bottle - Pours rosy amber with a very small white head. Red wine, dry and yeasty and with a little funk dominates the nose. Taste is tons of citrus sour, with lots of lemon and orange rind. Sweet Tart in the middle, with a dry finish that doesnt linger too long. Carbonated nicely, with a decent amount of body. Great stuff!
Bottle @ Erik och Filip. Pours Brown/Red with tan head. Aroma- Cherries, Red berries, Sour, Sweet, Smooth. Taste- Cherries, Sweet, Sour, Grapefruit, Woody, Brett Long sour aftertaste.

Bottle.  Batch 04x3.  Pours a murky reddish brown with a frothy light tan colored frothy head.  Aroma reminds me slightly of New Glarus barels, woody, super oaky, cherry, lactic, rounder than other vintages.  Flavor follows, very oaky, medium tart sourness, really does remind me a lot of New Glarus in this instance, just a touch nutty, the wine aftertaste is quite nice, just a hint of bitterness.  Medium/light bodied, nice fine sizzling carbonation.   Great beer, a little better than the other 04s Ive had, that were not very sour, but not nearly as good as the batch 2.

Bottle shared by rudolf with myself and IPFreely. Amberish color topped by a thin white head. Lovely aroma full of hay, barnyard, lemon, and cherries. Great sourness, some lemon-lime like notes, and stone fruits. Pleasant acidity and lively carbonation. Lingering cherry flavors. Excellent
0.375l Batch 005xl - Red/brown liquid, fizzy appearance, no head.  Sour nose, grapefruit and roses.  Brett laden front, almost a buttery note.  This is an extraordinary BEvERage.

#1900, Shared with Tim & Jacob.  Orangey copper body, nice tan head.  Nose is acidic lemon grapes, lemony brett, wood, bitter orange.  Flavor is acidic - lemons, lemonade, wood, cherries.  Quite tart.  A bit of sweetness & balsamic comes out in the finish.  Wonderful stuff!

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2011 375ml batch 04X1.  This might just be my favorite sour by RR.  This sour solder is orange/amber in color with a small head.  The old cake whole is inundated with tart and sour cherries, light fruit, oak, funk, and brett.

375, 04x3. As the cork pops theres a quick burst of cherry aroma, followed by a little must. Pours nice orangey-red, a bit hazy, with a foamy white head and already nice lacing, even before I drink any of it. Nose is bretty, wet oak, tart cherries, sweet wine. On the first sip, the flavor is strongly sour, and not a lot else. After a few sips, though, this beers complexity really shines through. It begins with a tart attack, then evolves into big bretty flavor with a sort of hovering cherry note. Dry as a fuckin bone, especially at the finish. I almost feel like this beer is as much about the dryness as the sourness, and theres certainly a multiplicative effect that makes the whole experience like a big punch in the mouth - a very enjoyable one, though. Definitely among the best sours Ive had, and its particularly impressive from an American brewery. Absolutely lives up to the hype.

[2980-20100627] Tap. Sour yeast aroma has mild plastic notes and a little fruity cherry. Slightly hazy, dark orange amber body with a long-lasting creamy off-white head. Sour fruity yeast flavour has a long sour cherry aftertaste. Medium body is fairly sour. Was expecting even more sourness but is pretty good.
(@ Belmont Station, Portland, OR)

This has to be one of my favorite, slightly more available sours. What a beautiful looking beer first of all. Aroma is great. Sour, sweet, fruity. SOme grapes, cherries, wine, wood and funk. Flavor is tart, sweet and sour candy, prickly cherry pie and red wine. Nice brett character and finishes dry and smooth. Lovely every time.

Batch 003. Perhaps just a little too sour, but wonderful... just wonderful. Ive been saving this back to enjoy with friends and family on a hot summer afternoon and got the chance this past Sunday. What a delicious brew, though I enjoyed the temptaion batch 003 that I had right before this just a little bit more. Wonderful, wonderful brew!

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Batch 003
A: Brown body with reddish hints. small off white head, little lacing.

S: Sour cherries, oak, apple cider, slightly wine-like in feel.

T: This is the epitome of wine smoothness and beer complexity. Sour and tart fruits up front, with a hint of bitterness. Lots of cherry flavors. Some wine like acidity from the barrel aging. Delicious.

M: Smooth. Flavors seamlessly transition on the tongue. The tart and sourness is not overwhelming, but distinctive enough to make this beer special.

O: I had no problem putting this bottle down... Russian Rivers most consistently impressive offering.

In the bottle on 11/13/09. Pours a hazy reddish amber with a big explosive foamy white head. The head rapidly thins to a small sheen. This beer is very much a kriek. Theres lots of acidity and cherries to the aroma. The flavor is very sour. This has an intense acidity. Theres a strong oakiness to the beer. A real saving grace is the little blast of candy sweetness at the finish. The beer is too complex for me to understand.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2013 bottle batch 04x1 poured an amber in color with a thin cover of white foam. aroma has nice funkyness, red grapes, wet barrel wood, cherry tartness, and acidity on the lower side. mouth feel has a bit of substance with light prickly carbonation. flavor gets started with funk, wet red grapes, sour cherry, and a growing dryness as the glass goes on. quite a nice beer that hits both on the funky and fruity sides .

Bottle 375ml thanks to mikesgroove. Beautiful orange/brown body with tons of white browinish lacing. Aroma of fresh butter, vinegar, tart cherries, rotten apples. Wow, this is complex. Taste is quite different. At first, its very sour with tart cherries. Then I get some apple/grape sweetness and oak flavors. It finishes with a lemony dry and sour lingering finish. Palate is hard to describe, it is both dry from the sourness yet it also has something sticky sweet about it too.A truly unique experience.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2012 I think I was on drugs the first time I rated this...awesome stuff.  Pours dark red, almost purple, some white head.  Very tart, funky in the nose and palate, but its not bitter....drinkability is high.  Carbonation is moderate, not too high.  Finish is dry and lingering.

(375ml Bottle - Batch 004) Pours an amber color with an off white head. Smell is tart cherries, funk, oak, and vanilla. Taste is sour cherries, oak, and some funk. Medium mouthfeel, good carbonation. Overall this is a great sour.

Tap @ brewery.  Clear, deep amber body with an off-white head of Med/small size, sheets of lace.  Fruity aroma (sparkling apple cider, pgrape) mixed with rotting leaves, oak, malty.   Medium-ish body with nice, soft Carb.  Flavor is almost sweetly fruity (apple, caramel), but lmost balanced yet puckering and sour with oak, citrus.  Its really like a traditional brown ale, but very sour.

Damn tasty brew.  Pours a lighter amber color with a thick white foam head.  Has an aroma of vinegar and cherries.  Has a frothy mouthfeel.  Has a sour taste with some bitters and notes of cherries.  Really enjoyed this.

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle. 

Batch 004x1. The beer pours a clear orange color with a white head. The aroma is a lot of tart cherries with some oak. The flavor is tart cherries, vanilla and some oak. The beer is dry but not as dry as Sanctification. The cherries really make this an excellent beer. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

375ml bottle courtesy of ericandersnavy.  Pours a cloudy, light amber body with an effervescent fizzyness.  Leaves windowpane lacing all along the glass.  Aroma is funky, sour, white wine, tartness and a certain "wow" factor.  The flavor is nearly ripe bing cherries, funk, red wine sour and a light sweetening towards the finish.  Medium to active carbonation that made my mouth water.  Id like to get my hands on more of this.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2010 Bottle. I have had this several times and every time it just amazes me. A perfect balance of sour and tartness. Pours a brownish orange tinged color with a tannish head. The aroma is a mix of the funk and sourness, I think the sourness edges out the funk by a little bit. Excellent mouthfeel with a good amount of carbonation. This is a beer I keep searching for cheaper and less expensive substitutes for. Truly amazing. Im glad I stocked up with plenty in the cellar!
Batch 5x003 (8/1/10): Opened a bottle after the cork looked like it wanted to really shoot off. Only the cage was holding this together. Poured a hazy, rust color with a nice fluffy head. Sour notes abound in the nose. The taste is much more funky than I recall in past batches. Light mouthfeel. Still outstanding.
Batch 4: doesnt seem as sour and tart as the other batches I have had so far.

Batch 04x4. 375ml corked and caged bottle. Served in a Tank 7 tulip. Poured a clear dark gold with two fingers of fine bubbled, white head. Lots of carbonation, effervescent. Great aroma with tart cherries and some brett. Light bodied and fairly dry. Very tart flavor with more fruit. Some of the barrel flavors came through in the finish.
Very unique and complex beer.

Bottle at Peters 2nd annual spring gathering.  Batch 4.  Orangey with head and lace.  Tart fruit and leather aroma.  Peachy sour barnyard hay wood leather with dry finish.  Complex and insanely delicious.

Courtesy of Nate.  Pours amber with fizzy white head.  Great sour nose, wine grapes, horse blanket, spice, pepper, lemon juice.  Taste of lemon and caramel, sour and dry with mild spice, pepper, dry as all get out.  Just awesome.   Thanks, Nate!

On draft at RRBC. Brown with ruby edge, slightly hazy and beige compact halo. Aroma is tart fruit, some musky notes and sugar or muted maple. Integrated flavors of dark fruit, cherry and supple leather notes. So well-integrated that the contributions of he malt, fruit and bugs are indecipherable from eachother. Lean body (fits right between Temptation and Consecretation)  with satisfying tartness that dries out further in finish.

From stefanje via trade.  The pour was a hazy brownish copper color with a thin layer of fizzy white bubbles.  The aroma was tart cherries and a bit of funk with some oak coming through as it warmed.  The flavor was sour cherry and oak with a minimal amount of funk, some earth and very little of the Pinot Noir coming through.  Thin, dry, drinkable and delicious.  Very good stuff.

Location: 375 ml bottle from NickD717, 5/24/10


Aroma: The nose of this one is full of funky/sour cherries, with some wine notes, and some booze

Appearance: It pours a quite hazy caramel-red color with a fluffy beige head that leaves lots of lace on the glass

Flavor: The taste also has quite a bit of tart cherry, a touch of mild sweetness, and some yeast flavors too

Palate: Its medium-full bodied, theres something very wine-like about the body, and theres a slightly boozy feel

Overall Impression: 
This one is quite sour.  It almost makes the mouth pucker, but it does so while still providing a nice flavorful drink.  As I watch the end of Jack Bauers run as the greatest bad ass in the history of television, I drink this wonderful beer.  Something so sour serves as a reminder that we all soured on this show a bit over the last few years, but well still miss it.  It was exceptional at one point.  Just like this beer, it is was special at one time.  A great beer celebrates the final hours of a great show. Tick, tick, tick, tick...

Pours a nice brown with a small off white head. Aroma is sour cherries, lactic, some of the base brown ale and a touch of the wine barrel. Flavor is sour cherries done just right, lactic and acidic, the base beer has been totally transformed, some oak and finishes puckery. Fantastic brew.

Bottle. Batch 4x3.

Murky orange/red/brown color with a big off-white head that leaves plenty of lacings. 

The smell is fairly blurry with a prominent oak character and notes of sweet cherries, grass, mud and brett. Nice acidicty. 

The taste is full of events. Sweet malty cherries and malts up front quickly handing over to a prominent sourness coupled with grass, lemon, minerals and vinegar. A mild bitterness develops towards the finish as the beer ends with nice cherry flavors, oak and a very mild funkiness. 

Medium body and velvety smooth but dry finish. 

A nice one. Very impressive composition. Quite reminiscent of a sparkling fruity wine.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2010 375mL bottle, Batch 04, 3rd bottling.  Pours a translucent amber with a slight tinge of red and a finger of white head.  Aroma is intensely sour, with lots of oak, funk, and a bit of tart cherry.  Taste is a fantastic balance of sourness, tart cherries, oak, and funk.  The tart fruit adds to the flavor and complexity without dominating.  Awesome beer.   edit, august 2010, batch 2,3,4,5 vertical.  4 is the best, followed by 5, 3, then 2.  2 is the most acidic, 3 has a mediocre aroma but makes up for it with the flavor.

The smell is sour, cherries, fruits, funk, complex, and good. The look is clear, copper in color, with a beige colored head.  The taste is tart, nice dry sourness, wood, funk, and fruit. Nice feel and finish.

Bottle of Batch 4 tasted at Peters RBSG. Pours a deep n dark burnt orange with minimal white head. Aroma is rich of pinot noir grapes, brett, lemon, and maraschino cherries. It all blends together perfectly; just a joy to sniff. Sour cherry flavor is at the forefront, and theres an excellent balance of brett, oak, and cranberry in the back. Slight club soda finish with moderately heavy tartness. Now THATS what Im talking about! A masterpiece in complexity, balance, and straight-out deliciousness.

Bottle from ajm.  Thanks man!  Poured surprisingly dark and somewhat reddish.  Had a soft aroma with light sour features.  Surprisingly light nose compared to the taste.  Light cherry taste, tannins, pleasantly thin.  Thin mouthfeel .  Great brew.
Bottle. Amber-orange colour with a beige head. Aroma is sourness, brett, lemon, caramel. Flavour is sour, brett, berries, lemon, caramel. Complex beer.

Tried at Stones first annual Oakquinox in April 2010.  Pours a brown-amber with tiny white head.  Aroma of funk, barnyard, tart vinegar, and light cherry and citrus.  Flavor of subtle cherry and citrus.  Its tart but not overly so and very nicely balanced for a sour.  Finishes with a nice refreshing tartness.  (649, 292)

Draft @ EBF and bottled. Bottle had in comparison to 9 month old Red Poppy. This was young and still very nice, brune pour some head. Nice yeast, funky sour, with sour cherry notes, and some attributes from the wine barrel.

Beautiful muddy reddish brown pour with very carbonated creamy white head. Nose is sour cherry, musty grape and cedar. Taste is very sour grape, cedar, pinot noir, oaks and smoked cherry. Slight dry finish from the ever present head.

Bottle from Iowaherkeye. Pours clearish orange with red hues.  Funky brett and pediococcus notes make up most of the aroma with a good amount of cherry.  The smell made my salivavary glands fire.  Flavor is even more sour than I expected; made me pucker slightly, but in a good way.   There is the sweetness and cherry and some mild bitterness in the finish and some funky barnyard flavor.  Very good to have this again.  Thanks Joey!

Liquid Sunshine X  Olympia, WA  
Bright orange in color with a thick aroma of pinot noir and sour cherry.  Big malt flavors also linger as this beer develops it brings out even more flavors and aromas.  Lots of yeast flavors linger and in the finish.   This was quite exquisite.

Yet again, footbalm straight thuggin.  Thanks, man.  What a super fun brew to drink!  Sharp as a knife, smells like teen spirit.  Im not gonna lie- the sour kick in the dick is downright titillating.  The End.
Little I can add to the reviews.  Wonderful sour and on par with Red Poppy (but slightly less fruity).  Puckers your lips in the best way.

Ive tried other Belgian sours and this is by far the best Ive tasted so far. I had it on tap at Russian River Brewing in Santa Rosa. The taste was tart and clean, no "barnyard" odor or taste (as some Belgians Ive had). Tart cherry with a hint of red wine from the aging barrel. Very clean on the palate and left me wanting more. If not for the cost, this would be in my spare refrigerator at all times!

Well, I was going to save this for my 100th beer - but, I couldnt wait.  Bottle supplied by my brother-in-law (from Oakland) for a belated X-mas present.  Trying to provide any details on this would be an insult.  Probably one of the top five beers Ive ever had - probably not as good as the Consecration, but it was UNBELIEVABLE!    Like crack, I want more.

Pours a slightly cloudy reddish brown into the glass with bright highlights.  Aromas of tart cherry and plums.  Flavor is a burst of intense sourness delivered nicely by the carbonation with a  bit of fruitiness and oak.  Very soft malt flavors stay on the tongue as it dries out on the finish.

Pours a dark brown with a mild head. Nice sweet cherry smell with a oak hints. Taste like sour cherries, with an oaky floral finish. Overall an excellent beer one the worls best. Thanks to Freddy from beverages4less for shipping.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2010 To try to describe this is pretty much pointless. Its awesome stuff, to say the least. There is a perfect mix of flavors and textures, winey notes, fruity notes, funk and wood, all masterfully blended. I wish I had more. Thanks to michael-pollack for the trade! Batch 04X2

Bottle, 37.5cl, #003. Its an almost clear beer, dark golden in color and with a dense, off-white head sitting on top. In addition to lambic-like barnyard and lemon notes, theres a lot of berries on the nose. The flavor is pretty much the same, even more pleasant, with a touch of brown-ale like caramel and roasted malts as a slightly hidden foundation. Medium body, almost astringent on the palate, and quite fizzy. The finish has both caramel notes in the back, barnyard and lemon doing the main work, and some alcohol chiming in, giving a certain warmth. A really lovely and complex beer. 091127

Loud popping cork, Beautiful Burnt Sienna pour with a small tight offwhite head.  Aroma wafts up to me from the glass, sour cherry, peach and mango sweetness, vanilla, sour , soft, dry wood, a flutter of acetic acid.  Flavor is sour cherry, puckering with vinegar, waves of sweet peach and sour cherry laced with vanilla wood.  Nice barrel tannins soften this to a rich velvety bruin.

A: Copper with a thin white frothy head.

S: Very nice aroma and pungent. Sour with a touch of phenols. Apples and spice with some sweetness and an underlying woody / mushroomy note.

T: Sweet and sour up front fading to a spiciness and finishing dry and woodsy. Alcohol starts to come through at the finish. Theres definitely a tanin note from the wine barrell againg.

M: Thick and smooth with perfect carbonation.

D: Great

O: This is unique and delicious. Proof that if you take the care in brewing a beer you would in creating a fine wine, the results can be just as mind blowing.

375 ml bottle from South Bay Drugs.  Batch 004x2.  Pours a cloudy reddish plum brown color with a thick beige head.  Aroma of Brett and other wild yeasts right out of the gate, with notes of cherries, oak, syrup, and even some vanilla.  The flavor shares that complexity, and it all comes together so softly and smoothly.  Notes of cherry, wood, cola syrup, and malts go nicely with the acidic nature of this.  Sweet, tart, and surprisingly easy on the palate.  This is a great beer.  I had super high hopes for it, and it didnt blow me away completely but absolutely delivered.  Im actually surprised at my decent notes on this one, given how late in a long session I had it.  Cant wait to try more Russian River sours.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2010 Draft pour at Choice City Deli is mostly clear amber/orange. Aroma of unripe fruit, spice, floral, molasses and tart berries. Taste is quite a kick in the face, mouth stripping sourness but after the first taste its not so abrasive. Medium body, great beer.

Batch 003. 375 ml poured into my snifter. I am consuming this as I review it.

A- Body is a very hazy IPA-like amber hue. Pours with a nice, bubbly 1-2 finger head that immediately subsides to a thick collar and has great retention from there. Cloudiness is thick and mostly uniform with some dynamic yeast sediment floating around at the bottom.

S-The first thing that comes to the nose is slightly sour with a big accent on vinegar but a slightly acidic sourness as well. Behind this is sweet orange, exotic fruit, and a hint of cherry as well as a hint of vanilla and oak.

T- Slightly salty flavor upfront accompanied by a slight vinegar sourness. Behind this is some oak and a slight presence of exotic fruit but the cherry is a bit hard to detect. More oak and perhaps cherry pits come through for the finish as the initial sourness and saltiness wears off. What lingers is the remnants of oak and cherry flavors as well as a slight acidic bitterness.

P-High tingly carbonation and medium weight body. Body is not crass but does have a slightly acidic tone to it.

O- This is another great sour from RR. Not as good as their other sours that I have tried, IMO...but still a very very good sour. This one has a bit more of a vinegar presence than the others but is still a very good, well done beer. I am looking forward to Consecration and their other beers that I have not tried yet.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-11-2009 01:28:32

Batch 04X3: Wow, I continue to be amazed by high quality sours. My first "real" sour was at a WSB meeting. Matt sampled something I had never tasted before, and now I am in a whole new world of beer. Supplication is one such beer, uterly smooth, tart, sour, and complete. I would recommend this beer to anyone who wants to come over to the sour side, as this one is IMO the epitome of a well made sour. Yes you can taste the oak, but it is very subtle. Cherries much more present, but not overwhelming in the least. This is a well balanced beer and I am looking forward to tasting it again in a year. Tasted from the bottle @ 45°F.

Batch #04X3 courtesy of Eric at Tims tasting. Smells of cinnamon, apples and cherry with a touch of allspice. Looks like apple cider - cloudy and deep orange, but tastes of sour cherries with a wine undertone. Also reminds me of Sweet Tarts without the sweet.

A lot of people consider this a benchmark for American Sours, and its a pretty tough one to live up to.  Aroma is moderately tart cherries with a strong brett presence, making me curious how funky this beer can get with some age on it.  First drop hits the tongue and is lightly sour with a strong cherry presence, extremely creamy mouthfeel, perhaps the best Ive ever tried in this department. On the back end, the beer has a notched up sourness, perhaps an 7/10 if 10 were Old Growth, and some slight oak notes to accentuate the sour cherries.  A bit like a high quality vinegar.  Overall, an exceptional beer that I actually find unremarkable in comparison to some of the other RR Sours.

This is probably the sourest beer Ive ever tasted. Prominent sour cherry flavors, vinous and spicy aroma, and a texture that catches in the back of the throat. It might have been too much for me, but Ive decided that it makes an excellent summer sipper.

Batch #4.Pours a almost clear red with a light fizzy head.Nose is amazing with cherries and wine.Taste is remarkable with cherries,oaky pinot noir and lemons,The mouthfeel and finish are outstanding as well.This is an awakening for me as far as beers go.I have never experienced a beer like this but it has moved to the top of my list instantly.I have never given a perfect score but this is close...
UPDATED: AUG 1, 2014 Bottle at Teressa.  Rich sour cherries and vinegar.  Long finish def notice the Pinot nior.  Perfect carbonation

Rating number 1800. Bottle of batch 4 courtesy of Wavers1, and a bonus no less.  Ive had this a couple times before, but never a full bottle (though I have a batch 3 around somewhere from another generous RBer) to myself.  Pours a crimson and orange hued amber, with the faintest touch of haze, and a medium to large dense and creamy ecru head.  The soft funky notes hit just from opening the bottle and pouring.  Closer to it, it gains even more intensity, spicy funk, soft chewy cherries and vanilla, and a nice clean brett profile. Amazingly soft and gentle, slow moving and delicate.  Nice acid, nothing bracing, very lovely. Little bits of cherry and a light sweet note. Dry wood and slow tart acid on the finish.  Just so incredibly subtle and complex.  Thanks again baker, this was great.

Pours a cloudy dark reddish amber with a nice off-white head.  Nose and taste of this are similar - big sourness, cherries, citrusy hops, oak.  Finish is very long and sour with fruity notes.  A big, complex, and well-balanced beer.  Great sour.  If only it cost less.

Intensely honest aroma lays out the path--you know whats coming. Ruddy amber and subtle fizzy bubbles. Malt and tart cherries sneak in and then explode on the palate - f yeah. A tingling mouth watering experience.

mild, bright, sour cherry aroma -- very wine-y, with dry wood and lots of cherry juice.
blurry red-orange-brown, thin frothy beige head.
sour fruit flavor, with a long, dry wood, yeast and deliciousness finish. just enough cherry to make it juicy.
medium thin, slightly sticky.

Wow, this is a unique beer!  Pouring a slightly murky orange/brown with a wispy white head.  The wine barrel aging is apparent in the first rush of flavor.  A wine tinged, woody flavor comes through.  The sour flavor is next which is a mix of the sour cherries and the Brett sourness.  Im not a big Brett fan, but this is well balanced and not overpowering.   This beer has a real personality that is strong but not too over the top.   Ill be coming back for Supplication!

Tasted from 375mL bottle at Lush CBC event, Batch004.  Pours amber brown with a thin white head.  Aromas of sour cherry, brett, grenadine, and burnt rubber.  Flavors are sour with brett, featuring red fruit on back of palate, and green apple front palate.  Carbonation is lively with a medium body and a long fruity finish.  This beer is super drinkable and very complex.

Bottle. Murky golden with a white head that diminished to nothing. Huge complex nose of tobacco, oak, brett, wine, tart cherry and yeast. Flavour is the beez neez of that same character - very oaky, tart cherry, vinous, earth and hint of smoke. Gorgeous balance. Not overly tart and finishes with this awesome lingering fruity and woody finish. Yes this is sensational. Cheers to who brought this along.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2011 Sampled at RBWG 2010.  The aroma is huge oak and Belgian yeast.  The flavor is big sour with citrus and so much more. Awesome stuff! Re-rate 8/26/11. 375mL bottle thanks to darn1207! Hazy amber pour with a small khaki head that fades to a ring but sticks. Oak, spice, tannins, and tart berries on the aroma. Ohhhh, awesome flavor. Oak, tannins, huuuuge sourness, tart cherries, and delicious subtle pie spices. Damn this is good! Up 0.1 (added a point for "overall")
From 375ml,golden, frothy, medium sweetness, medium sourness, The best sour beer your can get.

On Draft at Union Jacks Hop fest today. Pours a light brown with pronounced carbonation for the first 15 minutes or so. I let this warm up for about 30 min. The nose has lacto funk and slight vinegar, first sip is sour with mild rice wine vinegar flavor but transitions to the slight cherry and malt flavor I taste before the tart finish. Another great beer by Vinnie.

375ml Bottle. Batch 04X2.  Respectable pop with a heavy layer of slowly rising CO2.  Has a medium orange color with a quarter inch layer of fizz.  Nose is dry with hints of cherries, wood and musty Brett funk.  Flavor is almost sweet upfront with delicate cherry notes that are quickly overwhelmed by a tart vinegar character.  The sourness is drool inspiring and lingers in the roof of your mouth.  Carbonation is lively and stronger than most Ive had in this style.  Body is thin and showcases the sour aspects from the Lacto and Pedio additions.  Ends on a long dry sour note that leaves you craving the next sip.  Definitely a world class sour and one of my favorites from Russian River.

Pours a brownish amber with some haze, and beautiful white head that rose with little effort on the pour.  Nose has a fruit dessert-like aroma with a little lime.  On the palate theres plenty of vinegary passion fruit, sweet malt, wile sour flavors, and a tangy sweet fruity finish.  Incredibly easy drinking for the style, and no unpleasant aspects of the barnyard-ish character.
Thanks to Ericandersnavy.  Outstanding beer!  Very sour, call it sour cherries on steroids.  Still a pleasant sip and as good as it gets for a Belgian Sour.

Bottle at post Pre ZBF 2010.  Hazy pink/orange.  Good cherry sourness.  Some cherry, sour aroma.  But lacks funk character.  Pretty good in mouth.  Very sour vinegar on finish.  Lacks finesse and character.  Too sour.  Very very dry.  Compared to something like unblended Girardin on draught in Belgium, well this doesnt even get into the ballpark.
bottle thanks to bhensonb. poured amber with a white head.  aroma was awesome with cherries and oak. flavor was tart with cherry and dry with oak. great stuff! thanks bill

Bottle.  Pours a hazy light brown with a slightly off-white head.  Aroma is sour cherries and a bit of wood.  Taste is malt sweetness at first, with a sour cherry and wood finish that is just heavenly.  The Pinot Noir barrels add a smooth grape characteristic and a slippery wine characteristic that makes the beer an incredible, incredible experience.  I love this beer in ways too numerous to account here - great great achievement by Russian River.

Bottle.  Thanks Chris & Meredith!  Reddish-bronze with a wallop of a sour cherry aroma.  The flavor adds a woody component, nice and funky-but-not-too-funky wildness.  This is an awesome blend of delicate flavors.  (#3868, 3/22/2010)
Bottle. Poured a orange-yellow color with good lacing and tasted of slight vinegary cherries with a not too sour finish. Best sour on the planet as far as Im concerned!

Tried the batch 3 and batch 4 side-by-side.  (Matt supplied the batch 4)  One of the striking differences was in color, the older batch was significantly lighter.  Batch 3 was very dry and tart, while the newer one was somewhat fruitier (although I never would have known what kind if the bottle didnt say so) both were very pleasant, but I preferred the batch 3.  Excited to age a few more bottles of the batch 4 and hopefully it will turn out the same.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2010 375mL Batch 4 at Carolina Goes Sour thanks to SpencerDB! Pours a cloudy orange with a very nice nose buttered waffles, oak, spices, almost whiskey barrel notes instead of wine barrels. Taste is a powerful lacto/pedo sourness that sits in the back of the throat. Not too much else. I was really unimpressed. Will need to try this a few more times. (Batch 4 - 3/22/2010)ReRate: Batch 4 courtesy of ajm. Pours a cloudy blood orange with a towering, rocky, tan head that leaves insane lacing. Aroma of cotton candy, lacto, sour cherries, baked cherry pie. Im still not too keen on the taste here. The body is thin and spritzy. And there is a massive oak dryness, tannin, leather quality that distracts from the cherry and sour elements. Its damn good, but I would take Beatification, Consecration, or Temptation over this any day.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2010 Amber hued clear brown body with a frothy off-white long lasting head.  Nose has so many qualities ranging from its malt character to the wood, currants, and abundant ester components.  Malt body is hearty and serves as a scaffold to highlight the unique facets of this amazing drink.  Vinous character pervades throughout as does the barrel wood and cherry.  Complex earthy notes in the form of leather and wood.  The sour essence is dead-nuts on with the brett and lacto blending their products with the berry, the wood and wine and various tannin and everything else that embodies the essence of sour and tart.  A truly amazing drink,.

On tap at Toronado. Light sour aroma with mild oak, lactic acid and bit of vinegar-soy. Mild malt sweetness but mostly a subtle oaky tang. Dark coppery amber clear with thin lacing head. Medum body with medium-light carbonation. Little carbonic fizz. Sour Tons of acidic tang. Light oak and mild sweet malt. Lactic and mild bitter, acidic and refreshing. A real nice sour. Crisp clean finish with a little tart fruity acidic winey after.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2010 Bottle via trade with aplusbreaks.  Clear amber pour, no carbonation and a sour cherry syrup aroma.  Flavor was vibrant sour cherries, very lactic and finished very biting and dry.  Very solid beer, can see why its as highly rated as it is. (Rerate on 6/12/10, this must have been a better bottle, because this beer is near perfect...)

bottle pours hazy orange/brown with a light tan head...lots of lacing.  Funky lime and peach nose.  Sour white wine and champagne with lots of the barrel coming out and mixing well with the tart apple and cherry flavors.

The bottle looks great, as well as the beer in the glass. Orange-brown, nice head. Starts quite sourish, also nicely fruity from the beginnig. Notes of lemon and apricot. Becomes then more and more dry and a bit nutty. Finish not as sourish as the beginning, well balanced. Intense and a bit warming aftertaste. Very nice!

A nice little match day treat for me and my lady thanks to aplusbreaks.  Pour is a deep turbid brown with a thin ring of head.  Aroma is tart, cherry, light wine, and so clean.  Flavor, ah the flavor... So tart and clean with hints of cherry, wood, and wine. Great palate too. Really refreshing and really extraordinary.  I love it.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2010 Batch 04X5. A hazy orange-brown beer with a great 2 finger head that lasts fairly long. What a wonderful sour aroma, cherries, floral, vinegary. The taste is very tart, mouth puckering sour but not over the top, while tasting the cherries in the middle with a dry ending that leaves good lacing. I want more as this does leave your taste buds dancing-what a beer!
one of the best sours.got a case of batch 4 01 when i went to the younger release. what a great sour. what a great brewing co.

375ml bottle Batch 04X3 Thanks to bhensonb ... this has made a great birthday beer!  I love sour ales and this one is top notch... pours a deep orange with a 1 finger creamy white head... quickly fades down to a thin lacing... a moderate acidic nose with some light Brett, lemon, butter, oak, and tart cherries.  lovely carbonation throughout.  sharp and dry medium body with a bigger presence of tart cherries, oak and a higher level of sourness.  The souring bacterial strains have done their job well here... the farther back the beer flows in the mouth the more tart everything becomes... leaving you with a burst of sourness on the finish while also leaving your mouth rather dry.  the deeper notes of the cherries and the Pinot Noir barrels come through over the top of the mouth and towards the back, while the lighter citrus and butter notes coat the sides and front.  Supplication is an amazing beer and leaves you wanting more... a lot of work is put into this and it shows.  A world class beer for sure.

batch 004 from 375ml. pours hazy light red with no head. aroma is of red fruits, sweet, tart cherries, oak. drinks very well rounded with tart cherries, oak, red grapes, plums, acidic lemon rind. not overly tart and finishes sweet. fantastic.

pours a cloudy dark orange with a small off-white head, and good lacing.

smell is of sour malt, wild yeast, cherry, and tart fruits.

taste is tart, fruit, cherry, wild yeast, and malt, ends very sour and somewhat dry.

Bottle. 12.7 oz. Split with and courtesy of James. My mid-millenium mark brew. Rating number 500! Pours a firm, hazy amber-orange with a moderate, white head. Aroma of lemon, orange zest, corriander, wheat, bread, malts, sour cherries, grapefruit, dry hops, honey and pine. Full bodied with a chewy, sticky, tart palate. Finish is slow, sour as hell, and full of bitter tanginess. Outrageously delicious, supremely-crafted sour ale from Russian River. Epic brew for such a great milestone in my beer-tasting journey. Cheers.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2014 Bottle take out from teresas. Pours a dark reddish amber body with insane carbonation. Aroma is delicious tart and cherry. Mouthfeel is incrwdible explosion of flavor..notes of sour tart, cherries,  and overall one of the greatest sour ales Ive ever had. Sampled again on 7.18.2010 with pat at Teresas.  Sampled directly after a vertical 4 flight of consecration. This is clearly my favorite - not too big of a difference in aroma, but pours a lighter amber red body. Notes of sour cherries linger around a good second after you swallow. The Taste / aftertaste / finish is where this beer dominates consecration.  +0.1

Color is a lovely orange-brown with a creamy and persistent head. Tart aroma with funky, earthy notes, some oak and cherry. Refreshingly dry flavor, and of course sour as well. Some lemon notes come through in the finish. This is a great beer for special occasions, since its a bit expensive for everyday drinking.
All I can say is TART.  A great sipper filled with cherries in every sip.  Only downside to me is that it really dries out the tongue.  Had to have water handy to re-hydrate.

This is a kickass sour. Some of the examples of this type are like drinking a Jolly Roger green apple candy. This one is a sour *BEER*. Nice clean sour taste. Citrus with a nice cedar finish note. 

If you can find this, BUY IT.

12.68 oz. 3x4 or 4x3 (cant remember which one) bottle from City Beer in San Francisco. Finally, I get to try this! Nice light brown color with an orange hue. Fluffy slightly tan head. Looks like it is going to be a great sour. I like the look of Consecration a bit better (it was a little darker). Nice PUNGENT sour aroma with cherries. Cherry sour aroma cuts through with an insane and amazing brett aroma that is unlike anything I have smelled before. Nice subtle wood backing. Again, I feel the Consecration had more wood characteristics, but this is still amazing. Nice wood backing, brett, sour, and cherries. Just a very wonderful smelling sour. Wow, this smells more sour than it actually is. The sour flavor is not incisive, but extremely mellow (in my opinion). The cherries creep up and hit the taste buds, and the mellow brett mixes quite well with the cherries. The wood is also mellow and mixes well with the afore mentioned flavors. The sour cherry flavor is perfect; it doesnt have an artificial, medicinal, or off-putting characteristic to it (as some beers made with cherries can have). Very nice sour, and extremely happy to have tried. I like this, but I must say Consecration has a slight edge over this one.

Pours with an amber hue with a small white head that is mostly diminishing
Aroma is of dark fruits, citrus, alochol, and musk
Flavor is dry initially with a strong sour finish - amazing! The best sour ale Ive tasted by far - flavor is rich!!!
Medium mouthfeel - light carbonation.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2010 Bottle. Batch 04x4 served in a tulip. Pours a cloudy crimson with thin ivory head. Nose of light lemon, raspberry, oak, vanilla and a hint of the cherry. Taste of cranberry, green apple, vinegar, a hint of yeast, wine cork and pear. 

Sour is not my typical style; but this is a great beer. Its a cross between sweet-tarts and booze. Brilliant!

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2010 Tap @ the Hop & Vine...  Poured amber with a white head.  Spiced, fruity cherries, sour/tart aroma.  Lightly drinking, tart apple, wine-like tartness and other fruits that hinted towards cherry.  Great palate that even felt like it could clear my sinuses.  Solidly balanced body even with all the sourness.  Great for puckerheads and sour pusses.

Hazy orange brown pour ..... sour malty aroma .... taste of sour cherries a little tart and oaky with a oaky dry cherry finish smooth reminded me and my friends of a warhead sour candy with a very dry finish ...... a perfect sour ale

Bottle 375ml. @ home. [ As my rating # 13000 on ratebeer ]. Clear medium amber red color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, berry, cherry, wood, oak, tart berry, notes of lacto and brett. Flavor is light heavy sweet and acidic with a long long duration, a very very dry finish, really chicken ass sour. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. Awesome ;O) [20100301]

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2014 Bottle from Capones. This beer is worth the wait to get. I wish I had another to age a year or two. Aroma is malty, cherry, yeasty. Pours a deep rich darkness. The taste is worth savoring. Sip on this one slowly and enjoy. The cherries come through as well as some of the alcohol. Very complex to wrap your head and tongue around. One of THE BEST sours.

375 ml bottle poured into a tulip.  Orange/brown hazy color with thin white head.  Aroma is tart sour cherries and a bit of yeasty funk.  Taste grabs you right in the tongue and the back of the mouth, sour, with hints of oak and wine.  Very crisp and carbonated.  Quite complex, delicious!

Pours a clear crimson with a medium sized white head.  Little lace.  Aroma is yeasty, musty.  Some malts come through, but smells a bit like a barnyard.  Flavor is fantasic.  Sour cherries, malty, yeast...very complex and enjoyable.  Palate is consistent with the style...fizzy, light-medium body, with a finish that sticks with you.  Overall a extremely enjoyable sipper.

Bottle, batch 04x4, orange pecan shell color with faint foam, really nice aromas of
leather, wood, sour fruit, flavors of woody , musty, sour fruits, finish disappears 
rather quickly

Bottle - huge thanks inflateablehair.  Light orange amber color with a thin beige head.  Smells like a top notch sour ale; tart, dry, and oaky.  Tastes...  well, its really effin good.  Dry, sour, tart, oak, and fruity.  More details to come when I can sit down an enjoy a full bottle.  Damn.

Batch 4.  Dark amber color, fluffy tan head head, really nice pour.  The aroma is nice but its not as lively as I expected.  The flavor is sour, more so than Temptation or Beatification, with cherries, tart wild berries, plenty of wood/barrel notes, light bretty funk.  Scratchy dryness in the finish.  The flavor is not massive but more intense than some other RR Sours but perhaps not quite as complex.  Ill look forward to revisiting down the road.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2011 Bottle from batch 4. Pours a nice amber color with with a thin off white head. Pretty lively carbonation in this. Has a cherry, and wood smell to it with just a little funk. Has a nice smooth sour cherry taste to with a little wood in there as well. Not as sour as I thought this would be. Has a nice dry finish to it as well. Another wonderful sour from RR

On tap at the Falling Rock in Denver. Pours a cystal clear, ruby colored body with a thin, creamy, beige head that dissipates slowly and leaves tons of lacing. Another gorgeous beer. Aroma is tart cherries, funk, brett, oak, and some other fruity esters. Flavor is similar. Lots of tart cherries, but not over the top sour with a light sweetness. More oak, funk, brett, and fruity esters while remaining subtly vinous. Finishes dry and oaky with sweet and sour cherries that leave a lengthy aftertaste after a light body and lively carbonation. Overall, another great sour from RR. Not the most intense or complex, but very well done. Picking between these -ations is hard.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2010 Pours out a clear copper-ish amber, topped with a dense white cap, from the 375ml. bottle (batch 04X4) into a wine glass: Right off, I can tell the nose is of maraschino cherries, red wine, vinegar, and Belgian yeast. Other notable characteristics are freshly cut red and green apples, oak, wine cork, pear, dark cola, spices, notably ground ginger, and damp basement. I can go on and on with the nose. Acidic mouthfeel but also has a woody backbone. Flavors of sour cherry and lemon meat. One of the earlier ratings mention past prime orange juice and I can definitely see that. 
Not very tannic for this particular wine, which is surprising. Overall: An ale that you can go on and on dissecting... really good to try out with friends. Pairing: Rib eye, or another rich steak served at The Bull & Bear in NYC. Rebuy: Definitely. #322 on 02032010, DG.

375ml bottle, batch 04X3, courtesy of wavers1. thanks, baker! so i was "forced" to drink this one after the cork blew while it was resting in my cellar. and boy am i glad it did! pours a absolutely stunning ruby-copper with a thick, fluffy off-white head and sticky lacing. aroma can only be described as gorgeous with massive brett funk, sour red cherries, blackberries, pinot grapes, and horse blanket initially with subtle notes of wildflowers (lillies come to mind), sweet vanilla, lemon bar cakes, and earthy wood coming through as it opens up. flavor is damn near sublime with huge, tart red cherries, sour apple candy, tart apricot, red wine vinegar, and a hefty dose of brett up front with smooth oak and vanilla notes adding a touch of balancing sweetness. palate is medium bodied with brisk carbonation, mouth-watering tartness, and a lingering, dry, funky, cherry nectar finish. overall, the best sour ive have the pleasure of tasting. guess i have to thank the beer gods for popping the cork on this one for me tonight.
batch 04x2. nose is great. can smell the oak. taste isnt as sour as the nose. mild tartness.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2011 2oz at NOTB
Appearance : Hazy pale amber

Aroma : Tart and sour. A bit lactic and barnyard

Taste : Nicely tart. Slightly lactic and acidic. 

Overall : Not so complex but quite good. Not as good as consecration.

Re-rate 110415
375ml bottle thanks to mikesgroove.
Appearance : Clear pale amber with a small creamy white head. Long head retention.

Aroma : Awesome white grapes with light cherries and amazing brett. Light cough syrup (coming from the sour cherries) with tannins. Light tropical fruits.

Taste : Tannic and sour with nice white grapes and cherries. Finish is mouth puckering with sourness and tannins. Great brett profile. Rather acidic.

Overall : Very nice stuff. Nose is awesome  With the grapes, tropical fruits and light cherries. Very well balanced and very complex. Finish is too tannic for me. Still a very nice beer with so much complexity.  App 3 to 4. Taste 9 to 8. Overall 16 to 17. Over 4 to 4.1.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2010 Bottle at LS X.  Hazy orange with a white head on it.  Big sour orange and nectarine aroma.  Quite sour tasting, with a little sweetness balancing it out and more complex fruity esthers on it, plus the tart cherries themselves.  Some woodiness is present as well.  Some barnyardy funk comes forward on the finish.  This is a really delicious sour.

Draught at Sour Fest. Murky light brown with thin white head. Aroma of woodiness, big sour funk, caramel with notes of white wine from barrels. Taste is awesomely sour - very puckering, and has light fruitiness on backtaste. Very carbonated.

375 ml bottle that I received as a generous bonus in a trade with joeneugs.  Pours a hazy amber with a thin off-white head that disappeared after the first two sips and left light lace.  Very pleasant aroma of dough that is proofing, vinegar, dusty barnyard, oak, and fruit that I cannot identify specifically as cherry.  The flavor is sour, but not mouthpuckeringly so, with some vinegar, fruit (again I cannot identify if specifically as cherry), yeasty dough, and oak.  Dries out considerably towards the finish.  Effervescent on the palate.  Very, very enjoyable!

Smooth, but  vibrant and refreshing. Hazy yellow-orange with a frothy, lasting head.  Aroma is both yeast and wood.  Fine tartness and sourness from start to finish. Notes of sour cherries, green apples, and other zingy, crisp fruit.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2015 Pours a orange amber color with a tan head which fades to deccent lacing.  aroma is of sour cherries, vinger, wet hay, and some citrus.  flavor is of sour cherry, oak, apples, vinger, a little barnyard funk, and a little wine.  has a light body with alot of carbonation and a sour, bone dry finish. overall, a another excellent sour from Russian River.

Dark apple cider color. Lasting head. Barnyard and apple orchard nose with a slight astringency and some cherry. A little wet bandaid, though not as Bretty as some. Dances on the tongue. Rainwater, grape and green apple skins. One of the more subtle sours Ive had, doesnt crush your palate, but lingers well like a good wine. Refreshing.

375 mL bottle from South Bay (Batch 4, brewed December 23, 2008, bottled December 14, 2009).  Reddish-orange pour with a bubbly off-white head.  Sour apple cider vinegar aroma, with notes of cherry, wine, and wood.  Beautiful sour cherry flavor, oak, and apples.  The first sip was jaw-clinchingly sour but this is much more drinkable afterwards.  This is an outstanding sour beer worthy of the praise and price.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2010 Russian River
Supplication
 I hate sours. Why does anyone drink this shit? Poured it out. Never again. I am tired of being screwed by this brewery. Yuck. Apparently I am not the beer connoisseur I thought I was. Left a lingering ass taste in my mouth.  $13 for nothing.  Sorry to all you sour lovers out there, but this just isnt my style. Come have a barley wine sometime.
Flavors are cherry juice, barnyard and horse blanket. Pours a rusty reddish flavor with an off white head. Very dry and sour. Extremely sour not overly sweet
a truly fantastic sour.  perfectly balanced with everything it should be.  incredible on all levels.

375ml Bottle, my second in a week.  Pours a beautiful clear ruby-dark wood color with a small fluffy head.  Aroma is tart cherry, acidity, syranam cherries, wood, blackberry.  Upon sipping, the acidity hits you up front, then subsides just long enough to let you perceive layers of rich citrus-berry flavors devoid of any true sweetness. Then the acidity returns, beautifully.  The barrel-aging is complex, deepening the flavors in subtle ways rather than adding much weighty wood-barrel flavor (vanilla, oak, charred, etc).  I found myself enjoying this one as a lighter-bodied sour.  Besides the obvious acidity, Supplication does not present the intensity of flavor of Consecration, nor LAs Cuvee de Tomme.  The new bottle size is perfect for a single serving!

Dark earthy amber with a light dusting of a caramel colored head.  Aroma is wonderful.  Slightly doughy with lots of barnyard, a touch of dark fruit and some biting citrus notes.  A little bit of hay is also present.  Flavor is sour but not overwhelmingly so.  Lightly toasty with some cereal character.  Carbonation is apparent but comfortable.  Finishes out with a great balance of sweet and sour.  Overall, a great brew.

Pours a beautiful hazy-orange amber with a vivacious, well lasting white head. The lacing is amazingly thick and sticky while the mountainous froth simply wont dissipate. The aroma is very evident upon un-corking, filling the immediate space with funk and fruit. Huge funk and wood are pervasive in my sensory experience, while cherries and vinous notes offer a powerful balance. Nectar fruit and a nice lactic quality round out the subtleties. The flavor is out of this world in terms of balance and flavor quality. The fruit arrangement is amazingly unique and works perfectly here: fresh grapes, tart cherry, nectarine, apricot, and further nectar-fruit incarnations prevail. The funk character is quite amazing- farm, lacto, oak tannins, leather, and horse taint just make me smile and go in for another sip. The palate is full, frothy, pillowy, and nicely sitting, while the finish is perfectly puckering and dry. An amazing quaff indeed- one of my favorites from Russian River.

Dark copper pour with a beautiful gradation of light to dark. This draws the eye upwards to a very tight and frothy head that simply will not dissipate, and looks almost like a cappuccino. Aroma is robust and full, with lots of funk, wood, red wine, cherry, and lactic notes. The vinous and woody qualities really create a delicate and beautiful balance with the sour funk and more aggressive fruity aspects on the nose.  My first impression of the flavor is an incredible balance for a sour ale. The tart cherry and barnyard funk is totally evident, but the wine, wood, and sweet nectar fruit create an impressively full and flavorful musculature that surrounds this beers skeleton of sourness. The result is a very impressive body of work by Russian River. Palate is excellent; with full body and a smooth massaging characteristic on the tongue. The funk is not overly aggressive, and this brew slides down exceptionally easily. Truly a treat.

Pours deep red with huge white head, with lots of carbonation and lasting lace in the glass.  Aroma is full of pinot spiciness, oak, and lots of tart cherries.  A huge complex taste up front is pinot, oak, leading into some mocha and vanilla tastes before the tart cherries blast your tastebuds with mouth puckering sour that ends a bit dry and leaves you wanting more.  Excellent brew, best sour Ive had!

Batch 04X5.  The pour is an effervescent, clear, crimson-amber color with a fizzy, creamy, rocky, very full, off-white head which continues to grow, lasts throughout, and leaves sparse but drippy lace.  The nose is interesting with sour cherries, spicy oak notes, wet earth, some funky mushroom notes, some raisins and toffee poking through, maybe some mocha and red currant.  The flavor is even better with a nice balance of sweet, tart, funk, and complexity; the cherry notes and the brett create a nice tartness without being overly sour, some sweet raisins, brown sugar, bretty funkiness, similar earthy tones and spicy Pinot notes work well together, toasted oak, and hints of mushrooms.  The palate is nice with a tart quenching mouthfeel, a medium body, and nearly lively carbonation.  It finishes with some wet oak and Pinot spice adding just a bit of bitterness to match some sweet mocha and lingering cherry tartness making its full presence.  A very nice sour from a great brewery.  Somehow finds a nearly puckering tartness in the finish but keeps all the complexity through the flavor progression.  The brown ale has been altered a great deal but hints of the base beer still show through.  An interesting combination of characteristics in this one but RR always seems to make it work, well.

Incredible range of flavors in a really drinkable brew that is perfect with seafood or solo. 375 ml bottle pours copper red with thin off-white foam that leaves lace traces over the whole glass. Intense aromas of apples, bread, and a touch of brandy really takes off as the beer nears room temp.  Tastes of champane, sour apples, sour cherries, oak. Finishes fairly dry, but with lingering fruit.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2010 (375ml bottle thanks to a generous BA at BA La Muerta release and ericandersnavy) Pours murky orange with great lasting bubbles. Nose of tart cherries, cranberries, oak barrel, funk and nail polish. Taste of salt, capers, black cherries, tart apricots and currants. Very smooth and tart. Various bottlings of batch 4 have been different, but this is a phenomenal sour when at its best.
bottle thanks to a ba at the balm bottle release.  deep amber pour with a cream head.  nose is tart, wood, funk, and slightly acidic.  great on the palate, very sour, cherries, funk, wood, and bugs.

Hazy light brownish with a lovely orange glow resting underneath a decent sized white head that leaves fantastic lazing on the glass used. Aroma is generally somewhat muted with subtile notes of funk, vanilla, light lemon, wood and perhaps just a touch of the cherries. Flavor is delivering way more than expected based on the aroma, just an exploation of woody notes and sweet nectar, sweet cherries, vanilla and light chocolate followed by an amazing sour finish that really stretches the flavors out to every corner of your mouth with sour and almost kind of meaty cherries, lemons, funk and fresh vanilla. Ends on a dry and burning note with a lingering light "meaty" cherry sweetness.

Being, at most, simply one who is more curious about sour beers than one who really digs them, I can say I really liked this. Nice pour with a waning off white/tan head. Sour cherry, light oak, and spice aroma. Nice mouthfeel with even, light carbonation. Classic Belgian sour flavors of earth, hay, sour fruit, and the nice subtle addition of winey oak. I liked it, but I think just a tad bit ov errated probably owing to my lack of zealotry for this style.

Bottle.  Pours clear copper with an off white head.  Aroma is tart with a lot of funk, oak, underripe fruit and malt.  Flavor is intensely tart with lots of oaky tannins and a dry finish.  Moderate palate and crisp with light carbonation.

375 mL.  Pours with a body like champagne, a dark reddish brown, like the color of iced tea, lots of bubbling up the side of the glass.  Aroma is all cherries and sour loveliness.  Flavor is a subtle explosion of sour cherries and apples, before fading into a slightly oaky finish.  So tart, so good, must have more.  Originally rated this a 4.4, but after having a bit more, I realized thats too low.  This couldnt have been done much better.  Really amazing, well-balanced brew.

One helluva beer. Amazing interplay between beer, sweet and sour cherries, barrel and wild yeast. The depth of the cherries is fantastic, the sourness is refreshing, the barrel pulls everything together. A wonderful beer.
Pours a deep rich amber with a small off white head. Nose is cherry, rhubarb, raspberry, tart fruit, and Brett. Taste is similar with a smooth tart cherry finish. Great sour!

Batch 4

Appearance:  Pours an clear amber/copper with a dense fizzy white cap of film. Within the clear body, you can see plenty of visible rising bubbles. The beer leaves behind spotty lace.

Aroma:  Fresh cut red apple, wine barrel, wine cork, musty basement and pear.

Taste:  Both wood and acid duke it out on my tongue for the first big bold flavor to hit my mouth. As it settles, the sourness outlasts the woody notes.  Im amazed that between the wood and the sour notes, this beer doesnt not seem very tanic or astringent to my tongue.  I can pick out lemon and sour cherry for the fruits, and my imagination takes me to  past prime orange juice

Mouthfeel: Thin to medium bodied, very fizzy and refreshing.

Overall: Very sour, very woody, but balanced and clean at the same time. Wow man!!

Pours out amber gold with thin layer of bubbles. Smell is sweet but sour . Taste is sour upfront with some tart fruity funkyness. Flavors are cherries, grape, acid, oak,and yeast. Complex but smooth. Very refreshing. Lambic like. Good stuff

A: Supplication is a hazy, light brown color with no head and some spotty lacing.

S: A huge burst of sour cherries, acetic and lactic acids, brett, and oak. Absolutely wonderful.

T: The taste is even better than the nose (and thats a difficult task). Wonderful sour cherry flavor, lots of lactic acid, and a mild funkiness. There is also a nice tannic component contributed by the barrels and (presumably) the cherries.

M: The carbonation is very light, but works well for this beer. The mouthfeel is quite slick and the body is medium.

D: Such a great combination of flavors and aromas, along with an amazing level of refreshment. This is one of the best wild ales Ive had, and Im never disappointed by Russian River.

batch 4. pours pinkish amber orange with a large foamy off white head. Very soft with fine bubbles. The aroma is oaky and tart with a very nice rich fruit character. Grapes, cherries, melon, and a bit of leather and funk. The flavor is gorgeous. Tart cherries, citrus peel, leather and oak. Sour, dry, and super complex. A real masterpiece.
on tap at the brewpub in santa rosa, out of a tulip. excellent brew another great sour ale from RR.

Where to start, another amazing sour from Russian River.  The pinot characteristics come through.  Vinnie has perfected the domestic sour.   The "barnyard" is minimized and the crispness shines.  A bit of cola but the barrel choice chops that down.  An amazing beer. 

Consecration is my favorite sour, so this is rated in comparison to that and .2 less.

Light brown with a slight red hue, clear, thin head, slow bubbles. Aroma- barrel funk, sourness, underlying cherry.       Taste-very sour cherry, backbone of really complex malts. Long finish with earthy, sweet elements. Body on the fuller side. Batch 004x2

Sampled at Rose and Crown in Palo Alto. A really interesting brew. A true sour. It was harsh on the palate after Pliny the Younger but after a few sips this beer really took over and cleansed the palate and made for a really nice drink and the crispness of the sour was fantastic. So worth a try.

Bottle 04x2.. Pours a red orang with a lasting white head...Aroma is very very tart and funky... Flavor is very sour up front but finishes with a nice tart sweetness... Lots of carbonation.. Awesome beer!

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2010 Pours ruby-brown with one finger head. Aroma is cherry and red fruit, a little funk and lacto. Carbonation is high/medium-high. The brew is quite sour, and has wonderful flavor of fruit and oak. The finish doesnt linger long. A fantastic beer.

Batch 04x1.  Supplication is a wonderful beer.  This is the third time that Ive tried it, and my appreciation for Russian Rivers brewing only grows.  This is probably my favorite of their normal sour rotation.  It is a rust-colored beer with a big, white, small-bubbled head.  The aroma is a symphony of cherries, oak, brett, fruity malt, old leather, apricots, plums and grass.  The flavor is tart and dry but smooth, pulling in the wide array of flavor to a wonderful harmony.  The flavors in Supplication are a tad more balanced against each other than most RR sours (no complaints about any of them, though) without any particular flavor dominating.  The mouthfeel is light and mildly effervescent.  Its a very refreshing beer and I cant help going back for more.  Absolutely delicious.

This is ... well sour. Had a glass from the tap at Teresas following a consecration. This is dryer and more sour. It has a fairly strong aroma of cherries. Overall, a great beer that reminds me of a dry champagne.

9th December 2008. Hazy orange amber beer. No real head. Sharp lambic nose followed by a sour taste! Fortunately it isnt a bottle of lemon juice. The cherries are subtle. Nicely balanced and drinkable sour although I wish there was more barrel characteristics coming through.

375ml bottle, batch 2.  Pours a hazy reddish golden brown color with a medium sized off white head.  The aroma is tart cherries, woody, acidic and moderately sour.  The Brett fingerprints are there as well.  The flavor is heavy with tart cherries, caramel malts, woody, and an overall sourness that is very drinkable.  This is extremely well crafted.  Medium bodied and smooth.  I had this batch when it was fresh and it has aged wonderfully.

Orange, long lasting off white head, good lacing.
Aroma is lightly sour, good amount of citrus, some sweetness, cheese.
Flavour is fairly sharp, acidic, lots of citrus, pink grapefruit tartness, good funk, sweetness lingers throughout.
Tart mouthfeel, medium body, moderate carbonation.
Finishes long, tart, high acidity, dry. 
Pretty damn good. Each sip brings new flavours and even more complexity. Best American brewery. 
375ml bottle obtained in a trade with TheCheeseMan, thanks Dan.
Opened on March 24, 2009.
Batch 003.
2009 Bistro Barrel Aged Fest.  Poured hazy reddish amber, granny smith apple, passion fruit, wood, little malty.

Ok I was going to save Veritas 006 for #1300, and then I had this at the Bistro Barrel Aged Fest, and it seemed even more worthy, so here goes.  Pours a brilliant reddish amber with slight haze and a half-inch of creamy off-white foam.  Aroma is amazing with sour cherry, bretty and lactic notes, leather, oak, and some sweet malt.  Flavor is tart, with brett, lacto, pedio, funk, and some sweet caramel malt, sour cherries, oak, and spice.  Complex and just amazingly good flavor.  Sour but not overly so like Beatification can be.  Medium body with a sharp, acidic palate and a long finish.  Went back for this two more times despite all the other great barrel aged beers there.  Great beer, Vinnie!  Worth the long wait.

Pours a slightly cloudy golden amber with thin fizzy white foam head. Wonderful aroma of tart oakiness and dark fruit. Puckering but not too acidic with lots of oak sourness and dark fruit flavor especially sour cherries. Nice balance of sweet and tart with dry finish.
Hazy golden pour.  Aroma is loaded with cherries and wood with some lactic tartness.  Flavor is tart but not overly sour with a lot of wood and cherries.  This was VERY good.
Never a favored style but this is an interesting beer.  Such a sour nose.  Wood, cherries.  Flavor to match with a ton of funkiness.  So sour!  This beer screams with personality.

Served on tap at Obriens TION night in a 13oz Chimay on Feb 2. Have had it in bottle (batch 003) on several occasions previously. Bottle matches tap pretty close.

Color was a dull gold with a light white head. Smells of tart fruits, cherry, apple, sourness. A very drinkable sour, less biting than a flanders or some of RRs other sours, medium bodied, and less fruits in the taste than I expected. Good stuff.

375ml bottle from WeeheavySD. Pours brown with orange and gold edges with white head. Aroma is sour as hell with wood,  cherries, and some funk. Flavor is tart with some sour cherries, funk, and some wood. This has a lip smacking tartness to it. Really good stuff. I cant stop licking my lips. Good beer to celebrate my 30th birthday.

On tap at Falling Rock Denver. Pours out a cloudy brown topped with a small head. Aroma was sweet candy, light berry notes, plenty of the funk and some wood. Taste more of the funk, tart, sweet cherries, some oak, and a little spice. Very nice.

Sour cherries and dark red tannins dominate the nose.  Burnt sienna pour with ample head.  Funky, iron-like tartness comes out for a romp around your tastebuds.  Darker and heavier for a sour, and the attempted contrast is pulled off beautifully.  The solid body combined with the wine-like elegance of the finish is something to be applauded.  Woody notes abound, but do not overpower.  Quite a treat.

Bottle Batch 3 from miketd. Pours murky brown, dissipating head. Nose is big and soft, lots of vinous type notes. Cherries are still vibrant in this one. Funky and sour nose. On taste, this is how to do a cherry sour. Softened acidity. The oak comes across to prop up the cherry notes. This is really a more refined version of the Cascade Sang Royal. More nuanced and pretty deep. Exceptional.

Bottle from MRuesch. Thanks Matt! Hazy brown pour with a thick tan head. Bretty, vinegar, sour cherry, tart aroma. Tangy tart cherry taste with some vinegar tartness. Not much of a sour fan, but I thought this exceptionally well done.

Batch 3. Poured a slightly cloudy orange, with just a little foam on top. Aroma is as expected: RR Sour-ness and a little light fruit. Flavor as expected again, but gladly with a little more complexity due to its medium amount of alcohol. In other words, its very similar to Beatification, but has a little more flavor simply because its slightly heavier. Palate medium, par. Overall, good. Top 50 material? No.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2011 Batch 3 bottle from glouglouburp.  Thanks again for the sweet trade.  pours an amber orange with a nice beige head.  leaves some sparse lace on the glass.  beautiful beer.  aroma of cherries, leather, light bretty funk, cotton candy, caramel, and earth.  Flavor  is  moderate cherry tartness, bread.  well balanced, refreshing, nice bouquet opens up as it warms.  awesome beer.  wish i could drink this more often.  sad that my bottle is now empty.  


batch 4x4 extra from hophead 22.   Cherry sourness, a lot of oak, some doughy funk.  vinegar.  Great.  The wood flavor in this is a agressive.  Good for sure, but I prefer beautification above all RR beers Ive tried.  


batch 006x2
ultra drinkable.  nice clean dry leather funk. touch of cherry and red wine oak barrel give some added complexity.   watered down cranberry wine with a touch of balsamic.   pleasant cherry lactic acid sourness.   moderate level of tartness.    this stuff drinks itself.

Stone Sour Fest 2009
Poured a murky amber.
Nose was of candi sugar and vinegar. 
Taste was sour, plenty of vinegar to the point where it burns a little, and finishes with an odd residual sweetness.

Been waiting on this one for a while, and tonight seemed like the night. Big (big) thanks to Bobby91w for this gem. Batch 3. Pours a reddish orange-copper, with a large, very dense head. The aroma is tantalizing. Dusty citrus, funk, lots of oak, not much of that pinot comes through. Hoo boy thats delicious. The tartness lingers forever in your mouth, and what starts as a very acidic oaky citrus/cherry flavor ends up showing more of the pinot from those barrels, and more bitterness. If the sourness in here didnt come across quite so harshly, this would be up with Deviation and Isabelle. As is, it exceeded expectations (which were high to begin with) - this is a damn tasty beer.
Tasting at TARs. Batch 001. Pours a clear amber. Smells lightly sour. Sweet and sour with some bitterness. Light grassy and leathery aromas. Hints of alcohol. Medium bodied. Soft carbonation.

Thanks to stlwill for sharing this beauty (and probably a couple other I forgot about).  Pours hazy amber with a minor white head.  The aroma has lots of sour funk, lactic acid, oak, vinegar, tart cherries, wild yeast and barnyard.  Medium body with some graininess and some sharp, but soft carbonation.  The flavor starts off with berries, lactic sourness, some spiciness, oak, dryness for the style, vinegar, funkiness from the yeast and dry sour cherries.  The finish is very tart and dry.  This is an excellent beer in every way.

Thank to MrBunn, I got some of this.  Oh thats good....strong aromas of sour cherries, and some wood. pours orangey red with a nice little head. Taste is beautiful...Sour and tart cherries, some oakieness, just damn tasty.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy amber with a decent sized head and aromas of funk, tart cherries and so forth.  Flavor is similar with the cherry presence coming through a little subdued, but very nice.  Thanks, Kan!
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Batch 003
Poured from 375ml bottle into Duvel tulip.
A nice "pop" once the cork came off...a nice sound. ;-)

A - Pours a burnt orange with a white fizzy head. Bubbles linger on top and around the edge of the glass. Carbonation continues to rise up from the bottle of the glass to the top. Some lacing, but the head isnt all that sticky, which doesnt bother me at all.

S - A wonderful fruity tart smell immediately hits the nose. Lots of oranges, apples, mangos, pineapple mixed with some wonderful sour cherries, lemons, and limes. A fruit explosion, you could say. There isnt an overpowering of either, a perfect match, which is something I look for in an American Wild Ale. Too much of one or the other takes away from the beer - this is a perfect balance.

T - Nice and tart/sour right off the bat but not much sweetness at all, which is surprising because of the nose. I also get some oak/wood flavors. A dry finish, much like champagne. The aftertaste is where I get some fruity sweetness - very nice. Really enjoyable, just what I was looking for when I opened this bottle.
